description:
Slinky Physics Workshop - Wellington, This one-day workshop experimentally investigates the physics of the slinky spring using past IYPT problems.
It is for both students and teachers, attending as a school group or individually.  
The workshop will reinforce the waves, mechanics and practical achievement standards of NCEA and their equivalent across other examinations. It will be especially useful for
Current year 12 students who plan to participate in the 2026 NZ Tournament or try for the NZ Representative team going to Zurich in July
Teachers new to the New Zealand Young Physicists' Tournament who want to support students through the Tournament in 2026
This is a full day workshop, between 9am and 4pm. We are providing lunch and refreshments in the breaks, plus a goodie bag for every student. We will also have workbooks for all participants including a teacher's version. 
You should bring a water bottle and your phone to film some of your experiments, sometimes in slow motion. A laptop may also be useful for sides to present your work, but it is not essential as whiteboards are available. All experimental equipment will be provided.
The cost is $135 for a school group of up to four people, or $40 for individual teachers and students. Both prices are inclusive of GST.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene.
Timing:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm

description:
Smart Property, Smarter Retirement, Are you between 30 and 55 years old?
Do you have a clear plan for a financially comfortable retirement?

At our free property investment seminar, you’ll discover how smart strategies can help you:
* Build reliable income streams
* Protect your financial future with debt reduction
* Live comfortably in retirement from long term rental income

Bonus for Attendees
You’ll be entitled to book a FREE one-on-one consultation with our licensed financial advisers and if qualified, a full financial plan (valued $995 - $1999). This starts with a discovery session to understand your financial situation and goals. From there, our property team can assess the best available property options and present those that align perfectly with your objectives.

Seats are limited — don’t miss this opportunity.

Our Speakers

Lara Maloney
Director of MyFutureNZ Ltd and a Qualified Financial Adviser, Lara has an MBA (First Class Honours) specialising in Finance and Marketing. She has completed her NZ Certificate in Financial Planning (Level 5) and is authorised by the Financial Markets Authority to provide financial advice and investment planning services. Lara is committed to shifting the paradigm around the traditional 30-year mortgage and helping others create personal wealth.
FSP 529864

Campbell Venning
An esteemed residential investment specialist, Campbell brings an impressive three decades of extensive property knowledge. He has led a property-education franchise network, an investor-focused property development company, and a technology start-up offering specialised investor tools. Campbell's passion for real estate motivates him to assist others to build wealth through property and secure a strong income into retirement.
Licensed REAA 2008

description:
Steve Sinclair - public lecture, Steve Sinclair - public lecture
'fourth_space, beyond Architecture as a Narcissistic Entity'

LT2 at the School of Architecture and Design VUW.

About this Event

Steve Sinclair is co-founder and director of fourth_space, a practice that seeks to "rescue space to make places," to "recycle bits of left-over architecture," and to make Architecture as "a unifying discipline - politics, regulation, location, design, finance, construction and user experience - that should maintain social and artistic concerns."


https://cdn-az.allevents.in/events10/banners/b883d840-741c-11f0-867e-7d1fd93eb1fd-rimg-w1200-h597-dcd5d5d5-gmir.jpg

Steve studied at the Mackintosh School of Architecture and the Bartlett School before completing an MSc at the London School of Economics. He worked at Morphosis, Ron Arad Associates, FAT (Fashion Architecture Taste), and Harper Mackay (MAK), before joining Paolo Mozzato in 2004, and subsequently Huw Williams, to form fourth_space.
In addition to directing fourth_space Steve is a design advisor to the Hackney Estate Regeneration Design Group, teaches at the AA and is co-owner of award winning Ombra bar & restaurant - where the “Negroni_Talks...!” happen. Available on podcast, these events "promote looser, all-encompassing engagements with greater participation, as well as dispelling false authority and un-challengable ‘expert’ opinions.... "
Steve's lecture is hosted by Te Kāhui Whaihanga ~ New Zealand Institute of Architecture in association with School of Architecture and Design, Victoria University of Wellington ~ Te Herenga Waka and the Architectural Centre.

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1, This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

Description
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

• Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
• Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
• Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
• Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
• Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
The "Other" Curriculum Roadshow - WELLINGTON, Multiple Choice: Wellington Screening and Education Discussion
Join the Aotearoa Educators Collective (AEC) for a pivotal evening of discussion focused on the future of education with colleagues in Wellington. We are proud to host a screening of the compelling documentary, Multiple Choice - see the trailer here.
This film explores the profound and often challenging impacts of high-stakes, standardised testing on students, teachers, and the entire education system. Following the screening, we will open up a vital conversation about how we assess, Curriculum reform, and celebrating what is great about what we are doing now in Aotearoa New Zealand.
Your Voice Matters
This event is a crucial opportunity for educators, policymakers, parents, and community members to engage directly with key issues shaping our local schools and kura. We aim to:
Spark informed discussion about the role of assessment and qualifications.
Reflect on the implications for the ongoing redevelopment of the New Zealand Curriculum, national testing, and NCEA.
Encourage collaboration across our sector to reimagine equitable, future-focused pathways for all learners.
The Event Plan
Come together for a social networking event and evening of insight, hosted at St Patrick’s College.
The event will include:
A screening of the documentary Multiple Choice (approx. 1 hour).
A dynamic DRAFT Panel Discussion featuring a mix of local and national leaders:
Panel Convenor - Mark Potter | Principal of Berhampore School
Ragne Maxwell | Principal of Porirua College
Lynda Knight | Principal of Glenview Primary School
An Audience Q&A to foster broad community dialogue.
This is your chance to connect with peers and contribute your perspective to the national conversation. Secure your spot today!
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Sweat Reflect & Connect with Carolyn Patchell, Sweat – get those endorphins going!
Reflect – review our movements!
Connect – spend time with our classmates!
Sessions:
All Day 10.15am to 4pm $55
Morning 10.15am to 1pm $30
Afternoon 1.15pm to 4pm $30
Our day will start with a 30-minute Dance Fitness session that will include warm-ups but no cool down as we’ll head straight into a Tips and Tuition session. We’ll break down movements, go over cues and choreography, and look at how to increase or decrease intensity (or manage any injuries we might be carrying). We’ll take a break together and some healthy snacks will be provided along with hot drinks. We’ll then head into another Dance Fitness session where you can put your newfound knowledge to use (or just have some fun and party like it’s Friday night)! After a stretch and cooldown, we’ll do a bit of a wrap up over lunch (bring your own) and spend some time relaxing and chatting. Hot drinks will be available, or you can pop out if you need a barista made flat white!
If you’re not staying for the full day, we’ll say farewell after lunch and the rest of us will prepare to greet those coming in for the afternoon session.
The afternoon will start with a Strong Fit session which will contain elements of our Thursday night class. We’ll then move straight into a Tips and Tuition session which will look at all elements of our Strength Based Combo class. This will include form, technique, options, and how to maximise your weekly workouts. We’ll then take a break with some healthy (and easily digested) snacks before we power into a final Strong Fit session. Following the session, we’ll have a decent stretch and take the time to review what we’ve learned, chat amongst ourselves, and say farewell before our day concludes at 4pm.

description:
David & Shimna @ Newlands, This dynamic guitar & violin duo are re-united for a series of sizzling shows across New Zealand in 2026. Shimna will be back from Belfast, Northern Ireland & this tour marks a special reunion, a chance to bring their close harmonies, infectious fun vibes, and exquisite guitar and fiddle playing back home to New Zealand where it all began!
Seated Show
Intimate Setting
Cheaper $15 tickets for under 18s
Saturday 28th March at Kingston House
Doors open from 6:30pm / show starts at 7pm (8:45pm finish).
Tickets are VERY limited - don't miss out!
What people are saying:
“Seriously sublime stringwork. World-class melodies.”
“Amazingly written and performed piece that kept me glued through to the end.”
“Great guitar riffs and performance – your two voices are so nice together.”
"OMG I love you guys"
David & Shimna are an acoustic guitar and violin duo whose music has been described as “absolutely beautiful… perfectly played… fragile yet powerful.” Their sound blends intricate guitar work, lyrical fiddle, and close vocal harmonies into a powerful yet vulnerable experience for all present.
David is based in Auckland, while Shimna has been living in Belfast, Northern Ireland since March 2025. This tour marks a special reunion, a chance to bring their music back home to New Zealand and share it in the way it’s meant to be heard: up close and personal in a town near you.
This summer, they’ll be touring small halls and community spaces across Aotearoa, bringing their songs to places most musicians don’t usually go. Each evening is an invitation: a night of stories, connection, and an experience intended to stay with you long after the music has ended.

description:
The Art of Mending - Micro Mill, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.

This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.

There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!

In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.

Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.

Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.

Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.

Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.

description:
Together in Dialogue: Te Tiriti o Waitangi and Pacific Partnerships, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Pacific style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and effective insights. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from different communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Together in Dialogue?
In Together in Dialogue, you will share meaningful conversations around Te Tiriti o Waitangi and the role and responsibilities of Pasifika as allies. By engaging in deep talanoa, you will explore cultural, historical, and contemporary implications of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and how Pasifika people can strengthen this unique relationship and promote cultural awareness.
This is a 3.5 hour in-person learning experience. The day will begin with a Pōwhiri, to welcome you into the space.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Waikanae Makeup Masterclass - 27.09 @2 pm, About this event
Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.
During the class, Nikki will demonstrate step-by-step techniques on a model while you get to apply your own makeup. You'll have access to professional products and tools to follow along and create your flawless everyday look. It’s fun, interactive, and designed for all skill levels.
"I can’t wait to share my knowledge with you and help you create a makeup routine that leaves you feeling fabulous and confident every day!" – Nikki
What You Need to Know:
No equipment required! We’ll provide all makeup products, brushes, and mirrors.
Bring a willingness to learn and a positive attitude.
Classes are capped at 12-15 participants to ensure personalised guidance.
Arrive 10–15 minutes early to get settled.
Please come with a clean, makeup-free face so you can get the best results.

Each holiday the programme changes to add variety for the many returning students.

description:
Water Casting - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.
Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.
You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.
Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!
We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.
The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.
A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.
This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.
For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.
Workshop fee $128, Early bird $115 till 17 August.

description:
Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Paciﬁc style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and eﬀective insights. Tai refers to ocean waters, which represent your opportunity to rise through the ebb and ﬂow of this learning journey. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from diﬀerent communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Voices from the Moana?
In Voices from the Moana, you will explore and share rich narratives of healing and resilience from different Pacific nations and perspectives. The Pacific ocean is a diverse place and we have our own unique stories of healing through traditional practices, beliefs and methods. This Talanoa Tai learning experience invites reflection on your own understanding of different healing modalities from the Pacific and the impact it has on your worldview. It will equip you to advocate for social justice through Pacific voices. You'll gain practical tolls and insights that you can apply directly to your work.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
 Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

description:
Wairarapa Early Childhood Education Emergency Planning Workshop, Would you and your staff be confident in an emergency? Do you have a plan, and more importantly have you practiced it recently?

We are holding a free workshop for Early Childhood Education Centres in Carterton to come together to discuss your emergency plans.

This workshop is an opportunity for ECEs to share challenges and solutions and get advice from our Emergency Management Advisors.

It aims to help ECEs plan for significant events such as earthquake, tsunami, armed intruders and to share ideas and network around emergency planning.

This is an opportunity for Centre Managers, Directors, Health & Safety Representatives or Leads to:

- Share solutions, practical advice and learnings from recent events.
- Discuss your current plans with emergency management professionals.
- Learn more about our local hazards and important planning information including lessons learnt from the Christchurch Earthquake, Christchurch Mosque Attack and Cyclone Gabrielle.

Hope to see you there as we build safer and more resilient ECEs and communities together.

Places are limited to a maximum of 15 people attending each session. This workshop is endorsed by the Ministry of Education.

For more information, please email melanie.arcus@wremo.nz

We aim to make our community events inclusive to all people. If you are attending the event and have specific accessibility requirements, you can send us an email at melanie.arcus@wremo.nz with the event name and we will get in touch to see how we can meet your needs as best we can.

description:
Wellington Foraging for Wild Edible Weeds Workshop, Join Felicity of Wild Botanica for a wander around the edges of the Innermost Community gardens to learn about commonly found, wild, edible weeds. Build a relationship with a natural world that is overflowing with abundant, wild, edible, nutritious, medicinal plants. Learn their names & get to know them, along with folklore & stories from the past.

By the end of the workshop you will:
- understand the basic principles of foraging, including sustainable harvesting
- feel confident in identifying 10-15 wild edible plants
- know about their nutritional & medicinal benefits
- know about common toxic/dangerous plants to avoid when foraging
- know about the best ways to prepare your foraged greens for maximum nutritional benefit & flavor
- feel empowered to include foraged greens in your everyday diet

Walk away with hands on, practical skills & knowledge that you can use in your own life.

Investment includes hands on wild weed walk & discussion, cup of foraged herbal tea & wildly delicious foraged snack.

To learn more about Felicity and her offerings,
visit @wildbotanica.nz on social media
or www.wildbotanica.co.nz.
For any queries, please email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 30th August 2025, Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.
This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.
We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.
This isn’t just about food—it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.
Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit
www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.
For questions, email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.

2025 Pūkaha Wairarapa Garden Tour, 2025 will mark 15 years of Pūkaha’s much-loved annual fundraiser – the Wairarapa Garden Tour.

This two-day, self-drive garden tour will feature beautiful and unique gardens in North Wairarapa.

Highlights include…

Scenic Garden Trails
Wander through enchantingly designed gardens adorned with an abundance of native plants, exotic flowers, and captivating sculptures.

Meet the Gardeners
Gain insights from passionate gardeners who have nurtured these landscapes into works of art.

Exclusive Workshops
Learn gardening tips and tricks from experts, and uncover the secrets behind creating and maintaining a stunning garden.

The Market Fair

description:
Silver Ring-Making Day, This great one-day class is ideal for beginners, but experienced students are also welcome. Have fun making your own ring or perhaps a wonderful present for a loved one! The workshop runs from 10am - 4pm with a lunch break.

Students will practice making simple textured or polished rings in either copper or brass, then move onto making one or more silver rings from start to finish. They will learn measuring, texturing, soldering and finishing techniques to make beautiful, wearable rings!

Students can choose from creating textured, stamped or polished rings in flat metal, or adding in stacking rings in wire and bar. More experienced students may wish to make a wider ring, or a series of rings, perhaps in a tapered form or including finer details and finishing, or possible stone setting. This is a one-day class aimed at either providing a fun experience with a great result, or excellent grounding in basic jewellery techniques for those wanting to pick up the activity. Course fee includes practice materials and 8g sterling silver. Extra materials are available to purchase in the workshop if time allows. As this is only a one-day class we will be providing a set range of widths for your ring bands so as to make the project enjoyable and achievable.

Kids aged 12 and up (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
WellyForge#6, 10th Dec 2025 (Christmas Edition), Join us to help progress Wellington by bringing together science, tech & investors from across the city into an informal, fun and informative meet-up. The goal of the event is that you learn something new, meet someone new, have fun and we all start forging new paths ahead for Wellington.
Focus of the night is the KiwiNet award winners who are from Wellington. KiwiNet funds the commercialization of public research across 19 universities in NZ. So, your show will be:
1st Speaker: Dr Ben Mallett from the MacDiarmid and Robinson Research Institute (part of Victoria) who won the Breakthrough Innovator Award, and is a co-founder of JxB Space Systems.
Quickfire Speakers:
Maci Libby, Massey Design Graduate, founder of Wise Gear NZ, passionate about outdoor adventure
Suse Reynolds, KiwiNet Commercialization Icon Award Winner, and big start-up fan (investor & Director)
Lachlan Mead, Young Enterprise Scheme Award Winner, and founder of the Christmas Chaos card-game, yes, copies will be available!
2nd Speakers: Prof Rob Weinkove who leads the Malaghan Institute's CAR-T cell program which won the KiwiNet PwC Breakthrough Project Award, and John Robson CEO of BioOra, a spin-out from the Malaghan which recently raised $15m to accelerate roll-out of its cancer treatment.
The venue is bohemian bookstore, Undercurrent, a perfect venue for story telling but tickets are limited - so please reserve yours, but if you do end up not being able to come please return the ticket!
Join WellyForge

description:
Alzheimers Marlborough Art, Crafts and Collections Trail 2025, Alzheimers Marlborough Art, Crafts and Collections Trail 2025
Coinciding with World Alzheimers Month our 4th Annual Art, Crafts & Collections Trail is once again bringing art to your community and showcasing some of our local, wonderfully talented artists, while helping us provide services for people living with dementia and their families and carers.

We have a large selection of artists, craftspeople and specialty collectors displaying their art in their own studios, or in shared spaces in the Marlborough Alzheimers Centre and a selection of galleries around Blenheim.

Whether you're an admirer of visual arts, handcrafted masterpieces, or unique collectibles, this weekend promises an inspiring array of works to explore. Visitors can engage directly with artists, gaining insights into their creative processes and the stories behind their works. Families and friends are encouraged to come together to celebrate creativity while supporting a meaningful cause. This very special fundraising event helps us meet the increasing demand for the range of services we offer to support local people affected by dementia, and their families.

The Art Trail is a self-drive event with tickets available for just $30 per person, on sale from 19th August at the following places:

- Marlborough Alzheimers Centre, 8 Wither Road, Blenheim - Monday to Friday, 9am-3pm
- Scenic Hotel Marlborough, 65 Alfred Street, Blenheim - Open 7 days 9am - 9pm
- Agrivit Ltd, 29 High Street, Renwick - Monday to Friday, 8am-4.30pm
- Marlborough Art Gallery, Library Building, 15 High Street, Blenheim - Tuesday to Friday, 10am – 4pm, Weekends, 1pm – 4pm

Tickets are valid for both days of the Art Trail. The tickets show where to find each exhibitor, a brief outline of their style and an illustration showing the amazing talent on display.

Devonshire Teas will also be available at the Marlborough Alzheimers Centre, 8 Wither Road for $5 per person during the event.

We are encouraging our very supportive Marlborough community to gather their friends together and enjoy a special weekend out and about. It’s a great opportunity to see some amazing art and talk to some of our wonderfully talented artists living and working here Marlborough. You may even be able to purchase a favourite piece of art as a gift or for your own enjoyment.

All funds raised from our Art Trail remain in Marlborough.

description:
Ōtari Raranga Hōngongoi 2025 - Intermediate, Ma te mōhio ka roa, ma te ora ka mōhio
Through learning there is life, through life there is learning

Nau mai haere mai, welcome to Ōtari Raranga Wānanga - Intermediate level

After completing about 6 beginner classes (close together) as well as practice at home you may be ready to move up to our intermediate classes. We will let you know.

We will be planning projects in advance to keep all on similar taonga.

PRojects may include new closes for your kete timata, kete waikawa, puritanga, pīkau and pōtae. We will teach you preparation, preservation and storage of harakeke - important especially over winter months.

Additionally, we will induct you to the Ōtari Pā Harakeke when ready.

With regular attendance you will deepen mātauranga gained from beginner classes and share you learnings with others. (Refer to below for a reminder).

What’s included in your intermediate ticket?
- Three hours+ weaving class with our tuakana weavers and raranga rangatira.
- Limited access to tools as you are expected to be have your own kete mahi (tool kit).
- You are expected to bring your own harakeke.
- We encourage you to harvest for yourself but if you are unable to harvest for class, we have ‘Please harvest for me’ options in addition to your ticket at least three days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by our raranga Rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua) with Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu). Supported by our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngāti Kahungunu and Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia.
- At our discretion tickets are fully refundable or transferable.
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class.
- We offer concession tickets for students, unwaged, seniors, and those with disabilities.
- It is important to us that our classes are accessible to all. If ticket costs are a barrier for you please visit our website to enquire about our reduced cost or free tickets.

Follow us on Facebook or Instagram: Otari Raranga Weavers

For more information about what to expect and what to bring visit our www.otariraranga.co.nz

TICKETING INFORMATION
Tuakana = Older sibling
Intermediate / Tuakana - General Admission: $25
Intermediate / Tuakana - Concession Admission: $20
Intermediate / Tuakana - Koha Admission: $15
Two Class Pass - Two back to back dates only: $45.00

ADD ON - Harvest for me: $20 + eventfinder fees (10 rau only) - 3 days notice required
ADD ON - Harvest for me: $40 + eventfinder fees (20 rau only) - 3 days notice required

Note: Eventfinda fees apply

We mihi to our funders and sponsors Wellington City Council, Wellington Gardens and the Ōtari-Wilton Bush Kaitiaki, Maverick Creative, Good Fortune Coffee and Wellington Apothecary.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)

Donations, Tax Credits and Corporate Gifting
- We accept koha to support Ōtari Raranga Weavers via Shared Lines Trust. This enables us to continue to offer subsidised and free events to the community.
- Shared Lines Trust is registered with Charities Service; Shared Lines Trust (CC61762)
- All donations over $5 made to The Trust are tax-deductible
- For corporate gifting or individuals requesting tax credits please email SharedLinesTrust@gmail.com
- Visit www.sharedlines.org.nz for more information

description:
The Hectet - Live And In Performance, The Hectet bring you a night of melodious and grooving electroacoustic jazz music, to celebrate the release of their debut album, Here Comes The Hectet, off the back of their recent Australian album release tour.

They will also be playing unreleased selections from their recently recorded follow-up album, French Politics, across two sets of original compositions by Hector McLachlan. The music of The Hectet draws from a wide pool of influences, reflecting an open and ambivalent attitude to genre that has given it a unique and broad appeal.

Hector (piano, synth) is a pianist and composer from Te Whanganui-a-Tara who has played across Aotearoa and the world with acts like Revulva, Salvia Palth, Rachel Andie, The Unknot, and The Teskey Brothers. He has also released an album of electronic music on US cassette label Become Eternal.

Joining him are three Pōneke demons: Phoebe Johnson (double bass), Jasper Holloway (guitar), and Abe Baillie (drums), as well as very special guest Lily Shaw (saxophone).

The Hectet aims to please, and they can't wait share their soulful and expressive stylings with you.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Jazz Festival: Alex Trask Quartet - Imaginary Folksongs, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.
Alex Trask’s ‘Imaginary Folksongs’ blends Earth folk music with a speculative style from an imaginary place. Inspired by bluegrass, Scottish folk music, and jazz performance practice, the tunes have a simplicity in common. Free improvised sections contrast carefully arranged melodies, allowing creativity and structure to coexist. The fiddle-esque melodies and straightforward harmonies create an open and inviting sound that changes depending on the musicians on stage. Performing this music as a group invites each member to paint their private imaginings, creating a unique collective folklore. The quartet will also perform a selection of tunes that inspired the music, including songs by Brian Blade, Gordon Lightfoot, and traditional melodies.

Alex Trask – saxophone
Duncan Haynes – piano
Elijah Mulheron – bass
John Rae – drums

description:
Asia After Five: Experiences in Taiwan, About the event
The Asia New Zealand Foundation and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office Wellington are hosting an evening of stories and insights from New Zealanders who have studied, worked and lived in Taiwan. Hear from the Foundation's Leadership Network members and Taiwan alumni as they share their experiences and reflect on future opportunities for Kiwis in Taiwan.
Our Asia After Five events are interactive. You will have a chance to ask questions, network with others and learn more about Asia.
Event details
Date:  Thursday 25 September 2025
Time:  5:30pm-7:00pm
Venue:  Asia New Zealand Foundation, Level 16, Fujitsu Tower, 141 The Terrace (access to building via Cable Car Lane before 6pm)
This event is free to attend, but please RSVP for catering purposes.
This event is a collaboration between the Asia New Zealand Foundation Te Whītau Tūhono and Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New Zealand (TECO).
Our speakers
Ema Kato
Ema Kato is a recent graduate from Victoria University of Wellington with a degree in Communication, specialising in intercultural communication and Mandarin. Having lived in Japan, Taiwan and New Zealand, Ema is passionate about cross-cultural exchange and will return to Taiwan next year to pursue advanced language study and a master’s program at National Taiwan University with the Huayu and Taiwan Scholarships.
Tom Durkin
Tom is currently based in Auckland, working in Private Wealth at Craigs Investment Partners. Having studied Mandarin as a part of his degree at the University of Otago, he has long held an interest in Chinese language and culture. Tom spent two months travelling in Taiwan at the end of 2023. During this time, he joined parts of the Taipei Hui with the Asia New Zealand Foundation Leadership Network, worked with a farmer in Chiayi and spent two weeks at Fo Guang Shan Buddhist monastery in Southern Taiwan. His participation in the recent Shanghai Hui with the Asia New Zealand Leadership Network sparked a desire to re-engage and immerse in Chinese culture. Tom has recently been accepted to study at the National Taiwan Normal University - Mandarin Training Center from later this year. He's looking forward to sharing his experiences and hearing more on others' perspectives of the New Zealand-Taiwan relationship.
Lauren Pattermore
Lauren Pattemore is an early-career journalist based in New Zealand, with contributions to Stuff, the Otago Daily Times, Crux and Radio New Zealand. She recently completed a media internship with the Asia New Zealand Foundation in Taipei, working with TaiwanPlus. In 2024, she was named runner-up for Best Up and Coming Journalist at the Voyager Media Awards. She holds a Bachelor of Communication from Massey University, where she specialised in expressive arts and journalism.
Rob Eland
Rob was the sole New Zealand recipient of the Taipei City Chinese Learning Scholarship in 2018, selected by Mayor Justin Lester. With the scholarship, he took a sabbatical from work and travelled to Taipei, where he lived from mid-2018 to early 2019. During this time, Rob studied full-immersion Chinese at NTNU's Mandarin Training Center (MTC) and took part in several New Zealand–Taiwan cross-cultural activities, including supporting then-Deputy Mayor Jill Day and a group of New Zealand performing arts students during their visit to Taiwan. Rob returned to New Zealand in 2019, but he looks forward to heading back to Taiwan again soon.

Speakers on the night are: Etienne Wain 黃義天 , Juhyeon 주현, brenda wang, Brecon Dobbie 布雷肯.

description:
Bride Of The Year 2025, For 55 years, Wairarapa Bride of the Year has been a mainstay in the events calendar in the region. The event returns to the Wairarapa Events Centre for 2025, where brides who were married between 1 July and 30 June and were married in the Wairarapa, and/or have lived or are living in the Wairarapa, and/or whose spouse has lived in the Wairarapa, will get the chance to relive the magic of their big day, donning their gowns again, all while raising much needed funds for Te Awhina Plunket Wairarapa.

This event is unique in its focus on Wairarapa’s flourishing wedding industry. It is a great opportunity for couples planning their own weddings to look for inspiration from other local couples, for friends and families of brides to reminisce on the weddings. It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

A ticket to Bride of the Year provides you with a night of glamour and celebration of love, all while supporting Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

A ticket to Bride of the Year provides you with a night of glamour and celebration of love, all while supporting Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

description:
CHAPPELL vs CHARLI: A Drag Fundraiser Smackdown, Friday 27 September | 9.30pm @ Ivy Bar, Pōneke
Tickets: $20 (excluding ticket fees) | Generosity options available!
All proceeds to Wellington Pride Festival!

Kia ora! brats and popstars! Get your heads out the passenger seat and get ready, cause your about to be bumpin’ that with some of wellington drags finest!
Royalty is stepping into the ring (well, the stage) for CHAPPELL vs CHARLI : a high-camp, high-stakes, drag smackdown showdown, where our fabulous local drag artists channel the icons of Charli XCX and Chappell Roan to battle it out for title of 'Queen of the Chartsverse'… all in the name of charity xx

Three lip sync rounds. Four drag titans. One glitter-drenched champion.
Each round sees performers pull a mystery song each from their assigned diva’s discography and fight for the crown based on lip sync accuracy and undeniable star quality. Think charity boxing... but queerer. Like, much queerer. Only you! The audience! And our incredible judge Rachel Winter Hase, can determine our number #1 pop icon!

Featuring:
- Homer Neurotic (multi-award-winning drag king)
- Slay West (the biggest mouth in the biz)
- Petra Fyde (now your petrified)
- Ms. Leading (Your big bros lil secret)
(and Olivia Dreams on door)

Hosted by the ever-glamorous Selina Simone, and judged by local performance legend Rachel Winter Hase, who will deliver her pop verdicts with love and lashes *whipcrack.mp3

A high-speed crash of glitter, vocals, and vengeance! Expect drag, drama, and come ready to holler, hoot, bump and help decide who is our ultimate XCX BRAT or CHAPPELL POPSTAR!

Tickets: Just $20 + fees, with donation options for those feeling generous – every cent raised goes to support Wellington Pride Festival, helping make 2025 the queerest yet!

Accessibility: Ivy Bar is located downstairs but alternative access is possible with prior planning. Please email theselinasimone@gmail.com so we can accommodate you. If you wish to attend and donate, but cost is an issue for you, please reach to me as well xx

description:
CF's PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.
***
PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK
LA VITA IN ROSA
LEVEN IN ROZE
LA VIDA EN ROSA
LA VIE EN ROSE
ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO
AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.
***
CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.
What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.
Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!
Dress Code: PINK!
Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!
Suggested Koha/Donation: $5
Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!
EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.
Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:
02-0343-0003801-007
ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.
Please give generously.
LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.
NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.
RAIN DATE: TBC
***
This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.
#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban
Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer
Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening
This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer
And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump
Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness
Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.
To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.
CUBAN☆FUSION © 2005 - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists | www.cubanfusion.co.nz | info@cubanfusion.co.nz | 021-621-245

description:
Made to bloom, exhibition by Josefine Gronkrans, We have a solo exhibition coming up from one of our ceramic artists Josefine Gronkrans
The opening night is 14th October, Tuesday at 5:30 pm
Vincents gallery : Willis St Village
5/148 Willis St
Wellington
14th October - 4th November
Pencil the date.
Nau mai haere mai.
Josefine Gronkrans bio
I'm a ceramicists from a rural part of Wellington who take inspiration from the beauty of Creation. I moved to beautiful Aotearoa from Sweden a few years ago, and my journey with ceramics started in 2023 and I've been elbows deep in clay ever since. I use flora found all over the world, and outside my doorsteps, to shape my artwork. My ceramic pieces are all hand made and no piece will be the other alike. I mainly throw a shape on the wheel and then let it tell me what it wants to become.
This exhibition is guided by Ecclesiastes 3:1-11. I think life is beautiful in it's times of joy, but also in the times of struggle, where we can grow and learn.
A Time for Everything
There is a time for everything,
and a season for every activity under the heavens:
a time to be born and a time to die,
a time to plant and a time to uproot,
a time to kill and a time to heal,
a time to tear down and a time to build,
a time to weep and a time to laugh,
a time to mourn and a time to dance,
a time to scatter stones and a time to gather them,
a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing,
a time to search and a time to give up,
a time to keep and a time to throw away,
a time to tear and a time to mend,
a time to be silent and a time to speak,
a time to love and a time to hate,
a time for war and a time for peace.
What do workers gain from their toil? I have seen the burden God has laid on the human race. He has made everything beautiful in its time. He has also set eternity in the human heart; yet no one can fathom what God has done from beginning to end.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Celebrating Mahuru Māori: He wheako reorua o He Tohu and Pipitea walking tour — Mahuru Māori 2025, This Mahuru Māori, join a reorua (bilingual) He Tohu experience and hīkoi around Pipitea to celebrate te reo Māori and the unique hītori (history) of Pipitea. Deepen your understanding about ingoa tūturu (original place names) and the wāhi where He Tohu currently sits.
A reorua | bilingual tour of He Tohu and Pipitea
Join us and embark on a haerenga (journey) together to connect to the ancestors and our shared past. The tour will begin at He Tohu — a permanent exhibition of three iconic constitutional taonga that shape Aotearoa New Zealand.
* 1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
* 1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
* 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
These taonga are significant because they shaped who we are as a nation and will shape what we become in the future.
"Ka mua, ka muri | Walking backwards into the future"
A hīkoi around Pipitea
After the He Tohu tour, join us on a half-hour bilingual hīkoi (walk) around key sites in Pipitea of cultural significance.
There are slight inclines in places, but we will be walking on the pavement for the tour. If the huarere (weather) is looking inclement, please bring warm clothing, a raincoat, or an umbrella. If the weather is too bad, we will postpone the event, so please register so that we can notify you about the cancellation.
Shared kai
During the kaupapa, knowledge, pātai (questions), and reflections will flow between us. At the end we’ll have kai timotimo (snacks). You are welcome to bring snacks to share.
This event is suitable for all ages. Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the tour starts.
Nau mai, haere mai!
Book your spot
Places are limited so email us to book your spot.
Please include your contact details and the number of people in your party.
Email — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz
Celebrate te reo Māori
Reorua (bilingual) speaking kaimahi will host your taenga mai ki te whare, visit. Some will be kaimahi tangata whenua and some will be kaimahi Pākehā, Tauiwi rānei. Like us all, this mahi (work) is for us and our descendants — mō tātou, me ō tātou uri, haere ake nei.
Toi te kupu, toi te mana, toi te reo Māori! | Hold fast to the word, to the mana and to the Māori language!
Image: Kaiārahi leading the hīkoi through Pipitea. Photo by Mark Beatty
label: Community & Culture

description:
DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp 2025, Kia ora DEBRA New Zealand whanau !
Save the dates - DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp, Wellington, Friday 22 - Sunday 24 August 2025.
We are very happy to announce that we are planning a get-together for the NZ EB whanau and a few Aussie families in Wellington in August. We really hope you can join us - it will be wonderful to see you!
This event is a great opportunity to meet other families, connect with old friends and make wonderful new ones, learn from each other and from valuable talks about EB issues, and have time to relax and enjoy a couple of days in Wellington city - the creative capital! We're keen to hear about any particular topics you would like to hear about.
Everyone is welcome including extended family and friends, caregivers, and healthcare professionals.
Dates: Friday 22nd August (check-in from 3pm with informal meet and greet from 5.00pm), to Sunday 24th August (finishing 2pm after a farewell lunch)
Event location: Wellington City, venue to be confirmed
Registration will be launched in early May - please stay tuned for further details!
Your registration fee will cover the conference, meals and children’s activities from Friday evening to Sunday lunch time, but it does not cover accommodation (amount to be confirmed), travel or airport transfers.
DEBRA NZ will provide some limited assistance with accommodation and travel costs if needed, subsiding flights for the person attending with EB.
Please contact debra@debra.org.nz if you would like to apply for this support.
There will be more information soon.
We need an idea of numbers so please get in touch as soon as possible!
Email: debra@debra.org.nz with any questions and let us know if you are interested in attending.
Nga mihi nui,
Anna, Lea and the DEBRA NZ team
debra@debra.org.nz
label: Community & Culture

description: Wellington Jazz Fest: The Seth Boy Trio, Join us at LBQ this Wellington Jazz Festival for an evening with the Seth Boy Trio. Led by Wellington bassist, composer, and bandleader Seth Boy, the trio features Eilish Wilson on alto saxophone and Dillon Butcher on drums. Together, they bring a rich mix of original compositions and fresh interpretations of jazz standards, moving easily between blues, lyrical ballads, and playful bursts of improvisation.
label: Festivals

description:
DRAG BINGO with Homer Neurotic @ Dirty Little Secret, This is not your grandma’s bingo night. Wellington’s resident sad boy and pint-sized powerhouse, Homer Neurotic, is taking over the rooftop at Dirty Little Secret for a night of unhinged chaos, cocktails, and camp realness.
Get ready for an evening dripping in glamour, glitter, and glorious nonsense as you soak up the skyline views from one of the capital’s most iconic rooftop hideaways.
What to expect:
• Free entry, all you need is a table booking and good vibes
• Over $200 worth of prizes, including a $100 bar voucher for the grand winner
• Spot prizes, cheeky antics, and bad decisions encouraged
• Live drag performances that’ll leave you confused, flustered, and deeply entertained
• Dad jokes, dance-offs, and plenty of double entendres
• Drink and kai specials to keep you going
• After the Bingo stick around to boogie down with one of the resident DJ’s, spinning your tracks all night long
Bookings essential:
Tables available from 7.00 pm with balls dropping no later than 7.30. Walk-ins are very limited so grab your spot now:
https://dirtylittlesecret.co.nz/events/drag-bingo/
Safe and inclusive:
Dirty Little Secret is proudly LGBTQIA+ friendly. Our staff and security are trained to make everyone feel welcome and safe. Elevator access is available, but some tables are on raised flooring, so please reach out if you have accessibility needs and we’ll make sure you’re well looked after.
Heads up:
This is an R18 event. Expect colourful language, cheeky antics, and wholesome masculinity served with a side of mischief. Consider yourself warned.
Follow me for more nonsense:
Find me on Instagram at @homerneurotic for a peek behind the scenes and more of the drama, glitter and tears.

description:
Celebrating Mahuru Māori: He wheako reorua o He Tohu and Pipitea walking tour — Mahuru Māori 2025, This Mahuru Māori, join a reorua (bilingual) He Tohu experience and hīkoi around Pipitea to celebrate te reo Māori and the unique hītori (history) of Pipitea. Deepen your understanding about ingoa tūturu (original place names) and the wāhi where He Tohu currently sits.
A reorua | bilingual tour of He Tohu and Pipitea
Join us and embark on a haerenga (journey) together to connect to the ancestors and our shared past. The tour will begin at He Tohu — a permanent exhibition of three iconic constitutional taonga that shape Aotearoa New Zealand.
* 1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
* 1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
* 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
These taonga are significant because they shaped who we are as a nation and will shape what we become in the future.
"Ka mua, ka muri | Walking backwards into the future"
A hīkoi around Pipitea
After the He Tohu tour, join us on a half-hour bilingual hīkoi (walk) around key sites in Pipitea of cultural significance.
There are slight inclines in places, but we will be walking on the pavement for the tour. If the huarere (weather) is looking inclement, please bring warm clothing, a raincoat, or an umbrella. If the weather is too bad, we will postpone the event, so please register so that we can notify you about the cancellation.
Shared kai
During the kaupapa, knowledge, pātai (questions), and reflections will flow between us. At the end we’ll have kai timotimo (snacks). You are welcome to bring snacks to share.
This event is suitable for all ages. Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the tour starts.
Nau mai, haere mai!
Book your spot
Places are limited so email us to book your spot.
Please include your contact details and the number of people in your party.
Email — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz
Celebrate te reo Māori
Reorua (bilingual) speaking kaimahi will host your taenga mai ki te whare, visit. Some will be kaimahi tangata whenua and some will be kaimahi Pākehā, Tauiwi rānei. Like us all, this mahi (work) is for us and our descendants — mō tātou, me ō tātou uri, haere ake nei.
Toi te kupu, toi te mana, toi te reo Māori! | Hold fast to the word, to the mana and to the Māori language!
Image: Kaiārahi leading the hīkoi through Pipitea. Photo by Mark Beatty
label: Community & Culture

description:
DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp 2025, Kia ora DEBRA New Zealand whanau !
Save the dates - DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp, Wellington, Friday 22 - Sunday 24 August 2025.
We are very happy to announce that we are planning a get-together for the NZ EB whanau and a few Aussie families in Wellington in August. We really hope you can join us - it will be wonderful to see you!
This event is a great opportunity to meet other families, connect with old friends and make wonderful new ones, learn from each other and from valuable talks about EB issues, and have time to relax and enjoy a couple of days in Wellington city - the creative capital! We're keen to hear about any particular topics you would like to hear about.
Everyone is welcome including extended family and friends, caregivers, and healthcare professionals.
Dates: Friday 22nd August (check-in from 3pm with informal meet and greet from 5.00pm), to Sunday 24th August (finishing 2pm after a farewell lunch)
Event location: Wellington City, venue to be confirmed
Registration will be launched in early May - please stay tuned for further details!
Your registration fee will cover the conference, meals and children’s activities from Friday evening to Sunday lunch time, but it does not cover accommodation (amount to be confirmed), travel or airport transfers.
DEBRA NZ will provide some limited assistance with accommodation and travel costs if needed, subsiding flights for the person attending with EB.
Please contact debra@debra.org.nz if you would like to apply for this support.
There will be more information soon.
We need an idea of numbers so please get in touch as soon as possible!
Email: debra@debra.org.nz with any questions and let us know if you are interested in attending.
Nga mihi nui,
Anna, Lea and the DEBRA NZ team
debra@debra.org.nz

description:
DRAG BINGO with Selina Simone! @DLS, Darling, This is not your grandma's Bingo! this is DRAG BINGO with local drag artist, ya dad's favorite, sinner & showgirl, SELINA SIMONE!
Brace yourself for an evening dripping with glamour, sparkle, and a whole lot of cheek as you soak in the skyline of Wellington's most unique rooftop hideaway
DIRTY LITTLE SECRET!
Slip into something fabulous, grab your favorite drink, and get ready for an extravagant night of DRAG BINGO! We've got cocktails that'll make you blush, and more laughs than you can shake a feather boa at!
Expect live drag performances to make your heart race, dad jokes that'll have you in stitches, and beats from our fabulous local DJs that'll keep you moving all night long! Book your table for 7.00pm, balls dropping 7.30 at the latest!
Event Highlights:
Hold onto your wigs, honey, because it's FREE to enter! And we have well over $200 worth of PRIZES to be won! including our grand prize... $100.00 BAR VOUCHER! odds not in your favour? we have SPOT PRIZES up for grabs, so sexy naughty and fun I'm not allowed to mention them on this media platform!
Oh, and speaking of keeping things alive, why not order a bit of me with the "Selina Simone" cocktail? Curious about how I taste? One sip, and you'll be hooked! Check out our epic kai offers as well!
Get your gang together, you've got to book a table to secure your spot! let's turn this night into a campy, sexy extravaganza!
Reserve your table for 7:00 pm, bookings are hot, so snatch yours now through the link below (or the ticket link on this page) https://dirtylittlesecret.co.nz/events/drag-bingo/ Limited Walk-In's on the night
xx
Immerse yourself in enchanting breathtaking views that will elevate your experience. From the glittering city lights to the stars above, DIRTY LITTLE SECRET is Wellington's most unique rooftop bar, offering a setting as sensational as the entertainment!
But wait, the fun doesn't stop there! Our sensational DJ will be spinning tunes from around 9/9:30 pm 'til late. Let's keep the dance floor sizzling and the party vibes alive!
For our guests with specific accessibility needs, we have elevator access to ensure everyone can join in on the fun. However, as some tables are on raised bits of flooring, we encourage those with accessibility requirements to reach out to us directly. Your comfort is our priority, and we're here to make sure your night is as fabulous as can be!
LGBTQIA+ Friendly: Our staff and security at Dirty Little Secret are not just friendly; they're fabulous! Trained to meet the needs of all our diverse patrons, ensuring a safe, and welcoming space for everyone xx
TRIGGER WARNINGS: This is an R18 event! Expect strong language, good vibes, and thotty danger and legs so smooth they'll sweep you off your feet!—100% guaranteed! xx

description:
Drag Quiz with Selina Simone, DRAG QUEEN HOSTED QUIZ NIGHT @Ivy Bar
Where big brains meet bigger wigs

We’ve turned the fun up to 11 and the decorum down to a cheeky 2.4. Join Sinner & Showgirl Selina Simone for a night of trivia, glamour, and just the right amount of chaos.

The Quiz:
-4 themed rounds (theme revealed on the night)
-Pop culture, general knowledge, picture round, and our infamous music round
-No sports questions – promise!
-Created by our local quiz writer to test your knowledge and tickle your funny bone

When: Friday 19 September
Doors: 7.00pm | Quiz starts: 7.30pm
Where: Ivy Bar, Wellington
Cost: Free entry

Prizes:
-Over $200 worth of prizes
-Mini-games and spot prizes throughout the night
-Grand prize: $100 Bar Voucher + bragging rights for a month

Teams: 4–6 players
Bookings: Email steven@ivybar.co.nz with your team name and number of players, or use the sign-up form via the ticket link

Bonus Fun:
-Selina’s signature drag performances between rounds
-Drink specials all night

Accessibility:
Ivy Bar’s main entrance has stairs, but we can arrange alternate access with notice. Email steven@ivybar.co.nz (Subject: Accessibility for Drag Quiz).

Inclusivity:
LGBTQIA+ friendly – all welcome (yes, even the straight ones).

Content Warning:
R18 – adult themes, strong language, and dangerously smooth legs. Drink responsibly.
label: Community & Culture

description:
ENM/Poly Speed Dating, Are you looking to meet like-minded people who embrace polyamory? Join us for an exciting evening of Poly Speed Dating! This event is for those who practice or are interested in consensual non-monogamy, offering a safe and inclusive environment to connect and potentially spark new friendships/relationships.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

We will have a private function space for this event.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

description:
Fareham Journey Free Cohousing Information & Tour, Fareham Journey is building a sustainable cohousing community in Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston and they are looking for people who share their kaupapa to create this with us. The Fareham property has extensive grounds which includes a historic home, and established organic gardens, an orchard, and fields. It even has an arts community on site.

We run these free cohousing information and tour events on the third Sunday of every month, from noon until 2pm at Fareham, 80 Underhill Road, Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston in the South Wairarapa.

Learn about the Fareham Journey and our vision to create a sustainable and supportive community and how you can get involved. We invite you to bring a plate of vegetarian food to join us for a shared meal in the historic homestead, Fareham House, followed by the tour.

Ensure you RSVP to attend at https://farehamjourney.nz/rsvp/

description:
Community Halloween at the Fire Station 🎃, Community Halloween at the Fire Station 🎃
Community Halloween Event 🎃 at the Fire Station 25th October 2025.

With the long weekend coming and near Halloween, the station will open up for the kids (and kids at heart) for an afternoon Halloween treat.

Saturday 25th October 2025
1pm til 4pm

Where:
Waitārere Fire Station Forest Road

Free 👀 yep that's right free

Thanks to our event sponsors!!!

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Gallows Tour, Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.
While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Bed By 10 Is Coming To Wellington!, Bed By 10 Is Coming To Wellington!
🚨 NEW DATE ADDED DUE TO DEMAND 🚨

🎉 Bed By 10: The Ultimate 30+ Clubbing Experience! 🎉

Fancy going out for a dance but not keen on sacrificing the next day? We've got you covered!

Bed By 10 is a chance for ravers over 30 to relive the peak of the 80s, 90s & early 2000s clubbing scene! Expect crazy visuals, confetti showers, Co2 cannons and more as our resident DJ spins all the club classics 🚀

Good vibes only! Our event is designed for those who love to dance, socialize, and enjoy great music—all while being home and in bed by 10 PM ✨

Tickets Here 👉 https://likeit-loveit.com/pages/wellington-new-zealand
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Father's Day Quiz, Put your general knowledge to the test while supporting a great cause at the Father's Day Quiz!
Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. Your generous donations are greatly appreciated and make a significant difference. Once Cooper is fully trained, he will be placed with a visually impaired person for the rest of his working life. We believe that as the Scots Community bands together, your support can change a life.
To learn more or to make a donation, visit our Givealittle page.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Week: Tragedies Tour, Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.

description:
From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday, From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday
Marking 250 years since Austen’s birth this romp through her irreverent Juvenilia is spliced with deliciously pompous gems from Aotearoa’s earliest newspapers.

From the drawing rooms of Georgian England to the dusty streets of Victorian Wellington – the pretensions of polite society never change.

To mark 250 years since the birth of Jane Austen, her wildly funny Juvenilia is brought to life, including The Beautifull Cassandra, The History of England, Love and Friendship – and more.

Between Austen’s sharpest barbs you’ll hear genuine gems from New Zealand’s early newspapers, courtesy of Papers Past: gossip, pomposity, early etiquette advice, and scandalous society mishaps.

The result? A sparkling, one hour romp proving that the absurdities of status, marriage and manners travel across oceans, continents and centuries.

Performed as a series of readings with lightning character swaps, sly narration, and just a hint of scandal, this is Austen as you’ve never heard her: young, bold, and perfectly at home in 19th century Wellington!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $25
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/from-pemberley-to-pipitea-celebrating-jane-austens-250th-birthday/


Health & Safety
Please contact the event host for health & safety information.
label: Community & Culture

description:
In the Rume with, It's here... Rume's very first large-scale event on Saturday 13th December in Porirua at Pātaka Art + Museum!
In the Rume with is an event designed for gals aged 17-35–a night of wholesomeness, curated spaces, and shared stories. It’s a parallel to our first online series where you'll be able to connect and talanoa in person with some of our featured women (announcing soon). 
Our heart is to build community for women through storytelling and connection. We believe there's room for everyone at the table and know that this will be a special evening where you can come and leave inspired.
You'll be free to enjoy the room at your pace, with immersive activations and surprise treats throughout the night. Of course we'll have yummy kai, snacks and drinks supplied by local sponsors. 
Get your besties together and make a gals night out of it!!! Don’t miss this opportunity to connect with gals in your community, learn from our beautiful features and have some fun before the end of the year. 
Tickets are very limited so get in quick! See you in the Rume 😍
P.S. check out our socials / website for more info!
label: Community & Culture
