description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets
label: Community & Culture

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever, Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 5 OCT

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 5 October 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee
label: Community & Culture

description:
Guided tour of the historic Bolton Street Cemetery - Tiptoe Through the Tombstones, Guided tour of the historic Bolton Street Cemetery - Tiptoe Through the Tombstones
Explore historic Bolton Street Cemetery in central Wellington (just off The Terrace) with experienced guides. Hear entertaining and surprising stories with Tiptoe Through the Tombstones.

Tiptoe Through the Tombstones, starting at the Seddon memorial on Sundays at 2.00pm. A fascinating tour of Wellington's early history. The stories go far beyond well-known names from history, giving glimpses of ordinary people who made their home here.

Seize this opportunity to learn more about NZ’s oldest town cemetery and the lives of some of its many and varied occupants, people who lived in nineteenth-century Wellington. Hear wonderful stories from our colonial past as well as a reminder of the disruption caused by the construction of Wellington's Urban Motorway. Settlers and Māori were buried in this beautiful heritage cemetery, and their headstones can give us intriguing information.

All Sunday tours leave from the Kinross Street entrance to the Cemetery. The tours finish at the little museum in lower Bolton Street, just off the Terrace.

Children 12 & under: free (no ticket required).

Well-behaved dogs on leads welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/guided-tour-of-the-historic-bolton-street-cemetery/


Health & Safety:
Follow the directions of your tour guide, and stay on paths. Old headstones and railings around graves can be unstable.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
Ignite Alumni Pub Quiz, Are you a past consultant with Ignite? Do you want to reconnect with other consultants, test your general knowledge, and be in with a chance to win some cool prizes? Then you are invited to our very first IGNITE ALUMNI EVENT - Pub Quiz Style!
Ignite Consultants Wellington is hosting a Pub Quiz for all consultants past and present. This is your opportunity to catch up with other consultants outside of your projects, meet new people, and show off your quiz skills. Your time as a consultant might have come to an end but you are always part of the Ignite whānau as our Alumni!
The quiz will be held at the Cavern Club on the 7th of October, 2025 kicking off at 7pm. You are welcome to make your own teams, or you can choose to be allocated a team. We will do our best to put you with consultants from the same project as much as possible. If you're a Dunedin alum we would love to have you there as well! Teams are 4-6 people.
Tickets for this event ARE LIMITED- so get in quick! A $5 registration fee will go towards the running of the event and supporting Ignite.
We would really love to see you there our amazing Alumni!

description:
In the Rume with, It's here... Rume's very first large-scale event on Saturday 13th December in Porirua at Pātaka Art + Museum!
In the Rume with is an event designed for gals aged 17-35–a night of wholesomeness, curated spaces, and shared stories. It’s a parallel to our first online series where you'll be able to connect and talanoa in person with some of our featured women (announcing soon). 
Our heart is to build community for women through storytelling and connection. We believe there's room for everyone at the table and know that this will be a special evening where you can come and leave inspired.
You'll be free to enjoy the room at your pace, with immersive activations and surprise treats throughout the night. Of course we'll have yummy kai, snacks and drinks supplied by local sponsors. 
Get your besties together and make a gals night out of it!!! Don’t miss this opportunity to connect with gals in your community, learn from our beautiful features and have some fun before the end of the year. 
Tickets are very limited so get in quick! See you in the Rume 😍
P.S. check out our socials / website for more info!

description:
JKaiWa, Japanese Conversation Evening
(October), こんにちは皆さん！
Come along and flex your Japanese language skills at JKaiWa
JETAA Wellington’s monthly Japanese conversation evening. JKaiWa welcomes language learners and native speakers to come and enjoy casual conversation in Japanese with like-minded people!
This month JKaiWa will be held on Thursday 9th October from 5:30pm - 7:00pm, at the usual place, the Japan Information and Cultural Centre, Level 18, Majestic Centre, 100 Willis Street Wellington CBD.
For health and safety reasons we have been asked to limit the number of attendees to a total of 30 people. We still absolutely encourage anyone interested in attending to sign up, as we often do not reach this 30 people limit, however signing up is now mandatory, so please follow the link below if you wish to attend:
https://forms.gle/fernCvWAwM9hhG3M7
If all 30 places are taken you will receive an email letting you know of your spot on the waiting list. Likewise, if you have signed up and can no longer attend, you can email jkaiwawlg@gmail.com and let us know.
Sign-ups close the morning of the event.
This is a free event open to anyone with Japanese conversational ability from beginner to advanced and native speakers, so feel free to share this event with all your Japanese-speaking friends!
Some packaged snacks may be provided.
We hope to see you there!
よろしくおねがいします!

description:
It’s Vall Walk time again (nearly)!!, It’s Vall Walk time again (nearly)!!
HALLO FOLKS!!

Yep, that's right!! It's Vall Walk Time again (... well, not for a wee while yet ...)

This time I'm giving plenty of notice, because there's a chance my doggy-dad, Jack, might be able to come along (and Aria, and his peoples!) ... I HOPE!!

And because I LIKE it here, AND because it's gonna be a BEEYUTIFUL day (I just KNOW it!!), AND because the Tide is going to be LOW (or so calculates Buddy Dad, so we'll see if THAT turns out to be true), let’s go to the Beach at Queen Elizabeth Park!!

AND let's have a BBQ PICNIC too, cos it's SPRING time, and it's BOUND to be fine and warm!! YUMAY!!

Let's meet in the car park just inside the Mackay Crossing entrance to the Park. We'll head down to the beach from there! Bring your picnic and BBQ thingies too!! Buddy dad will bring our small portable BBQ and will cook things for you too. And don't forget about the small fee I charge to be your Official Taster!! (Snicker!!)

So, we’ll see you there!! WOOHOO!! I can hardly wait!!

And let's aim for a record turn out, because I KNOW there's lots of you Vall's out there, including a few newbies, just hanging out for some F-U-N, and blowing off some winter cob-webs!!

description:
John Campbell’s Destiny Church Investigation: Part 2 Under His Command, John Campbell investigated Destiny Church in a five-part documentary screened in April this year.
Join us to watch Part 2 of John Campbell’s Destiny Church investigation. John Campbell highlights some consistent themes of Brian Tamaki's Destiny Church: far-right prejudices, manifest anger, and hatred.
In Auckland on 21 June, Destiny Church organised a march to take "a bold public stand for Christian values, Kiwi identity and the future of this nation".
On Saturday, 13 September, Brian Tamaki attended the London “Unite the Kingdom” protest organised by far-right political activist Tommy Robinson that claimed to celebrate 'free speech', but also contained chants of hate, racist conspiracy theories, and Christian nationalist slogans. Among disturbing scenes, some people in the crowd ripped up a flag that read 'Secular Humanism'. To them, the very idea that people of all backgrounds and beliefs can live together with equality and respect is something to fear and destroy. For decades, the far right in the USA has painted humanism as a bogeyman, blaming it for liberal values, the rights of women, and the rights of LGBT people. It shows that those who thrive on fear are deliberately targeting the very values that underpin human rights and human dignity. Humanism is not a fringe or ‘woke’ idea. It is about fairness. It is about reason. It is about believing in the good that people are capable of when they are free to live their lives without fear or prejudice. These protests, which Brian Tamaki is supporting, are a show of force from those who wish to undo progress, to divide communities, and to undermine cherished freedoms.
We have a growing concern for secular values in our community. We cannot be silent. It is essential to keep compassion alive in public life and politics. After watching the documentary, we will discuss our concerns and how we might respond.
Time: Oct 6, 2025 06:30 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88183700512...
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Thorburn 1K - Community Weeding Competition, Kia ora e te whanau!
We kick off the community weeding season with a competition: The Thorburn 1k. Evergreen buckthorn - or Rhamnus alaternus - is a big threat to te taiao on Te Raekaihau. It prevents native plants from establishing by forming dense stands of salt and wind tolerant bushes that grow on steep escarpments. Join us to help remove 1000 of these plants across two weeding sessions! A point schedule helps you to get motivated and compete for the highly coveted Thorburn 1k medal.
Please meet at the intersection of Te Ranga-a-Hiwi and Ruru tracks. We will provide tools and gloves but please bring your own if you have some. We will finish at the Alice Krebs lodge for hot drinks and kai and there will be time for community consultation.
In the event of bad weather forecast, the day will be moved forward to Saturday.
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour, Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour
Part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025

"How hard is it to escape from places. However carefully one goes they hold you – you leave little bits of yourself fluttering on the fences – like rags and shreds of your very life.” Katherine Mansfield in a letter to Ida Baker, 1922

Explore the Thorndon that Katherine Mansfield knew and the traces of her legacy that remain in the landscape today. Beginning with an introductory talk, a viewing of the exhibition 75 Tinakori Road: “This marvel had come to the lane” and a hot drink at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, the guided walking tour will finish at the National Library of New Zealand.

Please note: This is a guided walking tour which will involve approx. 30 minutes of walking on flat ground with frequents stops. Participants are encouraged to wear comfortable shoes and bring appropriate protection from sun and rain. The tour will begin upstairs at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, if you have accessibility requirements, please see the accessibility information on our website or contact us to discuss.

Bad weather postponement dates: The tour will go ahead if there is light rain, so please bring a raincoat. If there is heavy rain and/or strong winds the Saturday 18 October tour will be postponed to Saturday 25 October; the Thursday 23 October tour will be postponed to Thursday 30 October. Participants will be notified by email and text message (if a mobile number is provided when booking) by 9am on the day of the tour if there is a postponement.

(Image: The Katherine Mansfield Memorial photographed by Charles P S Boyer, c1930s. Wellington City Council Archives, 00157-99)
label: Community & Culture

description:
Labour Day 2025 Open Day, FOR IMMEDIATE USE – OCTOBER 2025.
LABOUR DAY – OPEN DAY- Monday 27th October, 10AM- 4PM
Wellington’s historic Wrights Hill Fortress in Karori will be opened for public inspection again on LABOUR DAY, Monday 27th October, one of the official functions of Wellington Heritage Festival. The World War Two coastal battery will be accessible between 10am and 4pm.
On LABOUR Day people are invited to self-guide themselves through the tunnels and gun emplacements. The walk usually takes about one hour. Bring a torch with you for some fun!
Visitors will be able to explore the 620 metres of underground tunnels with a free map and history pamphlet. They will see the engine room, shell stores, plotting rooms and the huge gun pit where Gun Number 1 used to stand, as well as a replica of the 10-metre-long gun barrel.
On show will be historic photos, and some military memorabilia. A DVD of how a 9.2-inch gun operates will be showing as well.
Wrights Hill Fortress was built from 1942 to protect Wellington from Japanese bombardment. In the early 1960’s, the guns were cut up for scrap and sold, ironically, to the Japanese.
Admission is CASH ONLY- $20 for a family of two adults and three children under 15, or $10 per adult and $5 per child. (Sorry no EFTPOS). Access is via Karori Road, Campbell Street, and Wrights Hill Road. All proceeds go to the continuing restoration of the Fortress.
There is limited car parking at the summit of the Hill. Try walking from the base of the hill. Please wear strong footwear.
A BBQ sausage sizzle and soft drinks will be on sale. Make it a fun day for the family.
label: Community & Culture

description:
LONG LUNCH in the Waitarere Beach Forest, HELLO BEACH LOVERS
The Waitārere Forest Long Lunch
- Sunday 18 January 2026
- book your tickets online
Get ready for one of the highlights of our Waitārere summer calendar - the Waitārere Forest Long Lunch is returning on Sunday, 18 January 2026, and it’s looking to be our biggest and best yet!
 Held beneath the towering pines of the Waitārere Forest, this annual event is all about community,   connection, and celebration. The Long Lunch has become a much-loved tradition for residents and visitors alike - a day to relax, share good food, and enjoy the easy-going Waitārere lifestyle that makes our beach so special.
We’re proud to announce that "Gareth Heard and the team from Unique Realty" are now our major sponsors for Long Lunch. Their generous support is helping us make this year’s event extra special, including an exciting $500 cash giveaway to one lucky ticket holder! You must be present on the day to claim the prize, so make sure you don’t miss out on what promises to be an unforgettable afternoon.
Early Bird Tickets: $15* per person (01 Dec - 11 Jan)
Standard Tickets: $20* per person (12 Jan - 17 Jan)
Gate Sales Tickets: $25* per person (18 Jan)
*Fee (per Ticket/Order) 3% + 30c
All tables and chairs are provided - bring your own plates, cutlery, glasses, drinks, and a plate of food to share. From homemade favourites to gourmet treats, the shared tables are always overflowing with creativity, flavour, and generosity.
And don’t forget - the Long Lunch is also a major fundraiser for our community. There will be raffles, auctions, and prizes throughout the day, so bring plenty of cash and help us raise funds for local projects that make Waitārere Beach an even better place to live.
This year’s fundraising focus:
The Upgrade of the Community House Preschoolers' playground on Rua Ave.
It’s more than just a meal - it’s a celebration of our people and our place. Whether you’re a full-time local or here on holiday, you’ll be part of something special: great food, great company, and great memories under the forest canopy.
So gather your friends, pack your picnic gear, and join us for the Waitārere Forest Long Lunch. Let’s make this a summer to remember - full of laughter, flavour, and community spirit.
See you under the pines
on Sunday, 18 January 2026!
label: Community & Culture

description:
It's in the Ballot - CDC – Carterton District Mayoral Debate -In-studio, Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025
label: Government & Politics

description:
Letters Out Loud 2025, An evening of historical texts brought to life by famous voices. Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.  
Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, Jennifer Ward-Lealand,
This will be an evening of poignancy, laughter, and connection with Aotearoa New Zealand's past. 
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.  More information about these grants can be found here: Research Grant (turnbullfriends.org.nz)
Catering from 5.00, readings begin at 6.00, event concludes approx 7.15

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.
label: Community & Culture

description:
NZIFF: Twinless, A grieving brother finds an unlikely connection at a support group for siblings who have lost a twin, but his burgeoning bromance threatens to turn into something darker in this uncomfortably sharp-witted comedy.

When his brother is suddenly killed in a car accident, estranged sibling Roman (Dylan O’Brien) suffers the unique pain of being permanently severed from his twin. Inseparable in childhood, the brothers drifted apart as adults, brother Rocky (also O’Brien) living out and proud in Portland while Roman lived a (decidedly hetero) tradie life in hometown Idaho. It seems he’ll never have the chance to work through his complicated feelings towards his twin until stumbling upon a bereavement group for just such a purpose.

There he meets Dennis (James Sweeney). Neurotic, sarcastic, gay, he’s the opposite that attracts as the pair bond over trauma and a deep need for attachment. They quickly become each other’s emotional support twin-surrogate, on call for late night grocery trips, afterwork bitch sessions, and road trip singalongs. But odd couple bliss can’t last, as Dennis has more than friendship in mind, Roman grapples with explosive anger issues, and dark secrets inevitably come to light.

Sweeny’s sophomore effort as writer, director, and co-star walks an entertaining balance between discomfort and hilarity. With finely calibrated performances from both leads, Twinless is witty, warped, and surprisingly warm hearted. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

description:
Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour, Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour
The Makara Churches St Matthias and St Patricks date back to the 1800's. Monk Cottage built in 1867 is used as a local musuem for the area.

The churches and cottage will be open over one weekend from 10am till 3pm for people to visit. They are all within walking distance of each other.

Local people will be on site to talk to visitors. The cottage has information about early settlement of the area. St Patricks church has beautiful stained glass windows dedicated to early settlers. St Matthias has a graveyard where the early settlers are buried.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/makara-churches-and-historic-cottage-tour/


Health & Safety:
No particular health and safety issues apart from possibly someone tripping on an entry step. None of the buildings have difficult entryways, only 2 or 3 steps to get inside.

The road outside is quite busy at weekends so care must be taken getting in and out of cars if parked outside the grounds. There is plenty of parking inside the venue area off the road.

Marlborough Sports Awards 2025, Marlborough Sports Awards 2025
Join us for Marlborough's premier sports awards function. The 2025 live awards dinner, recognising all our nominees and winners.

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
Saturday Laughs with Ben Hurley and Josh Thomson, Saturday Laughs with Ben Hurley and Josh Thomson
Saturday Laughs returns to the Upper Hutt Cossie Club, with another great line up of top Kiwi comedy

With MC Ben Hurley
As seen on The Project, Seven Sharp, and more
With a massive but hugely likeable stage presence, Hurley can win over even the toughest room. A sharp improvisational mind and well honed original material make Hurley a popular act with audiences and critics alike.

And headline act Josh Thomson
Josh is a household name and a legend on the New Zealand comedy scene. He has been a mainstay on local comedy shows like 7Days, Have You Been Paying Attention, was the regular comedian on The Project and was the champion of Season 3 of TaskMaster NZ – which he now directs. He also directed and starred in a web series about his own father Subject:Dad.

As an actor he’s appeared internationally in Prime’s The Office Australia, Netflix’s The New Legends Of Monkey, NBC’s Young Rock and local hits Good Grief, Creamerie, Wellington Paranormal, Educators, Time Bandits and the Emmy winning INSiDE. His feature film work includes the How to Please a Woman (Australia), Don’t Make Me Go (US), and local favourites Gary of the Pacific, Pork Pie, & Guns Akimbo.

Josh continues to work as a live performer, whether gigging on tour with 7DaysLive, appearing on the Comedy Gala, hosting the Great Comedy Debate or as an MC for corporate events. He’s hosted the NZ Film Awards, the 48Hour Film awards, various Vodafone events and several spots for the NZ Music awards.

Support from
Li'i Alaimoana
Sera Devcich
Katy Borrows

Book early and often!

This event made possible with support from the Upper Hutt Creative Communities scheme, and Aotearoa Gaming Trust

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.
label: Community & Culture

description:
National Library 60th Birthday Open Home, Here’s to 60 years! Your National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa is turning 60 and we’re opening our doors in Wellington to invite you, your whānau and communities to celebrate with us.
Come along to view our collections up close, take part in activities and join guided tours of the He Tohu exhibition and our collection stores.
Our curators, librarians, archivists and conservators will share some of their favourite collection items and take visitors behind the scenes of the Library. There will be tours of He Tohu, a chance to help build a replica waka and a kids’ corner to keep the whānau entertained. At 2pm, we’ll be celebrating with cake.
Our friends at City Gallery Wellington will be open from 1pm to 4pm.
Experience your taonga
View a display of our collections from the National Library and the Alexander Turnbull Library, featuring taonga from books, comics, manuscripts, photos and more.
Learn about what we collect, how we collect and how you can make the Library your whare through making the most of our services and connecting with our collections. Drop in to chat with Library staff, learn more about our work and get up close with the collections.
Build a waka with friends
Help build the replica voyaging waka Whakaura and learn how Māori and Pacific peoples used their knowledge and navigational expertise to sail their amazing waka across one-third of the earth’s surface.
***Join a guided tour***
Explore our back of house — Take a special guided tour of our collection repositories and learn more about how we preserve the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand. Don’t miss out on this very rare opportunity to take a peek behind the scenes and see some exciting taonga in our collection stores.
Tours are 45 minutes and booking is essential as spaces are limited. Please email us to reserve your place — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz.
***Take a tour of He Tohu***
No booking required. Join our friendly kaiārahi for a guided tour of our exhibition He Tohu and view the three iconic constitutional documents that are shaping Aotearoa New Zealand:
*1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
*1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
*1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
History of the National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa: The National Library was formed in 1965 when the General Assembly Library, the Alexander Turnbull Library and the National Library Service (comprising the Country Library Service and the School Library Service) were brought together by the National Library Act 1965. For the past 60 years, we’ve continued to grow and evolve our collections and services.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Neurodivergent Speed Dating 20-35, 35-50, Neurodivergent Speed Dating 20-35, 35-50
Looking to meet new friends to hang out with, or maybe find love in a comfortable, respectful environment? Join us for a speed dating event designed specifically for autistic adults in Wellington!

This inclusive and sensory-considerate evening is all about meaningful conversations and low-pressure socializing. Whether you’re looking for friendship, romance, or just a fun evening out, this is your chance to connect in a space designed with your needs in mind.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

Accessibility and Comfort:
We’re committed to making this event as accessible and welcoming as possible. Sensory-friendly spaces, quiet zones, and fidget-friendly items will be available. There will also be conversation prompts on the table. Let us know any additional accommodations you may need when registering.

Who Can Attend:
All genders and sexualities are welcome to come and mingle and meet others for friendship but the speed dating part of this evening works best for heterosexual people.

We are volunteer run organisations but as with everything these days, the costs to continue are rising.
You can register a team of 6 people for $100, or register individually if you don't have a team for $20 and we will put you into a team on arrival.
Please arrive by 6:30pm to get your tables, drinks and food, to be ready for a 7pm quiz start.

description:
Experience Rapid Learning Cycles - Wellington, Rapid Learning Cycles (RLC) is a new project management approach for innovation that is a synthesis of ideas and methods from Agile and Lean Product Development. An increasing number of companies around the world are turning to RLC to get their ideas to market faster and regain their confidence to innovate.
Jason Low from Solid Consulting is a Certified® Rapid Learning Cycles Senior Consultant and has used RLC for nearly 10 years. When Jason was the Head of Design & Innovation at Trimax Mowing Systems, he saw first-hand of his 4 years there how RLC sped up R&D and drove better, more informed decision-making capabilities, and reduced the risk of project loop-backs.

This interactive session has been designed specifically to introduce the concept and value that Rapid Learning Cycles will bring to your business. Attendees will leave with actionable tools - like defining a "Core Hypothesis", "Key Decisions" and how to identify what project management framework to use for certain projects. These are all valuable skills to learn for any business, and you will be able to start applying these concepts in your workplace.
Using Rapid Learning Cycles will:
• Speed up your R&D program
• Give you a clearly defined project plan that is easy for everyone to understand - even for the most “blue sky” projects
• Get better engagement across the business
• Achieve better learning outcomes
• Build an extensible knowledge library
There are limited numbers for this event, so please register if you are interested.
Refreshments will be provided with a chance to network with all attendees after the event.
Here are a few of the internationally known innovative businesses that are public about their use of Rapid Learning Cycles: Breville, Phillips, Zespri, Gallagher, Trimax, Trimble, Navico, Kimberly-Clark, Whirlpool, Steelcase, Keurig Dr Pepper, Sonion, Medtronic, Sunpower, Constellium, Hyster-Yale, Novo Nordisk, Novozymes.
This event is proudly brought to you in partnership with:
Solid Consulting
Creative HQ
PDMA-NZ
The Rapid Learning Cycles Institute

description:
November Full Moon Drumming (10th year anniversary), Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
This upcoming gathering marks our 10th year anniversary. Over 10 years many people from all walks of life have joined and participated, adding to the collective co-creation. Each and every one has made this gathering what it is! We'd like to thank you all and to extend an invitation for a potluck-style birthday celebration from 5pm on Wednesday 5th of November, with Bday cake and lighting the fire at around 7pm. Come along, everyone is welcome!
If this is your first time, make sure to read the full event description bellow:
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising
label: Community & Culture

description:
Open Mic Night at Eva, Eva Pub's Open Mic Night: A Celebration of Wellington's Finest Musicians!

Join us every Thursday night at Eva Pub for an unforgettable celebration of Wellington's vibrant music scene!
With an electrifying array of local talent and plenty of opportunities for you to shine, there's no better place to experience the magic of live music than your favorite local hangout.
When: Every Thursday
Time: 8:00 PM Onwards with DJ set from DKav after the open mic
Where: Eva Pub, 35 Dixon Street, 6011
What to Expect:
Local Talent Showcase: Our stage is open for musicians of all genres, offering a platform for both seasoned performers and emerging artists.
Supportive Atmosphere: Hosted every week, our Open Mic Night is more than just an event; it's a community. Our friendly host will help you settle in, assist with setup, and organize the sets to ensure a seamless and enjoyable experience.
Community of Creatives: Experience the warmth of a community that appreciates and supports local and new performances. Whether you're a regular or a first-timer, our stage welcomes you with open arms.
Why You Should Be Here:
Discover Hidden Gems: Uncover the hidden musical gems that Wellington has to offer. Our Open Mic Night is a melting pot of diverse talents waiting to be discovered.
Join In or Enjoy as a Spectator: Whether you're a performer or a music enthusiast, our Open Mic Night is the perfect place to share your talent or simply enjoy a night of entertaintment.
Secure Your Spot:
Don't miss out! Reserve your spot now for Eva Pub's Open Mic Night
Let's make Thursday nights at Eva Pub the highlight of your week as we come together to celebrate the incredible music that our city has to offer. See you there!

Time: 8:00 PM Onwards with DJ set from DKav after the open mic
Where: Eva Pub, 35 Dixon Street, 6011
What to Expect:
Local Talent Showcase: Our stage is open for musicians of all genres, offering a platform for both seasoned performers and emerging artists.
Supportive Atmosphere: Hosted every week, our Open Mic Night is more than just an event; it's a community. Our friendly host will help you settle in, assist with setup, and organize the sets to ensure a seamless and enjoyable experience.
Community of Creatives: Experience the warmth of a community that appreciates and supports local and new performances. Whether you're a regular or a first-timer, our stage welcomes you with open arms.
Why You Should Be Here:
Discover Hidden Gems: Uncover the hidden musical gems that Wellington has to offer. Our Open Mic Night is a melting pot of diverse talents waiting to be discovered.
Join In or Enjoy as a Spectator: Whether you're a performer or a music enthusiast, our Open Mic Night is the perfect place to share your talent or simply enjoy a night of entertaintment.
Secure Your Spot:
Don't miss out! Reserve your spot now for Eva Pub's Open Mic Night
Let's make Thursday nights at Eva Pub the highlight of your week as we come together to celebrate the incredible music that our city has to offer. See you there!

description:
Our Lady's Home of Compassion, Our Lady's Home of Compassion
Join us for a tour of the newly listed Category 1 Historic Place, The Chapel of Our Lady of Compassion and Resting Place of Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert.

Three thirty minute tours will be offered over the course of each morning. Each tour will include information about the history of the building, the meanings behind the stained glass windows, and the significance of the site as an ongoing place of worship for the wider Compassion community.

Participants will have the opportunity to visit the final Resting Place of Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert who founded the Sisters of Compassion, the only religious order born in Aotearoa New Zealand. Come and experience the rich history and spirituality that are embedded in these sacred places.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/our-ladys-home-of-compassion/


Health & Safety:
If arriving by foot, we encourage guests to stay within the painted white lines and to avoid walking through the carpark. In case of a fire or earthquake, emergency evacuation procedures and meeting points will be clearly communicated.

Staff will ensure interior tour areas are clear of hazards that may cause harm or tripping. Our gardens and pathways are clearly marked. In the case of injury, staff have valid First Aid certification.

description:
Out in the Pool 🌈, Out in the Pool 🌈
Our Out in the Pool sessions are regular monthly sessions for all queer, transgender, gender diverse and non-binary folks 🌈

We invite the LGBTQI+ community and allies to dive in and swim in a safe and welcoming environment at Keith Spry Pool. These sessions are held on the first Sunday of every month and run 6pm-8pm.

Out in the Pool evenings at Keith Spry have:
🥽 Gender neutral changing rooms and bathrooms, as well as our Men's and Women's changing facilities.
🦄 Recreation lanes with inflatables, as well as the Dive board open (as staffing allows).

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.

description:
FULLY BOOKED - Family Shiny - Akatarawa Forest, Registrations open NOW
What to expect
This is a “Family Shiny” trip into the Akatarawa Forest.
Non members are welcome to join us but must register to obtain details of start time and location.
Vehicles must have a low ratio gearbox and must not be a 4wd car, station wagon or van, and if a soft top must have a roll cage.
Visitor Registration- $20.00 per driver
There is no trip fee for this trip however non-members pay a “Day Membership Fee” of $20. This is payable in Cash to the Trip Leader on the day.
The trip should be relatively easy as it needs to cater for people just starting out and all types of 4wd vehicles – but a good way to see if you want to get into 4wding and a chance to meet some of our club members (if you are unsure if your vehicle is suitable just ask).
No Dogs Allowed sorry
Once you have completed 3 Family Shinys you can join the club but can only participate in Family Shiny or Touring Class trips. Once you have also done a Training Day and had your vehicle inspected by one of our approved inspectors you can come along on our other more adventurous trips. To find out more on how to join our club go to https://ccvcwellington.wildapricot.org/page-1725861.
Like our Facebook page to find out about more trips and club nights.

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

description:
Plimmerton Rotary Garden Tour 2025, Join us for a Springtime treat- a tour of ten gardens around the Pauatahanui Harbour.

The gardens are varied, from bijou suburban hideaways to a lifestyle block, and from an 1860s cottage garden to a modern design gem. They are testaments to the care and creativity of their owners.

Included is the iconic Heritage Rose Garden beside St Alban’s church in Pauatahanui, which features legacy and modern rose varieties around the burial ground.

Gardeners will be inspired by the experience - it will be an unforgettable day out.

Times - Gardens are open from 9.30 am to 4.30 pm on both days, except for the Pauatahanui Rose Garden/Burial Ground, which will be closed on Sunday morning until 1 pm.

Garden competition – A prize voted for by entrants for the “Best Garden” for Consultancy Services has been offered by Distinctive Home and Landscapes Limited to the value of $600. Other spot prizes will be drawn at the end of each day for entrants.

Ticket holders:


Note that when ticketing, select the Zone to start at: Camborne, Paremata/Aotea, Whitby, or Pauatahanui.

Preplan your garden tour from the map provided when tickets are issued, and have the plan available on the day.

Note that every effort is made to ensure gardens are as safe as practicable. All gardens are entered at visitors’ risk.

must obtain the garden owner's consent if you wish to take cuttings.

Note that the event will occur wet or fine, pets are not allowed, and no ticket refunds will be available.


This is a Plimmerton Rotary fundraiser for community benefit, and net proceeds will be shared by:


Gillies McIndoe Foundation, founded by Dr Swee Tan, benefits research work in developing accessible life-changing treatment options for brain cancer, vascular birthmarks and keloid scars through the use of affordable repurposed medications. https://www.gmri.org.nz/

“HAROLD” - North Wellington Life Education Trust - visits primary schools with an intriguing mobile classroom, furthering the Education of unique Life Skills for primary school children in the Porirua Johnsonville regions. northwellington@lifeed.org.nz


A special thanks to Titahi Bay Horticultural Society for their early support.

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
label: Community & Culture

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Pure NZ Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Pedals To Powder (28 mins) Nick Kowalski, NZ. Two women cycle to every ski field in Aotearoa
in one wild season, braving storms and exhaustion—uncovering a hidden world of independent
ski culture along the way.
All in or Nothing (24 mins) Gordon Duff, NZ. Up against 120 riders with full support crews, a
young athlete only has himself to rely on. Follow his gruelling six days as he attempts to win the
overall title at the NZ MTB Rally. BEST DOCUMENTARY
Riverbound - The Storybook Has Just Begun (13 mins) Dylan Gerschwitz & Deane Parker,
NZ, World Premiere. Yak, a former pro kayaker now paraplegic, takes on Class 3 rapids in the
Upper Buller Gorge. Can packrafting restore his freedom—and redefine who gets to run wild
rivers? FESTIVAL SPIRIT AWARD
As One - The MHS Adventure Racing Team (15 mins) Louie Burger, NZ, World Premiere.
This uplifting documentary follows nine Motueka High students on a wild, 40-hour adventure
racing from the West Coast home—raising funds for World Vision with grit, laughs, and heart.
Spirit of the West (12 mins) Pedro Pimentel, NZ, World Premiere. Set against New Zealand’s
wild West Coast, this film captures the spirit of the Old Ghost Ultra—where community, resilience,
and grit collide in a transformative celebration of people and place. COMMUNITY SPIRIT
AWARD
Rakiura Solo (13 mins) Michael Beckmann, NZ. A tough solo hike around the 130km North West
Circuit on Stewart Island/Rakiura. Beyond the challenge, what makes this island truly special is
its rich wildlife. An ambient film without dialogue.
Waiatoto (20 mins) Josh Morgan & Jasper Gibson, NZ. This film tells the story of a traverse
across the Southern Alps through packraft, skis and tramping. Starting at the Matukituki, the route
went via Tititea, the Volta Glacier, and the Waiatoto, to the Tasman Sea. BEST NZ MADE FILM


Total running time: 125 minutes + 15 minute intermission.
label: Film & Media

description:
Karori Friendship Club, Looking for community, connection, and a good cuppa?

Come and join us at the Karori Friendship Club — a friendly weekly gathering where you can:
- Meet new people
- Share stories over morning tea
- Try your hand at a puzzle or join a chat group
- Simply enjoy time together in a relaxed space

Where: St Ninian’s Church, 208 Karori Road, Karori
When: Every Tuesday, 10am–12pm
Koha for morning tea

Although many who come are seniors, the club is open to anyone — whether you’re new to the area, a recent migrant, or just looking to make some new friends. People join us from all over Wellington, not just Karori!

Why not come along this Tuesday and see for yourself? You might leave with new friends, a full heart, and maybe even a completed puzzle.

REVELRY - Celebrate Footnote at 40, REVELRY - Celebrate Footnote at 40
Footnote New Zealand Dance are celebrating 40 years of daring, world-class, trailblazing contemporary dance.

40 years of connecting communities, pushing the boundaries, and uplifting Aotearoa’s artists. In 40 years, Footnote New Zealand Dance has created 100 works, and employed 100 company dancers. That’s a lot to celebrate, and we want to celebrate it with you.

Come join us for a night of boisterous festivity and unrestrained merrymaking.

What’s an arts event without a bit of fundraising? Curated just for Revellers, our Silent Auction is packed full of goodies. Bidding is open soon, and will close at the end of the night.

Entertainment for the evening provided by the fabulous Chocolate Box (Vanessa Stacey & Lisa Tomlin)

Bubbles and canapés on arrival. Cash bar serving tipples and treats all evening.

Early Bird tickets available till 14th August!

Rural Vs Urban, Rural vs Urban Cabaret Night Fundraiser
A wild night of laughs, rivalry, and good-hearted chaos — all for a great cause!

Hosted by:
The Golden Shears in partnership with the Masterton Lions Club

Date: Thursday, 20 November 2025
Time: Happy Hour kicks off at 6:00 PM — Show starts shortly after and wraps up around 9:30 PM, followed by prize-giving
Venue: Copthorne Solway Park, Masterton

A hilarious “Rural vs Urban” showdown featuring:
• Quick-fire challenges
• Kiwi trivia

description:
Paint and Wine Night in Waikanae Beach - Beneath the Blue, The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Waikanae Beach! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: First drink is included in the ticket price.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

description:
James Marsh Memorial, James Marsh Memorial
Join us for the annual James Marsh Memorial Game, a Kāpiti Coast Softball Club tradition.

This special event honours the memory of James Marsh, who was a cherished member of our softball family, alongside his family and father Tom.

The day is more than a game, it's a time to come together, celebrate James’s life, and remind ourselves of the strength and unity in our community. It also highlights the importance of looking out for one another and supporting mental health awareness.

Game plan:
11.00: U17 invitational game
1.00: Game, open to all skill levels—come play or cheer from the sidelines. We will put you in teams on the day.
1.00-2.00: Shared Kai, bring a plate if you can.

Let’s honor James’s legacy and continue the conversation about mental health, ensuring that no one feels alone.

This event is for everyone—friends, family, and community members. Whether you’re part of the softball world or simply want to show support, we’d love to see you there.

For more information, please contact us at
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
Site Visit - Wellington Airport Fire Station, Join us for an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at the new Wellington Airport Fire Station, currently under construction by Naylor Love. This purpose-built facility is designed to support future air travel and will enhance the airport’s emergency response capabilities, replacing the existing station on the eastern side of the runway.
📍 Location: Wellington Airport Fire Station, Coutts Street, Rongotai
📅 Date: Friday, 5 September 2025
⏰ Time: 3:30 PM – 4:30 PM (arrive at 3.15pm)
🎟️ Tickets: FREE – but limited to 20 NAWIC members only
🛠️ What You’ll See and Hear About:
Importance Level 4 Building
Challenges of designing and building in an airport environment
Sustainable features of the build
Landscape improvements and viewing areas
💬 Why You Should Come
👷‍♀️ Learn from an active, high-profile infrastructure project
🧯 Gain insights into the unique requirements of an airport fire station build
🤝 Network with fellow NAWIC members and industry professionals
🛠️ See how construction is adapting to new aviation technologies
🦺 PPE requirements (hard hats, hi-vis, glasses, steel-capped boots). We have spare hi-vis, hard-hats and safety glasses available – please advise us in your RSVP if you require any help with this.
This is a NAWIC members-only event with limited capacity — please book your space consciously! 
🙏 A special thank you to Wellington Airport and Naylor Love for generously hosting this site visit and supporting women in construction.
We look forward to seeing you there! 🚒
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

🦺 PPE requirements (hard hats, hi-vis, glasses, steel-capped boots). We have spare hi-vis, hard-hats and safety glasses available – please advise us in your RSVP if you require any help with this.
This is a NAWIC members-only event with limited capacity — please book your space consciously! 
🙏 A special thank you to Wellington Airport and Naylor Love for generously hosting this site visit and supporting women in construction.
We look forward to seeing you there! 🚒
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Site Visit - Holcim Readymix Wellington, Ever wondered how concrete is made?
Join us on Thursday 4th September, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of the Holcim Readymix NZ plant. Grab a behind the scenes look at:
 🏗️ The Process: How raw materials like cement, aggregates & water are mixed to create concrete
⚙️ Batching & Mixing: How mix designs are selected and adjusted
📏 Quality: Quality controls & production oversight, including testing & slumping
🚚 Dispatch:  Loading, scheduling & delivery coordination
🌱 Sustainability: Low carbon products and how Holcim is approaching driving a circular economy
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Thursday, 4th September, 1pm
📍 LOCATION: 121 Centennial Highway, Ngauranga Gorge
🚗PARKING: Parking is tricky! Please carpool if possible, limited parking is available at the front of the Holcim offices (2 car parks) and one more at the top car park. Alternatively, bus route #1 stops off at Ngauranga Gorge (Kiwi Point) stop and is a short walk away
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 10 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, glasses (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 ABOUT HOLCIM: Holcim is a global company across Europe, Asia, Pacific, Latin America, Middle East and Africa.  Holcim NZ  is a leading supplier of cement, aggregates and ready-mix concrete in New Zealand dating back to 1888. You may have noticed their big silos on the Centre Port (near the Interislander). Holcim have a network of plants throughout New Zealand, and one of their main missions is around sustainability, where they actively promote low-carbon concrete solutions, including their premium range ECOPact ECOplanet.

Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Speed Dating 30-43, 40-55, Speed Daters will be split into 2 age groups which will run simultaneously. There will be opportunity to mix with the other group during the break. We will have a private area of the venue for this event. Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Speed dating does not have to be stressful or frightening; you will be pleasantly surprised how fun and positive it is.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour
Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
• No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
• Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
• Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
• Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
• Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
• Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
• Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email or call 04 499 1400.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Lunchtime Author Talk with Charles Ferrall, Charles Ferrall will be in-store speaking to his recently released book South by South: New Zealand and the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. He will be in conversation with Michalia Arathimos.
21 October, 12:30–1:15pm
Unity Books Wellington
Free event–all welcome!
South by South brings to light many letters, newspaper articles, and pieces of official correspondence, much of which has not been published before, during the five expeditions of 1901–1916: the Discovery, Nimrod, Terra Nova, Aurora, and Endurance. In particular, Scott’s letters to Kinsey and Shackleton’s to Tripp tell of their hope, despair, exhaustion, and deep gratitude for their friendship.

description:
The Fabulous Carmen Walk Tour: Tea, Toasties and Trade, ** FREE, but please register at https://walktours.nz/book

Entrepreneur, entertainer, madam and mayoral candidate Carmen Rupe was based in Wellington for less than 15-years but has left us a rich legacy of memories and inspiring moments.
Join us on this free 90-minute community walk-tour as we trace Carmen's Wellington years (1967-1980). We'll visit some of the remaining inner-city business locations and imagine some of those that are no longer here: Le Balcon, Carmen's International Coffee Lounge, The Peacock, Cleopatra's Coffee Lounge, Carmen's Bazaar, The Gazebo massage parlour, The Cottage brothel and Carmen's Curio Shop.

Learn about Carmen's landmark 1966 court case, her race to become Mayor of Wellington in the 1970s, and how she supported and offered a safe harbour to Wellington's Takatāpui LGBTI Rainbow communities.

“I would more or less hypnotise all my guests like a black widow spider and trap my clients caught in my web. As people left my coffee lounge at 6am or earlier I would splash them with Carmen’s exotic juice which meant that they would be back another night for more. The scent would guide them to me. Some would hear my voice calling like an eerie whisper from the depths of darkness.” [from Carmen’s autobiography]

Accessibility information: The tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to around 20 walkers.

Starts at the rugby sculpture, Jack Ilott Green, corner of Harris Street & Jervois Quay (just by Civic Square)
Ends: Upper Cuba Street

Cost: FREE
Please register (for walker numbers): https://walktours.nz/book/
DURATION: 90-minutes
label: Community & Culture

description:
Throwing Muses, Throwing Muses - one of the most acclaimed US college bands of the 1990s - will perform two New Zealand shows in December.


The band has announced concerts at San Fran, Wellington on 9 December, and Double Whammy in Auckland on 10 December.
Throwing Muses' Aotearoa tour is part of New Zealand promoter Plus1 Touring's 25th anniversary celebrations.
These are Throwing Muses' first shows in New Zealand since 1994.
Formed by Kristin Hersh with high school friends, the band pioneered a new alternative sound, releasing a string of critically celebrated albums and touring the world.
Throwing Muses - featuring Kristin Hersh, David Narcizo and Bernard Georges - recently released new album ‘Moonlight Concessions’ which has been described by Pitchfork Magazine as: “A stunning return to form”.
‘Moonlight Concessions’ goes back to basics, a return for Throwing Muses to their esoteric off-kilter best courtesy of Kristin’s pin-sharp sketches and their suitably abrasive musical arrangements. The album follows ‘Sun Racket’ from 2020, a heady set filled with tough and tender tales spiked with surreal imagery.
Don't miss Throwing Muses performing their career-spanning concerts in Auckland and Wellington in December.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Tours of New Art Centre at 3-6 Market Lane, We’re excited to announce tours of the new Toi Pōneke Arts Centre whare at 3-6 Market Lane, Wellington. We will be occupying a portion of the building on the corner of Cable Street and Market Lane.
Before our new premises undergo a refit, we invite you to tour the interior of the building and see where the artist studios, arts offices and workshop space will be located.
Tours are available on Tues 2 and Wed 3 Sept at 10am, 11am, 12noon, 1pm, 2pm and 3pm.
The re-imagined Arts Centre Moemoeā (Vision) is:
He kaiwhakatere i te tupu me te whanaketanga o ngā ringatoi o Te Whanganui-a-Tara
A catalyst for the growth and development of Wellington artists
Our new Arts Centre will create a vibrant space that nurtures collaboration, creativity and cultural exchange among artists of all generations using Tuakana-Teina Kaupapa. 
For more information head to the Toi Pōneke Arts Centre website.
