description:
Towards modernism: The Walter Cook collection at Te Papa, Towards modernism: The Walter Cook collection at Te Papa
Curator and author Justine Olsen will explore Te Papa’s Walter C. Cook Collection of Decorative Arts. Walter intended to trace modernism’s roots from the Arts and Crafts Movement to post-war designbut, but how did he achieve this aim?

Join us at the Library or online. Register for a Zoom link:

Modernism through the eyes of a collector
Between 1965 and 1990, collector Walter Cook built up an extensive collection of British and European decorative arts, mostly purchased in Wellington. In 1992 he gifted the collection to Te Papa, significantly adding to the museum’s holdings of international decorative arts.

In the research for her book, Towards Modernism: The Walter Cook Collection at Te Papa, Justine Olsen drew on Turnbull and National Library collections, including the Wises Street Directories and Papers Past, to understand market trends through the flow of design from Europe to the market in New Zealand.

In this talk, Justine will explore the story of the market and changing taste, both at the time of production and half a century later, when these objects were sought after by dealers and collectors.

The Walter C. Cook Collection of Decorative Arts
The collection was built up over a twenty-five-year period by Walter Cook, a discerning and determined collector of modest means. The glass, ceramic, and metal objects — by designers including Susie Cooper, Clarice Cliff, William De Morgan, Christopher Dresser, and Inge-Lise Koefoed — track the evolution of design from the Arts and Crafts movement through to the British and European modernism of the 1970s.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Justine Olsen has been Curator of Decorative Art and Design at Te Papa Tongarewa the Museum of New Zealand, since 2009. Her special interests include late nineteenth and twentieth century design, and contemporary New Zealand craft especially ceramics and jewellery. With history curator Michael Fitzgerald, she developed the exhibition ‘Walter Cook: a collector’s quest’ in 2012.

Image: Justine Olsen, author of The Walter Cook Collection at Te Papa.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Festive Flyer, The Festive Flyer
Join us and celebrate Christmas with a delicious lunch and a day out on the train! Saturday 6th December 2025

Get into the festive spirit with Steam Incorporated—perfect for celebrating with colleagues, friends, and family!

Jump onboard our heritage train departing Wellington Station, and nestle down into your seats for a relaxing journey up the coast behind one of our heritage Da class locomotives.

After arriving at the private entry at Tatum, you'll take a short walk across the car park and follow the music into the Pavilion, where we settle in just in time for lunch!

Immerse yourself in a well-crafted meal, created by the talented chefs there. The menu is set to be a classic kiwi style Christmas buffet feast with all the trimmings!

There will be plenty to keep you entertained such as outdoor games, live music, and 2 dinner sittings, so there is plenty of time to tour Tatum, check out Tatum House, and relax in the gardens on the Tatum House Lawn with a drink. You will be advised of your sitting time prior to arrival.

Departing Tatum, climb on board, head to the Lounge Car, grab a drink from the bar and enjoy the journey home. This unforgettable ride hugs the dramatic coastline along the famed Kapiti escarpment, offering sweeping views of the Tasman Sea and rugged cliffs. It’s a rare chance to relive the golden age of rail in one of New Zealand’s most scenic rail corridors as the sun begins to set.

This excursion will be hauled by our 1955-built diesel electric locomotive, Da 1410, and consist of our steel carriages.

Fares (include your return train travel, meal and entertainment)
Adult 13+ yrs - $229
Child 2-12yrs - $189
Infant 0-2yrs - FREE

Thinking of a larger event, or your corporate Christmas Function?
We're pleased to be able to offer some fantastic packages for large groups, or corporate functions with our friends at Tatum. This all inclusive train ride and Christmas lunch combo is a great way to celebrate 2025 with your team! Please contact us via email or call us on 0800 783 264 for a personalized group package.

Please be at your boarding station minimum 10 minutes prior ready to roll, with your tickets, carriage letter and seating allocations at the ready.

Limited Mobility Disclaimer
Tatum does NOT have a platform. This means you must be able to board and disembark the train from ground level with little to no assistance.

Due to the age, design and nature of our heritage carriages, these are not suitable for passengers with limited mobility. If you have any concerns, please contact us on 0800 783 264 to discuss options with our bookings team!

All tickets and seating allocations are sent via email, within 48 hours prior to the departure of this excursion.

Prior booking is essential, make sure you reserve your spot now to avoid missing out on this experience.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse, Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

Visit Upper Hutt Blockhouse as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.

The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand Wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came.

Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts.

Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out.

Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.

We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10 - $15
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/visit-the-upper-hutt-blockhouse/


Health & Safety:
Please note as an historic building the Upper Hutt Blockhouse is not suitable for those with accessibility needs.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Tram 17 Inauguration (Fathers Day 2025), Join us at the Wellington Tramway Museum as we put our latest restoration project into active service at the museum!
Tram 17 was built in 1904 by the Wellington City Council Tramways as a four wheeled box (Palace) style tram. By 1917 the system had grown and 17 was rebuilt into its current form adding a set of trucks converting the tram to 8 wheels. Tram tram saw regular service until the 1940’s where it was eventually use for peak time travel, before being withdrawn in the late 50’s.
It was then sold, and taken to Bell road in Raumati on the Kapiti coast where it served as a beach hutt until the 80’s where it was donated to the Wellington tramway museum for display and eventual restoration.
2014 a conservation and restoration plan was put together, and the tram was shipped out to the Wheelwright Shop in the Wairarapa for a full body overhaul. It was transported back to the museum in 2017 and put on public display until new trucks (wheelsets) could be manufacturedby A&G price in Thames.
Since 2019 the tram has undergone new wiring, and extensive testing and running in and is now ready to take passengers along our museum.
Tram 17 is a wonderful achievement by all
Those involved, and we cannot wait to welcome you this Father’s Day to enjoy a ride on this heritage tram, saved from the scrap heap, and then saved again from rotting away.
Please note: We intend to run tram 17, however due to the nature and style of the tram, its operation is weather dependent. If we deem that the tram cannot run, we will advise accordingly.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Voice of Aroha Anniversary Gala 2025, ✨ Experience a Night of Celebration and Impact in Wellington! ✨
Join us at the Voice of Aroha Anniversary Gala on Saturday, November 1st, 2025, for an unforgettable evening of reflection, connection, and aroha. 🎉 Immerse yourself in inspiring stories, captivating performances, and the warmth of community — all while making a real difference in the lives of refugee and migrant communities across Aotearoa.
🌟 Voice of Aroha 6th Anniversary Gala 🌟
For six incredible years, Voice of Aroha has amplified untold voices, empowered youth, and brought people together through storytelling, leadership, and celebration.
💡 This year has been filled with achievements and new opportunities for our young people, but it has also been one of the toughest yet, with limited funding. To keep our mahi alive and ensure our youth continue to thrive, we need your support. Will you stand with us?
🗓️ Date: Saturday, November 1, 2025
🕕 Time: 6:00 PM – 9:00 PM
📍 Location: The Hub, Kelburn Campus (Te Herenga Waka – Victoria University of Wellington)
✨ What to Expect:
🌟 Inspiring youth voices
🌟 Beautiful cultural performances
🌟 Dinner with whānau for a great cause
🌟 Raffle tickets + prizes to be won 🎟️
🌟 A night of aroha, unity & impact
💫 Every ticket is a donation. Your generosity directly supports Voice of Aroha’s ongoing mahi — empowering youth, creating inclusive spaces, and ensuring refugee and migrant voices are heard, valued, and celebrated.
🎟️ Get your ticket today and be part of this milestone celebration! Together, we’ll ensure our mission not only continues but grows stronger, making a lasting difference for generations to come.

description:
Walt Quizney @ 1852, Wellington, Hakuna Matata, it means no worries for the rest of your days. And we've got Saturday 20th Sept all figured out for you!
Join us at 7pm for a Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious evening of Quizney themed trivia at 1852 Pub & Kitchen, Wellington!
Sport your best costume, brush up on your movie knowledge (including Pixar) and get ready to put all those years of watching "Quizney" to good use. Oh, did we mention we're having a sing-a-long round where you'll need to remember the lyrics of your favourite song lyrics?
In true Gee Quiz fashion, we'll also have fantastically-fun bonus games including our legendary but stressful Alphabetical round, where your team will negotiate 26 fast-fire questions as the time tick down, plus Last Prince and Princess Standing and The Line Up!
This quiz would not be complete without you, so book tickets today. A team ticket (up to 6 players) is $90).
Booking link: https://www.trybooking.com/nz/YMK
***Minors must be accompanied with parent or legal guardian***

description:
August's Nomadic Speaker: Rachel Young, Rachel Young is a freelance graphic designer, traveller, and occasional van-dweller who’s spent the last few years navigating the messy, beautiful reality of creative nomad life.
For Rachel, being a ‘nomad’ has never been just about travel, but a mindset. Since leaving her home in the UK in 2019, she’s moved across the world, worked remotely from a van, taught graphic design in China, and rebuilt her creative career more than once.
Today, she blends her love of design with a passion for helping other creatives navigate the highs, lows, and mindset shifts of freelance life, while inspiring those around her to pursue their own dreams.
In this Friday's talk, she shares the unfiltered truths of freelancing on the move - from creative burnout to financial uncertainty - along with the mindset tools that can make the journey not just survivable, but meaningful and joyful.

SOLD OUT- Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop, SOLD OUT- Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop
Please join the waitlist for free, and we’ll be in touch if another session is added or if there are any cancellations.

About this Event

Please join the waitlist, and we’ll be in touch if another session is added or if there are any cancellations.
Joining the waitlist is FREE. The $35 shown is the ticket price if more spots become available.
Be sure to check out our other event listings while you’re here too!

SOLD OUT- Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop (1.5 hours)
Step into the enchanted fairy grove for a magical potion-making adventure! Led by a whimsical fairy guide, this hands-on workshop invites young potion crafters (ages 5+) to mix glittery brews, stir up flowery scents, and create their own take-home fairy potions. 🧚‍♀️✨
This 1.5-hour experience is full of sparkly fun, gentle storytelling and a sprinkle of mischief — with fizzy surprises, sweet smells, and lots of giggles.
Includes:

description:
Wellington Speed Dating for ages 26-44 by Cheeky Events Australia, Wellington Speed Dating for ages 26-44 by Cheeky Events Australia
Get ready for a night of fun and connection at Wellington's hottest speed dating event!

About this Event

Let’s ditch the apps together and embrace real connections. Say goodbye to the dating apps and hello to your very own Cheeky Love Story! 💖
🍸 What’s included: Your first drink is on us—let’s toast to great company!
👇How It Works:
Before the event:Make sure to download the Cheeky Events App (free on Google Play & the App Store) to set up your profile and upload a photo.
P.S. Don’t worry—it’s not a dating app! We’ve skipped the chat feature because we’re all about real, in-person connections.
During the event:
Check in to grab your name tag and free drink token. 🍻
Arrive on time to enjoy 15 minutes of casual pre-mingling.
Ladies stay seated while men rotate every 5 minutes—don’t forget to rate your matches in the app! 👍👎
Take a quick 15-minute break before the next round.
After the rotations, feel free to stick around for some extra socializing!
After the event: Stay for extra mingling and check the app for your cheeky matches 12 hours later! 📱💖
For more details, check out our blog: What to expect
Who knows? You might just find your next spark! ✨ Our IRL singles events (single mixers and speed dating events) are happening across Australia, New Zealand, London, and NYC! 🌏

About Cheeky Events
We host fun, inclusive singles events across Australia, New Zealand, London, and NYC! Whether you’re in your 20s, over 40, looking for love, or just looking to meet new people, our events are designed to bring people together. Whether you’re seeking romance, new friendships, or even networking, we’ve got something for everyone!
👉 Follow us on Instagram:@cheekyeventsaustralia @cheekyeventsukandireland @cheekyeventsnewzealand @cheekyeventsukandireland @cheekeventsus
Visit our website: www.cheekyevents.net or download the Cheeky Events app to get started.
We can’t wait to see you at one of our events soon! 🕺💃
#speeddating

description:
2025 Annual South Coast Cleanup, Welcome to the 16th annual South Coast Cleanup, 10:30AM-12:00PM 13th September 2025.
As well as caring for our coasts and oceans, it’s all about community! Join us at any of our cleanup locations for a morning of litter collection and family fun.

WHEN
We kick off at 10:30am on the 13 September. We host clean up sites at 12 locations between Owhiro Bay to Breaker Bay on the Wellington South Coast. All rubbish will be gathered up around 12.15pm and taken to Lyall Bay by the playground to form one huge rubbish mountain that will be collected by the council.

Pitch in for a rubbish pile up at 12:30 at Lyall Bay playground where we will mound up our rubbish and admire our collective efforts! Then we will head to Parrotdog for a drink / kai after!

WHERE
Our fantastic friendly volunteer groups will be scattered along the coastline between Owhiro Bay and Breaker Bay. You can turn up at any of our volunteer sites:

Site 1 - Owhiro Bay hosted by Project Jonah
Site 2 - Dive Wellington hosted by Dive Wellington
Site 3 - Island Bay West hosted by Mountains to Sea and Island Bay Residents Association
Site 4 - Island Bay Snorkel Trail hosted by Friends of Taputeranga
Site 5 - Houghton Bay hosted by Houghton Valley School
Site 6 - Te Raekkaihau Point hosted by Ghost Diving
Site 7 - Lyall Bay West hosted by Underwater Club Wellington
Site 8 - Lyall Bay Central hosted by Lyall Bay Coastal Care
Site 9 - Lyall Bay East hosted by Earth Science NZ (formerly NIWA)
Site 10 - Moa Point hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 11 - Tarakena Bay hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 12 - Breaker Bay hosted by Breaker Bay Residents Association

description:
[FULLY BOOKED] Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), ** THIS EVENT IS NOW FULLY BOOKED **
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV
In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.
Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.
Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.
Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.
Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.
Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 2 November 2025
Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street
Ends: Vivian Street
Duration: 90 minutes
Cost / Bookings: ** FULLY BOOKED **
Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.
Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee
This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
Artistic Potential: Marine Reserves - A presentation/talk, A presentation and talk facilitated by Katy Cottrell, Matteo Collina and Alice Rogers.
Marine Reserves have obvious benefits to the environment, protecting species and providing underwater appeal to snorkelers and divers but a little realised benefit is what they can offer to artists of all mediums. Join artist Katy Cottrell as she chats with academic researcher Matteo Collina and director of the Victoria University Coastal Ecology Lab – Alice Rogers. Alice and Matteo will talk about their work with marine reserves from a scientific perspective and how this has inspired the artworks by Katy Cottrell and Rick Allender for their exhibition Taputeranga: Above and Below.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
AlterCOP30: Digital Collage, Led by Climate Training Co. and Jean-Philippe, the Digital Collage is a fun 3-hour workshop centred on collaboration and collective intelligence. 
The aim of the workshop is to raise awareness and train participants on the environmental issues of digital technology. The workshop also outlines solutions for a sustainable digital technology, and allows open discussions amongst participants on the important and timely topics.
A true team-building tool, allowing participants to come together and delve into the sustainability of our digital world, and engage with the solutions. 
It is built on the same theory and structure that underpins the Climate Fresk.
Benefits of this workshop for your organisation:
Build a shared understanding of digital sustainability 
Understand the problems and threats 
Find solutions that you can implement 
This workshop is rigorously sourced from data sourced by ADEME, Green IT, EcoInfo CNRS and the Shift Project’s reports and references.
How the workshop operates:
Understanding: in teams of 4 to 8, the participants identify and then draw the links between the cards of the game to build a “Collage” 
Personalisation: they visually express their key messages and link their work to their context: to take ownership of the content and create a team spirit
Debriefing: each group explains their title and decoration, then the facilitator makes a detailed summary of the whole system
Solutions: a solutions based exercise finishes the workshop, which stimulates discussion, reflection, and action around a sustainable digital world
If you're looking to build awareness and explore real solutions around digital sustainability in your organisation, this workshop is a great place to start.
In solidarity with AlterCOP30, this November we’re running a series of climate events across Aotearoa - bringing communities together to learn, connect, and take action for a just and sustainable future.
AlterCOP is a Global Initiative founded by The Matcha Initiative and The Transmutation Principle, locally brought to you by Climate Club, Climate Crew, and Climate Training Co.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Cacao and Soundscape with Kellie and Chelsea, This offering seeks to hold you in a space where you will be wrapped in warmth, and the healing alchemy of sound for two restorative hours. This will be an evening of inward reflection and deep nervous system nourishment, an opportunity to down regulate and tend to your inner world landscape.
The evening will begin with a cacao ritual and gently guided yoga nidra. Then guests will be cocooned in blankets, eye masks & bathed in sound alchemy for 90 uninterrupted minutes.
Chelsea and Kellie weave a story utilising an array of instruments in their collaborative offerings, as well as their love of voice activation and the power of mantra.
Over the course of this event, you will encounter the alchemic sounds of:
Two full sets of crystal singing bowls
The handpan and its earthy, resonant tones
Angelic harp melodies
Shamanic drumming
Soft and gentle wind chimes
Crystal pyramid and alchemy bowl with deep, ancient resonant frequencies
The shruti box and acoustic guitar, coupled with voice activation and sacred mantra
Previous attendees have described Kellie and Chelsea's soundscape journeys as unique, powerful, mesmerising and deeply soothing.

There is something so special about gathering with intention, to allow sound to move through you, to soften you, to bring you back home to yourself. We cannot wait to welcome you into the studio.

With all our love,
Chelsea & Kellie
Xx

description:
Cannons Creek community planting day, Join us and Ngāhere Korowai on Saturday 22 November at Cannons Creek Lake Reserve to plant grasses and trees. This planting is part of a project to restore and enhance the mauri of this important body of water.
This community event is an opportunity to meet and greet other passionate locals while we work towards restoring our streams. It is one of a handful of events focused on caring for Cannons Creek Lake. Come along and be part of the ongoing effort to look after this place!
Please note – there is a concrete path to the planting site, but the planting area may be very muddy and slippery.
When: Saturday 22 November, 9.30am-12pm
Where: Cannons Creek Lake Reserve – enter from the footpath on Warspite Ave and follow the flags
You will need to bring:
• gumboots or sturdy closed-toe shoes that you don’t mind getting muddy
• warm and waterproof clothing
• sun hat and sunscreen
• reusable water bottle
We will provide:
• plants and planting tools
• kai
• First Aid trained staff
• hand sanitiser
• sunscreen
• public toilets can be found in Bedford Court.
Getting there:
There is parking available in Bedford Court. The 220 Bus stops at the entrance on Warspite Ave and the 226 Bus stops on Bedford St which is within walking distance to the planting site.
Make your way towards the flags and gazebos, which will be located at the seats in Cannons Creek Lake Reserve. Friendly helpers in high vis from Porirua City Council and Ngāhere Korowai Collective will be there if you have any questions.
Event sign up/admin will be from 9.15-9.30am with the event running from 9.30am-12pm.
We appreciate you giving up your time to do some great mahi for Papatūānuku. Feel free to spread the word to whānau and friends to join you on the day!
See you there!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Challenges in a Changing World – what kind of future do we want?, Public Talk & Workshop

Humanity is at crossroads
One path into the future leads to increasing social and economic division, environmental destruction, war and planetary peril. The other path leads to increasing social harmony, economic and environmental balance, a golden era of peace.

Throughout history, especially at times of crisis, great spiritual teachers have emerged to show humanity the next step forward.

According to British artist, author and esotericist Benjamin Creme, a group of such spiritual teachers is now living in the modern world ~ Maitreya, the World Teacher and The Masters of Wisdom ~ to help and inspire humanity in its task of global transformation ~ to create a civilisation based on sharing, justice and peace; for humanity to act - to share and save our world.

From ancient times, a body of spiritual teachings known as the Ageless Wisdom has been handed down from generation to generation. A systematic and comprehensive account of the evolution of consciousness in humanity and nature, it describes how the universe came to exist, how it operates, and humanity’s place within it.

As humanity matures, further aspects of this previously hidden knowledge are released in a wider, more open manner. Throughout the last 100 years, the Ageless Wisdom Teachings have been communicated through individuals such as Helena Blavatsky, founder of the Theosophical Society, and later by Alice A. Bailey and Helena Roerich; followed by Benjamin Creme.

Along the lines of these teachings, humanity is once again at a critical point in its further development, now with a growing awareness of the necessity for unity, justice and peace.

According to these teachings, Maitreya – known as the Teacher for this coming Age of Aquarius – will emphasise the utter necessity for peace, and that the complete renunciation of war can only be achieved by trust. Sharing alone, Maitreya will affirm, can engender that trust.


~ followed by short Transmission Meditation session ~

Share International New Zealand. Contact (021) 261 2749
Access - entrance from Raumati Road/ walk - drive past Te Raukura ki Kāpiti / Kāpiti Performing Arts Centre
label: Conservation & Environment

Along the lines of these teachings, humanity is once again at a critical point in its further development, now with a growing awareness of the necessity for unity, justice and peace.

According to these teachings, Maitreya – known as the Teacher for this coming Age of Aquarius – will emphasise the utter necessity for peace, and that the complete renunciation of war can only be achieved by trust. Sharing alone, Maitreya will affirm, can engender that trust.


~ followed by short Transmission Meditation session ~

Share International New Zealand. Contact (021) 261 2749
Access - entrance from Raumati Road/ walk - drive past Te Raukura ki Kāpiti / Kāpiti Performing Arts Centre

description:
Clean Up Week 2025, Clean Up Week 2025
Help with nationwide clean up efforts by joining us at our Harbour Clean Up event on Monday 22 September, 9am-12pm.

We’ll be at the Harbour’s Edge (outside Kai Tahi). Come and burn off some school holiday energy with us!

As well as a chance to pick up litter, there will be:
✅free sausage sizzle
✅planting
✅play items
✅spot prizes.

Remember to bring your gumboots and lots of enthusiasm. Be part of Aotearoa’s largest movement against litter!

Postponement date: Thursday 25 September

description:
Clean and Care: Green Cleaning, Discover a more sustainable way to clean and care for your home!

Join eco-lifestylist Stella Carruthers for this hands-on workshop teaching you how to clean with no chemicals. Become aware of the dangers of greenwashing and how to identify commercial products that are safe for both people and planet.

Learn how to make your own effective cleaning solutions using simple ingredients from your kitchen. Discover that cleaning green not only saves you money, it can also support sustainable action that starts right in your home.

Please bring 2 small bottles and 1 container to take away samples of products. These can be upcycled items such as hummus pottles and small soda bottles for containers.

Spaces are limited, book now to clean green this spring!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Cannons Creek community planting day, Join us and Ngāhere Korowai on Saturday 22 November at Cannons Creek Lake Reserve to plant grasses and trees. This planting is part of a project to restore and enhance the mauri of this important body of water.
This community event is an opportunity to meet and greet other passionate locals while we work towards restoring our streams. It is one of a handful of events focused on caring for Cannons Creek Lake. Come along and be part of the ongoing effort to look after this place!
Please note – there is a concrete path to the planting site, but the planting area may be very muddy and slippery.
When: Saturday 22 November, 9.30am-12pm
Where: Cannons Creek Lake Reserve – enter from the footpath on Warspite Ave and follow the flags
You will need to bring:
• gumboots or sturdy closed-toe shoes that you don’t mind getting muddy
• warm and waterproof clothing
• sun hat and sunscreen
• reusable water bottle
We will provide:
• plants and planting tools
• kai
• First Aid trained staff
• hand sanitiser
• sunscreen
• public toilets can be found in Bedford Court.
Getting there:
There is parking available in Bedford Court. The 220 Bus stops at the entrance on Warspite Ave and the 226 Bus stops on Bedford St which is within walking distance to the planting site.
Make your way towards the flags and gazebos, which will be located at the seats in Cannons Creek Lake Reserve. Friendly helpers in high vis from Porirua City Council and Ngāhere Korowai Collective will be there if you have any questions.
Event sign up/admin will be from 9.15-9.30am with the event running from 9.30am-12pm.
We appreciate you giving up your time to do some great mahi for Papatūānuku. Feel free to spread the word to whānau and friends to join you on the day!
See you there!

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Under The Mistletoe, Join us this December for a kōrero exploring the complex lives of native mistletoes in Aotearoa.

Leading mistletoe expert and hands-on conservation practitioner, Trevor Thompson, will share insights into the ecology of these beautiful yet elusive plants, how he is propagating them, and the challenges they face across our landscapes.

From habitat loss to seed dispersal and browsing impacts, learn what is threatening the survival of these special plants and what’s being done to protect them. Come along to deepen your understanding, ask questions, and discover how we can help ensure these special species remain part of our ngahere for generations to come.

This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6.15pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Caring For Cats Indoors, Join us at Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne for an engaging and balanced kōrero about one of the more challenging conversations in pet ownership today – indoor cats.

Whether you’re the owner of a roaming cat, have a “catio” setup, are thinking about your next feline friend, or are simply wildlife-conscious, this is a chance to hear from veterinarian Brendon Bullen of Kelburn Vets about the facts, the challenges, and the practical options available to current and future cat owners.

We’ll explore how to keep cats happy, healthy, and enriched indoors, while sharing practical tips, surprising cat trivia, and myth-busting insights.

Come along for ideas, open discussion, and a fresh take on feline care and conservation.

This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6.00pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Welly On Wheels - City to Island Bay: Confidence & Skills for Biking, Join Wellington City Council, Pedal Ready, and Switched On Bikes for a guided bike tour along the cycle route from central Wellington to Island Bay. Build your confidence and skills to ride safely and efficiently by paihikara (bike), explore the latest cycleway improvements, and learn practical tips for night-time commuting.

The ride starts and finishes at Switched On Bikes HQ near Waitangi Park, heading to Shorland Park in Island Bay. You are welcome to finish the ride at Shorland Park or ride back to Waitangi Park. Note: the event may be postponed in the case of adverse weather.

Duration: Please allow around 2 hours for the ride.
Arrival: Arrive 30 minutes early if you’re renting a bike.
Preparation: Bring clothing suitable for changing weather conditions.

These rides are ideal for people who:
- Can ride a bike but haven’t yet started biking regularly in the city.
- Already ride in the city but want to gain confidence.
- Want to learn how to use Wellington’s cycleway network safely and efficiently.

Who can join: Open to riders aged 18+, or 13+ if accompanied by an adult. Younger children are welcome on cargo bikes or bike seats provided by participants. If you’d like to borrow a bike seat, please contact Switched On Bikes directly.

Bikes and bookings:
An electric bike is strongly recommended. Thanks to Switched On Bikes and Wellington City Council, you can rent one for only $10 if you don’t have access to your own. Please book your e-bike separately here: https://switchedonbikes.rezdy.com/642002/electric-bike-hire-welly-on-wheels

After the tour, you can either leave your bike with us and catch a bus back to the city or keep riding if you’re feeling energetic! You’re welcome to return the bike before 9am the next day at no extra cost or hold onto it for the following day at a discounted rate of $39.

If you’d like to learn to ride a bike away from traffic, check out the free Pedal Ready courses on their website.

For any pātai (questions) about the tours, please email info@pedalready.org.nz.

Privacy Statement:
Information collected for this ride is used for booking and safety purposes. Your name and emergency contact details will be deleted within 14 days after the tour. Other provided information may be stored anonymously to support project evaluation. Your email address will be kept for up to 4 months so we can share follow-up information about biking in Pōneke and invite you to give feedback about your experience.

You have the right to request access to or correction of your information. To do so, please email tours@wcc.govt.nz.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Musicking Together, Musicking Together is a free community music circle run by Sophie Sabri, registered music therapist in collaboration with different local musicians each month. The event takes place monthly at Evaro. It is open to anyone who has a love for music and no musical experience is required. The venue is wheelchair accessible.

This month we will host registered music therapis Hazel Barrett for a night of music taking us on a water journey.

Musical instruments are provided. Come along to meet new people and play music without pressure. "Musicking Together" is a safe space to create music together, to dance, to sing or simply listen to others. As long as we are in space, we are musicking.

How to find us? Evaro is located in the James Smith building, at the corner between Manners and Cuba Street. Enter the building and pass Rebel Sports to find the stairs. Go up to level 1 and follow the corridor on the left. You'll find Evaro to your left.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Destination Earth, Expect your senses to be stirred in a new art installation. Destination Earth aims to inspire climate action through art. It incorporates satellite data, real-time generative music, and responds to audience movement in real-time. Using video and immersive sound, audiences will be challenged to reconsider the rhythm of living as humans. 
You are invited to dive into the flow of the Southern Ocean and explore the pulse of the Antarctic circumpolar current. Participate by adjusting your walking patterns and breathing to ‘regenerate’ the world around you. Motion sensors will pick up your activity and adjust the environment to suit. At a sensorial level the effects of climate change will come to life. 

Destination Earth is a collaboration between Cellule Studio (UK) and Victoria University of Wellington. The work, by artist Salome Bazin, mixes art, science, and technology. It emphasises the urgent need to slow down human activity.  

A bi-cultural perspective is also central to the experience. Māori symbolic views of the ocean are included, offering a richer narrative of the global climate.
 
Image credit: Cellule Studio, directed by Salomé Bazin.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Dragonflies & Damselflies are Amazing and Important - Forest&bird Talk, Ruary Mackenzie Dodds and his wife Kari de Koenigswarter are rated as Dragonfly Ambassadors by the British Dragonfly Society. Although they have recently been involved in the setting up of a Dragonfly Hotspot at Exbury Gardens in Hampshire, England, their work currently centres on New Zealand where awareness of the significance of dragonflies is possibly behind that of the U.K, which has a growing understanding that dragonflies are a key indicator of the health of waterspaces. In this talk, Ruary takes his listeners back to basics on the amazing life-cycle of these insects. He outlines typical preferred dragonfly habitats, and touches on identification of New Zealand species. In addition to Ruary’s talk, Kari’s larva demonstration table shows actual examples of the larval stages on NZ species.

In their New Zealand work, Ruary and Kari are carrying out survey work on behalf of the Greater Wellington Regional Council, and are preparing a dragonfly education pack for schools. They have also carried out five summer seasons of night-filming an endemic dragonfly species – the Bush Giant – that lives in a burrow! A Radio New Zealand Our Changing World programme has been devoted to their work. (https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/ourchangingworld/546925/dragonflies-masters-of-flight).

Ruary and Kari have been working with dragonflies since 1985. They opened Europe’s first Dragonfly Sanctuary in 1991, and founded the National Dragonfly Biomuseum in Northamptonshire in 1995. They and their team of volunteers continued work with the National Trust at Wicken Fen in Cambridgeshire, and were instrumental in the setting up of the Dragonfly Centre there in 2009. Their adventures were published in Ruary’s memoir, The Dragonfly Diaries (Saraband, 2014). Kari and Ruary have also published a how-to book, Dragonfly-Friendly Gardening (Saraband, 2024). Ruary is a Fellow of the Linnean Society. He has given talks in eight countries. He has appeared on both television and radio, and was awarded BBC Springwatch’s ‘Dragonfly Geek’ award. He has been featured in BBC Wildlife Magazine, The Scottish Field, and in Wildlife Trust and National Trust publications. Kari specializes in the larval stages of odonate life, while – even after over forty years – Ruary’s heart lifts at the sight of a dragonfly in flight, and he loves sharing this enthusiasm with his listeners!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify The Hutt 2025, Electrify The Hutt 2025
Ready to make your home or business more sustainable? Join us at Electrify The Hutt 2025!

Explore the latest in electric vehicles, renewable energy solutions, and smart technologies designed to help you save money, reduce your carbon footprint, and futureproof your energy use. Whether you're interested in solar power, EVs, or energy-efficient products, this expo has something for everyone!

Meet industry experts, discover innovative products, and attend hands-on workshops to learn how you can electrify your life.

📅 October 4th, 2025
📍 Lower Hutt Town Hall
🕗 8 AM to 4 PM

For more details and to register, visit https://electrifythehutt.nz/

description:
Homicidal Pacifist - Dust Off Your Guillotines, Created and performed by Sameena Zehra

This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse!

Three haunted sock puppets leading government. Shit-for-brains liberals peddling ‘both sides’ fucknuggetry as the people march for peace and their governments pour gasoline on fire. And WT actual F is a ‘lesser’ evil? Sameena Zehra is back to explore whether it's time to dust off your guillotines (even for a pacifist, it’s definitely time) with dark comedy and delicious storytelling that will make you gasp and guffaw as you channel your inner homicidal pacifist to pen a culling list of your own.

“As a piece of political theatre, this is one of the more entertaining and potentially moving with a flair for the dramatic... a remarkable raconteur with amazing stories to tell…” - Nicholas Holm, The Post

Audience care and considerations: This show is accessible to blind and low vision audiences without the need for audio description. The venue is fully accessible. Sameena may occasionally raise her voice, but won’t shout. There is some direct audience interaction, but if you avert your gaze or shake your head, you will not be engaged directly. Contains adult themes, political and confrontational material, and coarse language.

General admission - choose your price: $8 - $100
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Electrify the Hutt Expo 2025, The Electrify the Hutt Expo is charging into Lower Hutt with a mission to spark inspiration and supercharge your lifestyle with the power of clean electricity. As energy bills climb and climate concerns grow, this high-energy event will show you how to take control—cut costs, slash emissions, and embrace a smarter, more sustainable way of living.
Discover the incredible potential of generating your own local power through solar panels, micro wind turbines, and more. With dynamic demos, interactive exhibits, and expert talks, you'll learn how easy and empowering it is to electrify your home, reduce your reliance on fossil fuels, and enjoy the long-term benefits of clean energy.
But that’s just the beginning. The expo goes beyond saving money and helping the planet—it’s about building stronger, more resilient communities. By embracing local energy generation, we can protect ourselves from rising energy costs, power outages, and climate extremes. It’s about creating homes and neighbourhoods that are not just efficient, but future-proof.
So whether you're a curious homeowner, a savvy business owner, or just someone who wants to be part of something positive, Electrify the Hutt is your place to plug in. Come connect with experts, explore cutting-edge tech, and join a growing movement to electrify our lives and build a cleaner, brighter Hutt Valley for everyone.
Add the date to your calendar now!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Emma La Rocca - Zero waste swimwear, Emma La Rocca is the founder of Emroce swimwear, the world’s first zero-waste swimwear brand.
Her cutting patterns are designed to fit together perfectly- like a puzzle. This innovative technique fuels creativity, reduces costs, and saves up to a quarter of fabric from ending up in landfill.
Now, Emma is on a mission to help other fashion brands embrace Zero Waste Fashion Design (ZWFD). Through fully funded consulting, she’s breaking down misconceptions and showing how sustainability and style can go hand in hand.
Join Emma as she introduces the world of ZWFD, shares her results, and invites you to try out some simple techniques yourself.
Register for this free event, enjoy a complimentary breakfast from our sponsors, and take part in this inspiring conversation about sustainable fashion.

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .

description:
Draw It Out - Parents of neurodivergent children block course, A unique space to support those who are supporting others.

Theme: For parents of neurodivergent children
Care for yourself so you can care for others, by processing emotions using a gentle powerful tool called Interactive Drawing Therapy.
Parenting can often feel isolating yet many are going through similar journeys. This 4-session block course is a safe space for parents of neurodivergent children to draw out their feelings, draw out their inner guidance, and draw on each other.

Dates
This block course consists of 4 workshops:
6.30pm-8.00pm
Thursday 13 November – Re-finding yourself
Thursday 20 November – Caring for your needs
Thursday 27 November - Self-compassion
Thursday 4 December – Seeing potential

Cost
$184 total ($46 per session)

Included in each session
You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance. No art skills are needed, more simple mark making.
This gentle yet powerful tool uses drawing and writing as a way to access your subconscious and to listen to your heart rather than your head for guidance. A tool often used in therapy, it is made accessible for self-care and community wellness through these workshops.

About Lara Phillips
Lara Phillips is a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy. With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.
“We all have the wisdom within to help ourselves, if given the space.”
For more workshops or to book individual sessions visit www.drawitout.co.nz.

Liability disclaimer
Draw It Out offers creativity for wellbeing. It is not intended as therapy nor does it replace counselling, therapy, or any other medical or clinical professional help. Participants are guided to draw out where they are at, whilst drawing out their own inner resources for support and guidance.
Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Friends AGM with guest speakers, Join the Friends of Wellington Botanic Garden for our Annual General Meeting and a pair of inspiring botanical presentations. You don’t have to be a member to attend — everyone’s invited!
Programme
Each presentation is 30 minutes, with time for questions.
Paul Bell-Butler
Botanist and PhD candidate, Paul is delving into the hidden world of leafy liverworts (family Lophocoleaceae). His research combines modern molecular techniques with traditional botany to reveal how these overlooked plants shape ecosystems and influence seed germination.
Clare Shearman
Plant Collection Team Manager at Wellington Botanic Garden, Clare brings a career spanning historic English estates to iconic New Zealand gardens. Fresh from the prestigious Longwood Gardens Fellows program in the USA, she shares insights into garden design, conservation, and how public gardens nurture wellbeing and connection.
Come along to hear their stories, celebrate our beautiful gardens, and meet fellow plant enthusiasts.
Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
For more info about the Friends: https://friendsofthewellingtonbotanic.wordpress.com/
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa A & P Show, This year will be Wairarapa A&PI s 146th annual show, and the only one of its type remaining in the Wairarapa/Wellington region. It is deeply embedded in the culture and history of the area and is accessible to people of all ages and capabilities.

The A&P show has something for all ages, with a focus on learning and family enjoyment. It provides connectedness between town and country, and the opportunities that the rural sector provides.

There is something for everyone, visitors can enjoy the typical animal classes and competitions including sheep shearing, wool handling, pet lamb and calf judging, and equestrian sports, as well as the beloved Goldpine pet corner where attendees can see farm animals up close.

The woodchopping, fencing and dog trials competitions are always highlights, as are the children’s art, scavenger hunt and lawnmower racing. Tickets are available either through Eventbrite or at the gate on the day.

description:
2025 Big Bash with Orchestra Wellington, 2025 Big Bash with Orchestra Wellington
✨REGISTRATION IS OPEN!✨

Follow this link to register for the 2025 Big Bash:

Complete the registration form and check your E-mail to receive the link to music PDFs.

ABOUT THE BIG BASH

First held in 2020, Orchestra Wellington's Big Bash is an annual mass play-in event which brings together hundreds of instrumentalists from across the Wellington region in a glorious afternoon of music-making.

Conducted by Orchestra Wellington's Music Director Marc Taddei, together we will rehearse then perform a selection of much-loved works. This year's repertoire includes Tchaikovsky's Romeo & Juliet Fantasy Overture and 1812 Overture!

Anyone is welcome to come along and watch both the rehearsal and the performance entirely for FREE. Rehearsal runs from 1-3pm with the concert starting at 3:30pm.

FOR PARTICIPANTS:
There are some important things to note before you arrive for this year's Big Bash:

👉 Location: Lower Hutt Events Centre at 30c Laings Road, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010.

👉 Timings: Please arrive no later than 12:45pm. Rehearsal runs from 1-3pm, then a short break before our free concert for community, family, and friends at 3:30pm.

👉 Bring with you: Your instrument(s), a music stand, a pencil, and any mutes or accessories that may be required (as per your part).

👉 This year's repertoire includes Tchaikovsky's Romeo & Juliet Fantasy Overture and 1812 Overture! Complete the registration form and check your E-mail to receive the link to music PDFs.

description:
Still Not Dead - Rachel McAlpine & The Andrew London Duo, After recovering from a shocking epiphany (OMG I'm getting old!), popular poet Rachel McAlpine started unpicking the mysteries of old age. Results: a best-seller book of poems, How To Be Old. A sell-out play, The Secret Lives of Extremely Old People. A podcast, Learning How To Be Old. And it seems at 85 she's still not done and still not dead. She reads selections.

On the cusp of receiving the mythical Gold Card, satirical songwriter/guitarist Andrew London and partner Kirsten assemble a selection of age-related songs from both original and borrowed repertoires, to compliment Ms McAlpine's meanderings. 'When I'm 64' is almost too obvious to include but...

Could ace harmonica virtuoso Coral Trimmer make a surprise appearance? We think so. You can expect more afternoon events from these people from now on. The bar will be open.

This will be followed by an action-focused discussion led by chef and grower Mara Masarotti on how to connect urban growers with spaces to grow kai at scale.

description:
Launching in-store: Capital Trees by Susette Goldsmith, Join us in celebrating the recent launch of Capital Trees: The Arboreal Legacy of Te Upoko-O-te-Ika the Wellington Region by Susette Goldsmith, author/editor of Tree Sense: Ways of Thinking About Trees.
"The significance and meaning of trees engagingly explored through the way they have shaped our capital.
From the fossil forest of Tītahi Bay and the ageing oak on Plimmer Steps, to the karaka grove on Wellington’s waterfront and a threatened stand of lowland beech in the Hutt Valley, Capital Trees journeys across the region to trace the living legacies of the city’s rich tree heritage and the many people who have shaped, protected and challenged it.
These legacies include arguments around heritage tree listing, the native versus exotics debate, biodiversity, attitudes towards heritage authenticity, trees as monuments and more, explored through facts, anecdotes and field notes.
Illustrated with contemporary photography and specimen illustrations of the species and individual trees covered, this book is a must for all who live in the Wellington region."
All welcome! See you at the signing table.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Korokoro to Percy's track working bee, Korokoro to Percy's track working bee
It's time to show some love to the track that joins the bottom of the Korokoro Hill through to Percy's Reserve. There's some great bush there, but it could do with some extra care.

Everyone's welcome to join us for weeding and litter collection. We'll also clear some space for planting in the new year.

Bring gloves, loppers and pruning saws if you're keen to get serious with blackberry. Or just bring your neighbour or your kids and some enthusiasm if you want something lighter.

We'll finish around 3.30pm with cold drinks & snacks provided.

Thanks to @Hutt City Council for support with rubbish collection, and Greater Wellington Regional Council for support of KEG activities.

3-430pm K-oTik

2nd Stage to be announced soon!
Our friends from Cosa Nostra food truck will be back serving fresh pizzas and also have a range of soft drinks available.
Kids under 16yo are free as well as the mini golf for all attendees!
Please note no alcohol will be allowed, you are however welcome to bring your own food and beverage refreshments, NO glass is allowed please. There will also be multiple water stations free for use.
The #29 Metlink Bus route will be running on the hour with the last bus leaving Happy Valley around 10pm. We will also contact the taxi companies to get them to provision taxis for the event closure.
We will not be offering ticket refunds or swaps for this event, if you can no longer make the event, you can on-sell your own ticket - buyers please be sure about who you are buying from as there are lots of scammers around!
Consent is always required at any event to ensure that everyone is kept safe and boundaries are not crossed. Please ask before any hugging, touching of any sort, taking photos, etc. We operate a zero-tolerance policy to bad behaviour. If you see something that doesn’t seem right, you have a responsibility to do something. And remember, if it’s not an enthusiastic YES then it’s a NO.
Open Air reserve all rights and have a zero-tolerance approach.

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

Matiu-Somes Island Trip, Matiu-Somes Island Trip
Join our club trip across to Matiu-Somes Island. Enjoy a pot luck lunch with time to explore the island before conducting an underwater clean up dive by the wharf (conditions permitting).

After a BBQ dinner it is time for a walk before dessert to observe the Little Blue Penguins returning to their nests at sunset and to hunt for Giant Weta and Tuatara.

Sunday morning is a great time to relax, continue exploring the island before the boats arrive and to conduct a beach clean up before catching a ferry home.

This is a great experience for the whole family.

$100pp + Ferry

Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake – The Legend Returns, We are delighted to share some exciting news – for the very first time in New Zealand, the RNZB Foundation has secured the rights for a special one-off screening of Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake – The Legend Returns, filmed live at London’s Sadler’s Wells Theatre in 2019.
Matthew Bourne’s groundbreaking Swan Lake offers an exciting reimagining of the traditional ballet loved by millions and it has taken the dance world by storm. Even if you have been fortunate enough to see the live stage performance, this screen version brings another dimension to the ballet - quite simply, it’s breathtaking!

description:
October Just Sew, Join us for our Just Sew - October edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book online and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

Bookings are prioritised, but we will do our best to fit in walk-ins if there’s space.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Recycled Rubber Jewellery, Come design and make your own rubber jewellery with Adi, using recycled rubber inner-tube tyres. Participants will walk away with 2-3 items of their own design, perfect for anyone hand-making their holiday gifts this year. We'll supply all of the tools, and your base materials. Feel free to bring some ideas of your own to try out!

Fareham Creative Space is an inclusive art space. You don't need experience in jewellery making to enjoy this class, though it's best suited to adults and older teens.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Hungarian Movie Night in Wellington, Hungarian Movie Night in Wellington
🎬 Film Screening: The Story of My Foolishness (1965, dir. Márton Keleti)
László Mérey and Kati Kabók are a charming acting couple well known in Budapest. On stage, the husband always takes the lead roles and reminds Kati that he is the “smart” and successful one. She stays in the background, playing the silly wife — until a family friend, a writer, helps her step out of this role and show her true strength.
A witty and entertaining comedy about marriage, theatre, and self-discovery starring with Éva Ruttkai and Lajos Básti. Don’t miss it!

🎬 Filmvetítés: Butaságom története (1965, r. Keleti Márton)
Mérey László és Kabók Kati a pesti élet rokonszenves színészházaspárja. A színpadon mindig a férj kapja a főszerepeket, és nem mulasztja el éreztetni, hogy ő az „okos” és sikeres. Kati a háttérben, butácska feleségként húzódik meg – mígnem egy író barát segítségével lehetősége nyílik kitörni ebből a szerepből és megmutatni valódi erejét.
Egy szellemes és szórakoztató vígjáték házasságról, színházról és önmagunk felfedezéséről Ruttkai Éva és Básti Lajos főszereplésével. Kihagyhatatlan!

#HungarianCinema #ClassicFilm #FilmScreening
label: Film & Media

description:
Northern Suburbs Big Spring Clean!, Hurray, it's nearly spring! Whether you're 8 or 80 come along and show your love for our neighbourhood and come along to this year's Community Spring Clean. This year we're going for Saturday 20th September, which also happens to be UN Community Clean Up Day.
Meet at Pukehuia Park at 10.30am to collect protective gear and rubbish bags, and then head out around our neighbourhood to collect what you can. You might like to head to somewhere you know is particularly rubbish-y around our suburb.
Bring your rubbish back to the park for a weigh-in and to be collected by the Council. Then celebrate your hard work and grab a free sausage or two off the BBQ.
Bring your friends and neighbours and join the fun and satisfaction of making our home a nicer place.
Organised by Newlands Anglican and Newlands Baptist Churches. For more info contact office@newlandsanglican.org.nz or get in touch with Rebecca on 021 0869 9235.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Dance Night - OUT HOUSE #1: Benny Salvador / Class War on the Dance Floor / UMU, Get yr dancing shoes on and come on down for the first instalment of OUT HOUSE, Pyramid Club's new, semi-irregular dance night showcasing the work of local creative musicians and producers. Skipping along the intersection of dance music and experimental sounds, Out House aims to get your feet moving, your body shaking and your brain waves oscillating. We are kicking things off with three exciting acts, Benny Salvador, Class war on the Dance Floor and Riki Gooch and Daniel Beban's new duo UMU.
---
One of the most exciting young talents in his home country's revitalised dance music underground, Benny Salvador is a DJ, multi-instrumentalist and producer from Wellington whose music finds common threads between house, techno, electro, disco-funk, dub, boogie and beyond.
---
Class War on the Dance Floor is solo project of Pōneke musician, Marika Pratley. A tapestry of vaporwave, chiptune, ambient, lo-fi, retro synthwave and hip hop. Marika is inspired by artists from Wendy Carlos to Peaches, Eno to Merzbow.
---
UMU is a duo of Riki Gooch and Daniel Beban. Silver Apples meets Kuduro with Riki's deep grooves played on an 80s Roland electronic drum kit which are manipulated and dubbed out by Dan on two Tama Techstar drum synths.
$17.50 presales available via UTR
Special thanks to CNZ for supporting Pyramid Club's programme
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Plant diversity & human impacts on endangered plants - Guided Walk, In this easy 60-minute downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on plant biodiversity and human impacts on endangered species.
Species radiation in the Southern Hemisphere with New Zealand examples - Kōwhai, Hebe (Veronica) and Kauri
Examples of rare and endangered species owing their situations directly to human activities. These plants include -
Shrubby toroaro/mingimingi (Muehlenbeckia astonii),
Three Kings kaikomako (Pennantia baylisiana),
Bartlett's rātā (Metrosideros bartlettii)
Three Kings vine/akapukaea (Tecomanthe speciosa).
Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.
This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

Predator Free Wellington Regional Hui, Predator Free Wellington Regional Hui
Are you a community group looking for new ideas or inspiration? Join us for a Predator Free Wellington Regional Hui. This event connects community groups, supports local strategy, and ties into the vision of a predator free Aotearoa.

At our Friday conference, you will hear from expert speakers including Helen Blackie, James Willcocks, Cam Speedy, Jessi Morgan, Paul Ward and community group leaders.

description:
Resilience and Emissions Reduction Workshop for Not-For-Profits | Blenheim, Ready your not-for-profit for the future
Do you know you need to take action to address climate change but don’t know where to start?
Do you want to strengthen your organisations’ planning and readiness for change?
Do you want practical tools and support to measure, assess, and report on your organisations’ impact?

In partnership with Rātā Foundation, our Earth+ Resilience and Emissions Reduction programme has been designed to flip the script on climate change, centering your organisation as agents of change and kitting you with the tools, support and community to make a difference; and it’s free of charge!
About the programme
With the support of the Terra Nova team and other programme participants, you will be guided to identify how your organisation is uniquely placed to contribute to the resilience and wellbeing of people and planet, and the opportunities and obstacles to creating positive change.
The programme is accessible and suitable for everyone, from those just starting on the journey, to those who have steps in place but are looking to gain access to further resources. This programme is not intended to add extra workload or deliverables for your organisation, it is an offer of support to integrate an Earth+ approach into your BAU; an answer to the question “what can we do about climate change?”
We know that every organisation’s capacity is different, so our support is available for you to utilise it when you need it until the end of 2025. This includes:
Access to a dedicated online community where you can connect with the Terra Nova team, other Rātā grantees and specialised partners. Ask questions, find resources and share your journey.
A toolkit of resources and impact sessions to develop your knowledge and connect you with the expertise and support to build resilience and tackle change in a range of impact areas.
Complementary access to the Cogo carbon emissions measurement tool, providing you the ability to quantify and report on your emissions impact and providing recommended actions for emissions reduction and cost savings, in an easy-to-use format.
It begins with a 1-day interactive workshop to kick things off. By the end of the workshop, you will walk away:
Feeling more empowered about the future, with a deeper understanding of resilience and climate change as it relates to your organisation’s context.
Having explored how you can make change positive and achievable, centered on the needs of your community and team. 
With free access to Cogo carbon manager, an emissions profile, report of your carbon footprint and practical action you can take to reduce your emissions.
Having built a network of support and gained free-to-use practical tools and templates.
Note: we will be running multiple workshops throughout the year; you only need to attend one workshop to join the programme. If you prefer an alternate date, please head to our Humanitix profile to find the corresponding event. 
The programme is fully funded for not-for-profit organisations and registrations are now open for 2025! Register for the programme and secure your spot in a workshop through this Humanatix event, and a member of the Terra Nova team will be in touch to confirm your enrollment. For more information about the programme and workshop, visit the Terra Nova website.
We look forward to welcoming you into our community of changemakers!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
SEED AND SEEDLING SWAP: Join us for the launch of Seeds to Feeds Island Bay!, We're starting a new group dedicated to building a kai secure Island Bay, and we'd love for you to be a part of it!
When: Saturday, 18th October, 10 am - 2 pm
Where: Seed to Sea, 38 The Parade, Island Bay
What to expect:
Seed and Seedling Share: Bring your extra seeds and seedlings to swap, or just come and pick up some new ones - we have plenty!
Learn & Create: Discover how to create new plants from your seeds and make your own seed packets.
Delicious Treats: Enjoy coffee, fresh herbal tea, and tasty treats.
Garden Open Day: Explore the beautiful garden at Seed to Sea and meet the chooks!
Share Your Ideas: We want to hear your thoughts on how we can create a kai secure Island Bay.
Seed and seedling swaps are an awesome opportunity for gardeners of all skill levels to collaborate and share what they might have an abundance of.
It's a great way to save money on buying new seedlings, an opportunity to learn from others, and can lead to new varietals in your māra.
Bring something to share if you can, but if not, come as you are – we'll have plenty for everyone!
label: Conservation & Environment
