description:
Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe, Join us for our Just Sew - November edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book through our website and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

description:
Maracatui, Get ready for a night of pulsating Brazilian rhythms as Maracatui ignites the stage at Rogue and
Vagabond.

Rooted in the rich cultural traditions of northeast Brazil, this vibrant collective of musicians and vocalists honours the powerful percussion and soulful songs created by past generations. Maracatui has evolved over the years, blending traditional sounds with original compositions and modern production techniques to create a sound that's both authentic and new.

Known for their infectious energy, Maracatui's performances are an irresistible invitation for audience participation. Their unique blend of powerful beats and beautiful melodies creates a communal experience that will leave you feeling uplifted.

And to be honest, the beer is also stellar! We love Rogue!

Music from 9:30
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear
Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray
Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators
Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Sustainable Spring - Pizza Box Solar Oven, Sustainable Spring - Pizza Box Solar Oven
The Department of Conservation has launched a nationwide call to...
Always Be Naturing
Encouraging all of us to connect with and give back to nature.
At Ngā Manu, we couldn’t agree more! These school holidays, your whānau can discover how fun and easy it is to Always Be Naturing:

PLAN YOUR ADVENTURE

Plus, throughout the holidays, your whānau can enjoy daily Lil’ Explorer Trail, eel feeding, Native Bird Close Encounters, and the Kiwi Night Encounter - all experiences that bring the concept of “naturing” to life.

MAKE YOUR OWN SOLAR OVEN
Thursday 2nd October (Tickets $5)
Discover the magic of the sun’s energy and build a simple solar cooker to take home—an inspiring blend of science, sustainability, and fun just before Summer!

Note: Ticket prices do not include entry to the reserve but we invite you to enjoy half price entry with every ticket sold.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career, Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career
In this month’s Friends of the Turnbull event, author and lecturer Annabel Cooper will talk about researching New Zealand filmmaker Rudall Hayward, best known for his silent films but also his later feature films ‘Rewi’s Last Stand’ and ‘To Love a Māori’.

Join us at the Library or online. Register if you’d like to join this talk and we'll send you the link to use on the day:

Rediscovering Rudall Hayward
Join us for a fascinating talk by historian and author Annabel Cooper as she delves into the life and legacy of Rudall Hayward — a trailblazer of New Zealand filmmaking.

Although not widely known today, Rudall’s career spanned from the early 1900s to the 1970s. He made four feature-length films during New Zealand’s silent film era, later navigating the financial challenges of accessing new sound equipment to make documentaries, educational films, and two more feature films — Rewi’s Last Stand (1940) and the first New Zealand film to be shot in colour, To Love a Māori (1972).

Drawing on research for her biography of Rudall Hayward and his family, Annabel Cooper will explore his enduring contributions to cinema, his collaborative work with his wives Hilda and Ramai, and the cultural legacy he left behind.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Associate Professor Annabel Cooper taught at the University of Otago for 30 years, and published on a number of New Zealand topics including gender history and film. Her last book, Filming the Colonial Past: The New Zealand Wars on Screen, is the subject of an exhibition, He Riri Awatea: Filming the New Zealand Wars, curated with Ariana Tikao for the New Zealand Portrait Gallery and now showing at Canterbury Museum.
label: Film & Media

description:
Peter Hook and The Light, Bassist Peter Hook has intimate knowledge of the music of bands Joy Division and New Order. He’s one of the founding members of both British new wave bands. In July 2026, he is bringing his band The Light to The Opera House in Wellington. Together they will perform New Order’s album ‘Get Ready’ in full to celebrate its 25th anniversary. To make the concert even better, they will also perform a selection of greatest hits from Joy Division’s and New Order’s back catalogue. Get ready to enjoy songs like Disorder, Shadowplay, Transmission, Love Will Tear Us Apart, Blue Monday, and True Faith. 
The dark and ethereal sound of Joy Division and New Order ushered in the post-punk era and continue to be influential in the rock music scene. Peter Hook and The Light are careful to meticulously recreate their music in a live setting. Audiences are in for a show where treasured songs are played with the passion and energy they deserve.

description:
Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms, Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms
Our native riparian plantings from 2023 have really started to thrive this winter, visible as you drive past the farm, or walking the local farm trail loop.

These native seedlings planted alongside the river, act like living sponges, slowing any farm runoff, filtering nutrients, anchoring soil and shading the water so that beneficial invertebrates & life forms can thrive. Creating cleaner water, richer habitat and less flooding downstream.

Keen to get involved? We have a few tree planting events coming up this season:

🌳 TREE PLANTING DAYS
- Sat 16th Aug 10am - 3pm
- Sat 6th Sep 10am - 3pm with @forestandbirdwellington

EVENT DETAILS
- Meet at 10am, 298 Whitemans Valley Road, Upper Hutt.
- We will walk 5-10mins to our planting site near te Awa o Mangaroa / the Mangaroa river.
- Come for a short time, or a long time, and join us for a kai and refreshments at 2pm after the mahi is complete.

BRING WITH YOU
- A Jacket and warm clothes - be prepared for a range of weather
- Boots or stout shoes
- Gloves - if you have them
- A spade if you have one
- Water bottle

Register at https://store.mangaroa.org/collections/events

#treeplanting #mangaroafarms #riparianplanting #nativetrees #volunteer #alwaysbeplanting

description:
Family Shiny - Akatarawa Forestt, Registrations open NOW
What to expect
This is a “Family Shiny” trip into the Akatarawa Forest.
Non members are welcome to join us but must register to obtain details of start time and location.
Vehicles must have a low ratio gearbox and must not be a 4wd car, station wagon or van, and if a soft top must have a roll cage.
Visitor Registration- $20.00 per driver
There is no trip fee for this trip however non-members pay a “Day Membership Fee” of $20. This is payable in Cash to the Trip Leader on the day.
The trip should be relatively easy as it needs to cater for people just starting out and all types of 4wd vehicles – but a good way to see if you want to get into 4wding and a chance to meet some of our club members (if you are unsure if your vehicle is suitable just ask).
No Dogs Allowed sorry
Once you have completed 3 Family Shinys you can join the club but can only participate in Family Shiny or Touring Class trips. Once you have also done a Training Day and had your vehicle inspected by one of our approved inspectors you can come along on our other more adventurous trips. To find out more on how to join our club go to https://ccvcwellington.wildapricot.org/page-1725861.

description:
WECG ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING 2025, ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
Tena Tatou Katoa, Greetings Everyone
A WARM INVITATION TO ALL TO ATTEND THE 2025 AGM OF THE WAIKANAE ESTUARY CARE GROUP INC
Venue: The Otaihanga Boating Club, Makora Rd,
Otaihanga
Date & time: Wednesday 3rd September at 7pm
Speaker Mike Joy - see Bio below

Mike is a Senior Research Fellow and Lecturer in Environmental Science at the School of Geography, Environment and Earth Sciences, Mike’s research includes ecological modelling, freshwater bioassessment, environmental policy, biophysical limits to growth and the role of energy in society. He is publicly outspoken about the decline in freshwater quality and ecosystems, especially the impact of nutrient pollution from intensive dairying on New Zealand's "100% Pure", clean, green image.
Mike is an outspoken advocate for environmental protection in New Zealand and for this has received several awards including an Ecology in Action award from the NZ Ecological Society, the Charles Fleming Award for environmental achievement in 2013 and in 2023 the Callaghan Medal for science communication from the Royal Society of New Zealand. In 2015 he was awarded the Morgan Foundation inaugural River Voice Award and in 2017 the inaugural NZ Universities Critic and Conscience award. His book 'The Fight for Freshwater' is a memoir that provides a rare first hand look at those whose voices question the health and future of our waterways.
The Meeting will conclude with supper and korero

description:
Reiki & Rest: An Energetic Circle for Emotional Clarity & Inner Peace, Reiki & Rest: An Energetic Circle for Emotional Clarity & Inner Peace
This is for you if you’ve been “holding it together” for everyone and feel like your inner world is overflowing. You’re intuitive but energetically drained, and you’re longing for a safe space to soften, feel, and reset.

Plus, your event ticket includes an amazing plant-based dinner and dessert, offering space to reconnect and integrate your experience.

Signs you might need this session:
– You feel emotionally heavy or energetically scattered
– You’ve lost touch with your intuition or inner calm
– You’re craving deep rest — not just physical, but soul-level
– You often put others first and find it hard to receive support

Workshop Details:
This 60-minute healing circle offers guided meditation, hands-on or distance Reiki, and gentle somatic grounding practices. It’s an invitation to rest deeply, release energetic tension, and reconnect with your inner stillness. Expect to leave feeling lighter, clearer, and more centered.

What to bring or prepare:
– Dress in layers for comfort and warmth
– Bring a blanket, water, and a journal
– Yoga mat provided
– Optional: crystals, an eye pillow, or anything that helps you relax and drop in

This is your time to receive. There’s nothing you need to do — just arrive, breathe, and allow yourself to be held in stillness.

What’s on the menu?!
Szechuan Noodles with Vegan Mynce
Thai salad with Green Apple
Summer Rolls with Sweet Chilli Sauce
Ginger Pudding with Whipped Coconut Cream

About Lynofuro:
Lynofuro creates trauma-informed, energetically safe spaces where sensitive women can finally exhale. Her intuitive fusion of Reiki, somatic presence, and deep listening invites powerful shifts in a soft, grounded way.

What past participants say:
“The reiki circle was so gentle yet deeply releasing. I didn’t know how much I needed this.”
“I felt held, safe, and completely restored.”
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Kiriwhakapapa Loop Track, This guided walk follows the 2km Kiriwhakapapa Loop Track in Tararua Forest Park, about 16km north of Masterton. The track is well-graded with a gentle 50m incline and includes bridges across the Kiriwhakapapa Stream. Walkers will pass through regenerating native forest and a stand of exotic Redwoods.

The walk will take approximately 2 hours and is led by members of the Masterton Tramping Club and Wairarapa Walking Festival Committee, who will also provide information about other tracks in the area.

Walk details:
Meet at 13 Church Street (carpark next to Masterton Police Station) if you’d like to carpool. The track is generally flat, with a 50m incline. Note uneven forest floor and tree roots. No cellphone coverage in the area.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Millennium Native Forest Reserve, Led by volunteers from the Friends of Millennium Native Forest Reserve, this walk offers a fascinating insight into how a once-degraded farmland has been transformed into a thriving native bush and wetland. The Millennium Native Forest Reserve is a community asset established by Masterton South Rotary on land leased from Masterton Trust Lands Trust. It is maintained by a committee called Friends of Millennium Native Forest Reserve. Walk leaders will share the Reserve’s inspiring history — from its beginnings in 1993 as a community-led project to restore local biodiversity, to its official opening in 2000 as part of a nationwide millennium celebration. QR codes placed at key spots offer short films presented by local college students, bringing the Reserve’s stories, conservation work, and unique ecology to life. Along the way, participants will hear how volunteers have reintroduced native plants and nurtured a habitat for native birds, insects, and aquatic life.

As you explore the urban Reserve’s meandering tracks, keep an eye out for tūī and kererū - with a bit of luck, you might also spot a gecko basking in the sun, a darting skink, long and short finned eels in the waterways, koura beneath the shallows, dragonflies, and even wētā tucked away in the undergrowth. You’ll gain an appreciation for the dedication it takes to maintain the Reserve and discover ways to get involved in its ongoing care.

Walk format:
This easy-paced walk is suitable for all fitness levels and ages. The tracks are 2.6km of largely limed winding tracks, with sections of boardwalks. Note: there is no toilet available at this reserve.

We’ll depart from the Hillcrest St Reserve entrance at 2pm. The group will pause at key points to hear stories, scan QR codes, and observe wildlife. Expect 1 - 1.5hr walk.

Photo credits: Friends of Millennium Native Forest Reserve.
This walk is part of the Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Poetry at Dorset Square, The artist collective Tramping Gently Club invites you to welcome undergrowth and fertility at Dorset Square. Join a thought-provoking walk through Dorset Square, part of the Featherston Walkways and Reserves. Along the way, discover a participatory artwork featuring the poetic voices of South Wairarapa youth —where walkers are invited to take part in Poems Against Sustainability.

This unique card-game artwork opens space for sometimes challenging but important conversations about climate change, our relationship to the land, and working with nature. First presented at Featherston Booktown 2022, and later developed during a year-long residency at Turere Lodge in the Remutaka Forest Park, this participatory artwork explores big ideas through creativity and play.

Set within the accessible Dorset Square—the most accessible of four urban bush reserves in Featherston. This walk is an opportunity to connect with a re-emerging under story of kawakawa. Once a paddock used as a training area for the Fire Brigade's competition team, the reserve now offers cool shade in the hot Wairarapa summer and an emerging low flammability undergrowth.

Walk Format:
Walkers can expect a gentle walk - 1hrs in total. Maximum 20 participants. All ages.

Image Credit: The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective

This event was previously advertised to be held at Pigeon Bush - however public access here is now restricted and the walk has been relocated to Dorset Square.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Weeding Bee 18th October, Weeding Bee 18th October
Kia Ora Koutou

Now we have finished planting we are turning our attention to the all important W**d releasing.
This is essential to keeping the seedlings we have planted this winter from being overwhelmed by grass and weeds.
Also mulching to help with moisture retention over those hot summer days (hopefully we get a summer!)
Meeting at the Nursery on Hana Udy street at 9am
Gloves, tools and sunscreen provided along with a morning tea and an update on the Reserve afterward.
Hope to see you there !



Health & Safety Notice: When working in the Reserve, please ensure your clothing and footwear are appropriate for expected weather conditions (cold, wet or hot) and the terrain (such as holes, hidden objects, blackberry, overhead branches). Trip hazards and slippery tracks are a possibility. Stay clear of waterways. Be cautious if you have allergies and carry the necessary medication. Enjoy your time in the Reserve and please avoid blocking pathways used by other users. Report any accidents, injuries or possible hazards to the H&S Coordinator (021 071 536)

description:
Wellington | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!
Why join us? You will:
LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.
Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.

Let's protect our local native wildlife by building pest traps to donate to Predator Free Wellington in support of their mission.
With materials and ready-to-assemble kitsets kindly sponsored by Aoraki Construction, we’ll roll up our sleeves and assemble traps at MenzShed Hataitai - all tools and materials provided. No experience required.

- Lessons based on traditional and modern arts/crafts, developing skills & creativity
- Structured, but in a home-studio setting
- Daily or weekly themes
- A child-friendly, relaxed environment for after-school
- Lots of variety / choice
- Excellent resources

The classes provide an opportunity to play and experiment in a structured but caring, home-studio environment.

Activities are designed and supervised by an experienced primary school teacher and artist.

To meet the needs of active and curious children after school we explore a variety of crafts such as sewing, crochet, pottery, felting, weaving, jewellery and woodwork; and the art forms: painting, drawing, sculpting and printmaking.

The activities utilise a child's growing mathematical skills such as estimating, measuring, scaling up & down, changing 2D to 3D, exploring symmetry, and pattern-making. Natural sciences, such as chemistry, biology, geology and physics are included, as well as history and culture.

See the creativekids artlab website. Phone Helen with any questions.

description:
Bunnings Halloween Family Night, This Halloween, Bunnings is inviting families across New Zealand to enjoy a safe, inclusive and delightfully spooky evening at their local Bunnings. On Thursday 30 October from 5:00pm to 7:00pm, stores nationwide will come alive with free Halloween festivities, including DIY workshops, face-painting and tasty treats.

Kids DIY areas across New Zealand will come alive with decorations from Bunnings’ Halloween range, creating a festive atmosphere for kids and parents to enjoy. Children can dive into Halloween-inspired crafts like making Jack ‘o’ lanterns or decorating masks and keyrings, face-painting and themed games. Bunnings team members will be dressed to impress in playful Halloween costumes, and plenty of food will keep everyone energised throughout the evening.

With the growing popularity of Halloween in Aotearoa, Bunnings is proud to offer a welcoming space for parents and kids to celebrate together.

“Bunnings has always been about community, and our Halloween Family Night is a great way to bring people together in a fun, safe environment,” says Melissa Haines, Bunnings NZ General Manager.

The Halloween Family Night has seen remarkable year-on-year growth, starting with 1,100 attendees across 8 stores in 2023, surpassing over 4,850 attendees across 41 stores in 2024.

This year, with all stores participating, Bunnings is set to make Halloween bigger and better than ever.


Visit Bunnings Halloween Family Night
Time and date: Thursday 30th October 2025 5:00pm-7:00pm

To book your spot at the Bunnings Family Night Halloween Event visit In-Store D.I.Y. Workshops - Bunnings New Zealand

For more information including store transformations, workshops and Halloween merchandise visit Bunnings Halloween
label: Kids & Parents

description:
Artists and their love of plants - Part 1 - Guided Walk, All over the world, and over centuries, artists have painted, wood-blocked and carved trees and other plants, and used them in other art forms. Many of these plants can be found in the Wellington Botanic Gardens. On this gentle 60-minute walk, starting and ending at the Founders’ Entrance in Glenmore Street, we will look at those plants and pictures of the artworks related to them. Artists will include Vincent van Gogh, Hiroshige, and New Zealanders Don Binney and Rei Hamon.

Meet at the Founders’ Entrance, Glenmore Street.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Australia, New Zealand, and a post-American Asia, Foreign and defence policy in Australia and New Zealand needs to grapple with the likelihood that the US won't compete with China for regional leadership. Canberra and Wellington thus need to develop strategies that emphasise self-reliance, yet Australia in particular is pursuing ever-closer integration with the United States.
Sam Roggeveen is Program Director of the Lowy Institute’s International Security Program. He is the author of The Echidna Strategy: Australia’s Search for Power and Peace and Our Very Own Brexit: Australia’s Hollow Politics and Where it Could Lead Us. Before joining the Lowy Institute, Sam was a senior strategic analyst in Australia’s peak intelligence agency, the Office of National Assessments, where his work dealt mainly with North Asian strategic affairs, including nuclear strategy and Asian military forces. Sam also worked on arms control policy in Australia’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and as an analyst in the Defence Intelligence Organisation. Sam writes for newspapers and magazines in Australia and around the world, and is a regular commentator on the Lowy Institute’s international magazine, The Interpreter, of which he was the founding editor from 2007 to 2014. Sam also serves as lead editor at the Lowy Institute, and editor of the Lowy Institute Papers.
All welcome but please register to attend.
label: Government & Politics

description:
"Le Malade Imaginaire" by Les Incompressibles - Wellington, "Le Malade Imaginaire" by Les Incompressibles - Wellington
Les Incompressibles from New Caledonia bring a playful, improvised twist to Molière’s Le Malade Imaginaire this October in New Zealand.

About this Event

🎭The New Caledonian theatre group named Les Incompressibles, will be performing in New Zealand in October with a playful reinterpretation of Molière’s classic Le Malade Imaginaire.
Lucie Dorio and Sam Kagy, two actresses from New Caledonia are performing the timeless comedy with their own vibrant energy, surprises, and a generous dose of improvisation.
Synopsis: Two actresses, running late, arrive to perform Le Malade Imaginaire. In their haste, one of them forgets the costumes and props. Not wanting to cancel the performance, they rise to the challenge of performing without costumes and proper props, using all means at their disposal to make it work.
📅 Saturday, 11th October 2025
🕕 2pm-3.30pm
📍 Alliance Française Wellington | Level 3, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎟️ Free entry
Many thanks to our sponsors and partners for their support: The French Institute, The French Embassy, The Government of New Caledonia, CREIPAC, The French Ministry of Culture, The Federation of French Alliances in New Zealand

description:
Drawing & Painting - Creative Arts Holiday Programme for Tween & Teens, Join us for a fun beginner friendly workshop for keen young artists interested in drawing and painting.

Over two sessions, tutor Jake Fairweather will lead participants through a series of exercises designed help improve your drawing and painting.

Workshop goals include:
- Identify the key aspects of a scene to focus on
- How to hatch in various ways to describe the form and express different feelings
- How to tell a story through composition and colour
- How to push the story even further by modifying the lighting and shadows
- Discover your personal drawing and painting style
- Develop greater proficiency with graphite pencil and acrylic paint

Tuesday and Wednesday, 23 & 24 September, 10 am - 1 pm daily.
Suitable for ages 10 and above.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation, sewing and pottery head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
Love in Scent, Join fragrance aficionado Benny Castles for an immersive journey into the WORLD of love, told through the art of scent. In this exclusive olfactive experience, indulge in small bites and sip on a glass (or three!) of something delightful, setting the perfect mood for exploring the emotional power of fragrance.

Over the course of the evening, you’ll sample up to twelve unique fragrances, each one tied to a captivating love story that inspired its creation. Learn the intimate tales behind these scents and discover how they evoke the passions and emotions that shape our experiences of love. Whether you're a fragrance enthusiast or a newcomer, this sensory journey is sure to arouse your olfactory senses and deepen your appreciation for the art of perfume.

description:
Cooking - Singapore Nyonya Food, Love scrumptious Nyonya or Peranakan food? Combining Chinese, Malay and other influences, come and discover how to make your own Nyonya cuisine. Some communal ingredients supplied, a list of other ingredients will be sent out before the course starts (approx cost $35).

Description
Create some classic mouth-watering and flavourful Nyonya dishes. Come and discover how to blend ingredients with distinct spices and cooking techniques. You can easily replicate these dishes at home.

Some ingredients supplied but a list of additional ingredients needed (approximate cost $35) will be sent out when course numbers are confirmed.

Please bring an apron, dish cloth, sharp knife, tea towels and containers to take food home.

Target audience: Adventurous food lovers!

Note: Nuts and gluten will be used in some recipes - this course is not suitable for vegetarians.

By the end of the course, you’ll have:
- Made a selection of Nyonya dishes to take home.
- Become more familiar with using the various spices.
- Understood more about the Nyonya cooking.
- Become more confident to cook Nyonya food at home.

Note: Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. While we wish to create an inclusive environment for all participants, it is important to note that our courses are unable to accommodate specific food allergies or deviate from the preplanned dishes and menus.

Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Prerequisites
Basic cooking skills required.
1 day

description:
KITA - Love Lives Here **revival + OHIMESAMA BREAKS, KITA 
Bass-heavy psych-pop

- KITA - lands on MOON for the first time in a few years, with live projection from Lucy Mila, and lights from The Doc Cave-Lynch! opening + closing BY OHIMESAMA BREAKS! Punctual departure, don't miss the take-off. A preview of their TWISTED FREQUENCY show.

8pm Doors / Opening by OHIMESAMA BREAKS
8:45pm - KITA -
10:15 Closing by OHIMESAMA BREAKS

Since releasing and touring their LOVE LIVES HERE EP in late 2023, the last two years have seen front-woman Nikita Tu-Bryant shoot and wrap her debut film featuring - KITA -
This summer, they are reviving their LOVE LIVES HERE Tour show with some added spice** in anticipation of their upcoming release of Tu-Bryant’s film.
Inspired by their EP LOVE LIVES HERE, the trilingual art-house film [ LOVE LIVES HERE ] is to be screened in 2026 on the film festival circuit around the globe.

Melding inspirations of folk, soul and psychedelia with the guitar and spirited storytelling of musician-actor Nikita Tu-Bryant (Avatar 2, Far North TV Series); the thick lushness of Moog bass synth and Fender Rhodes from Ed Zuccollo (Zuke); and the filthy drive and barking drums of Rick Cranson (Little Bushman) - KITA - have long-since solidified themselves as a must-see live band with a massive sound.
Over the years, you may have seen - KITA - main-stage with sets at SPLORE and WOMAD to the Wairarapa coasts at Tora Bombora and 121 Festival. Since their inception - KITA - have released 2 EPs and a debut album produced by Grammy-award winning Italian producer Tommaso Colliva (MUSE, RAZORLIGHT).

“ • KITA • are a vision straight from a synth-pop dream…the self-titled album • KITA • is a masterpiece ” - Muzic.net.nz

“To experience a • KITA • gig is to witness a stellar example of 3 strong musical identities ... fusing together to create a synergy and oneness unparalleled on the scene today.”
— Adam Page (WizardTone Studios AUSTRALIA)

The upcoming film is to be translated for a live cinema-stage show in late 2026 featuring live music from • KITA • playing a whole new original soundtrack, alongside a chorus of performers that echo the action and music on screen.

“ • KITA • have firmly established a reputation for their exceptional live performances, and their ability to connect people through music and storytelling.” - Ambient Light

description:
Harmonic Sound Journey at Space with Claudio SOLD OUT!, We invite you to a special evening of Sacred Harmonic Sound with multi-instrumentalist Claudio Escutia. This immersive sound journey offers a deeply restorative experience that invites you to settle into stillness, reconnect with the heart, and explore a sense of inner spaciousness through vibration and tone.
Claudio skilfully layers the sounds of gongs, crystal and Tibetan singing bowls, Native American flutes, and other traditional instruments, enhanced through high-quality audio equipment so the sound can be both heard and felt throughout your body.
Harmonic sound and vibration offer the nervous system a chance to truly rest. In this state of relaxation, the thinking mind softens, and we find connection to citta — the heart-mind. From this place, silence arises naturally through the vehicle of sound.
This experience is open to everyone. No previous yoga or meditation practice is needed.
What to bring:
You are welcome to bring your own yoga mat, though studio mats are also available. We will provide bolsters, blankets, and eye pillows for your comfort.
Booking is essential — spaces are limited and this event often fills quickly.
About Claudio
Claudio is a multi-instrumentalist musician originally from Mexico City and now based in Wellington. Born into a family of musicians, he began playing music at a young age and later studied classical guitar. His journey led him to Montreal, where he explored jazz, world music, and spiritual sound traditions.
Extensive travels in Asia and Europe deepened his connection with Indian music and yogic philosophy. He studied Tibetan singing bowls in Kathmandu and Varanasi, and has since worked with a wide range of instruments including the sitar, esraj, bansuri, harmonium, flutes, gongs, and voice.
Claudio’s work blends technical skill, deep presence, and a profound respect for the healing power of sound.
Learn more or listen to Claudio’s music here:
SoundCloud https://soundcloud.com/claudioescutiasounds
Instagram https://www.instagram.com/claudio_yoga_sound_healing
Facebook
https://www.facebook.com/soundhealingyogamusicclaudio

description:
Intro to 2D Traditional Animation - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, This is a beginners course in 2D animation where tweens & teens will learn the time-honoured principles of hand-drawn animation and how to apply them to your own animation project. You may work on a project incorporating your own ideas, or if you'd rather, an assigned a project from your tutor.

You can use any device, ipad or laptop you already own (except a mobile – it's really not big enough to do good animation on). The school does not provide any digital equipment.

Your tutor, Ross Payne, is a 30 year veteran of traditional 2D animation, and loves to share his knowledge about it for you to love it as much as he does.

In each lesson there will be examples and demonstrations of the animation principles with follow up exercises to put your new skills into practice. You'll work on your project both during class and at home, applying the animation principles to your individualised project.

You can choose to draw your animation on paper then scan/capture into your device, or choose to draw your animation digitally, directly into an animation programme. which ever you choose, instructions in class will be provided to give you the skills needed for this step.

Bring a water bottle and snack for morning tea.

This workshop is for ages 10 and above. Tuesday - Friday, 30 September - 3 October, 10 am - 1 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, pottery and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.
label: Kids & Parents

description: Sweet Sensations, Noble Rot wants to sing the praises of sweet wines and help you to learn that they aren't just one note. They'll showcase a range of wines from around the world that lean towards the sweeter side without leaving a cloying sensation on your palate, enhanced by a specially-curated five-course degustation menu from entree to dessert. If you would like to explore your favourite level of sweetness in wine, this event is for you. The knowledgeable Noble Rot team are here to show you that sweetness is one of wine’s most versatile assets, as well-balanced sweetness in wine can be delicate, elegant and complementary to both sweet and savoury dishes. Discover how some grape varieties are more suited to producing sweeter wines and how their level of sweetness is achieved. If you're into the sweeter things in life, this one is for you.

description:
Meet the Characters from Kiwi's Big Hararei show at Zealandia!, These school holidays, Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne will become the playground of a host of incredible critters from Circa Theatre's current children's show Kiwi's Big Hararei!
Brought to you by award-winning company, Horse With No Name, this free "Meet the Characters" event features an amazing array of manu, including kiwi, tūī, kārearea, and tītīpounamu.
The cast of Kiwi's Big Hararei will wow tamariki with a sneak peek of their show, featuring original waiata by Aotearoa singer-songwriter, Benny Tipene. They will also kōrero about the unique adaptations of these manu and how we can all be kaitiaki of them.
Bring your tamariki along to engage with these colourful creatures, with stunning costume design by GRIDLEY by Victoria. Musical performance, native biodiversity, and interactive theatre combine on the Heritage Lawn for an afternoon of spring fun in the sun! The team of talented children’s entertainers from Horse With No Name is so excited to share a snippet of their show Kiwi's Big Hararei with you.
Kiwi's Big Hararei will be playing at Circa Theatre over the school holidays until 4 October: https://www.circa.co.nz/package/kiwis-big-hararei/

description:
Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe, Join us for our Just Sew - November edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book through our website and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

description:
Paint and Wine Night in Waikanae Beach - Beneath the Blue, The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Waikanae Beach! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: First drink is included in the ticket price.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

Doors open at 5pm
Film starts at 6pm (running time is 2 hours 4 minutes)

Tickets are just $25 waged / $20 unwaged (all tickets include snacks) and proceeds go toward keeping your Timebank in operation.

About the film:
Award-winning writer/director Miki Magasiva (The Panthers, We Are Still Here) makes his feature debut with Tinā (Samoan for "mother"). Samoan music teacher Mareta (Anapela Polataivao) is plunged into grief after losing her daughter in the Christchurch quakes. Mareta takes a relieving role at an elite private school, where she inspires her students to perform at a big choral competition. In the trailer Mareta faces a condescending interview at Saint Francis, and her growing relationship with "spoiled, rich kids" annoys a family member. Tinā was chosen to open the 2024 Hawai’i International Film Festival.

The Guardian says "It’s a big-hearted tear-jerker about the power of art – and it’s already breaking records in its home country, where it’s received the widest-ever release for a local film and become the sixth-highest grossing New Zealand film of all time."

This film is rated M (contains violence, offensive language and suicide references).

description:
North Pole Express Kapiti: 1pm - Saturday, 20 December 2025, North Pole Express Kapiti: 1pm - Saturday, 20 December 2025
Be whisked away on the North Pole Express to meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.

About this Event


Public sales commence 1 September 2025.
Nice List presale: 12pm, 25 June 2025 - 5pm, 1 July 2025. Password required.
No tickets will be held during presale, any remaining tickets will be offered to the public from 12pm on 1 September 2025. To join the 'Nice List' visit the .
If you would like to purchase a private carriage for your group on this service, please email prior to 15 June 2025.



Join The Magical Journey to meet Santa!
Your tickets include:
Entertainers
Carolling
Iced cocoa
Cookies
Souvenir Mug
A special souvenir from Santa
Santa
Extra surprises along the way
Our Candy Class and Claus Class Guests travel in comfort and receive extra treats along the way.


Prepare to be surrounded by the magic and wonder of the Christmas season!
Families will love the magical train ride in one of our specially decorated carriages. You’ll meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.
Set to the sounds of carols passengers are invited to join us to be whisked away on the North Pole Express. Delight in the magic of Christmas as the train departs for a journey to collect Santa who has been magically transported to an undisclosed location along the tracks.
From the distance the North Pole Express arrives then the train Conductors invite you and the other passengers to climb aboard shouting “All aboard!”.


All Aboard
During the first leg of the journey wide-eyed children of all ages are invited to engage with characters who are eager to hear what makes the Christmas season special to them.
You’ll meet the conductor, and join in the fun singing and dancing with your hosts and a few other characters who will appear in your carriage on the journey.
At the 'North Pole' Cocoa Class passengers enjoy their iced chocolate from their souvenir mug, and a delicious cookie served by our North Pole Express hosts. Candy and Claus Class passengers will be served aboard the train on the way to the North Pole.
Along the journey Santa appears in your carriage to present each passenger with their very own Christmas ornament. During the trip, characters in each carriage lead passengers in carolling and entertainment as the train makes its way back home.
Children UNDER 2 years (0-23 months) and travelling on the lap of an Adult are FREE. All Passengers 2 years old and over must hold a purchased ticket.

Please note: Seating in our Candy and Claus Classes is strictly limited. Candy and Claus Class Guests receive some extra surprises and treats along the way.
Seating in all carriages is arranged in a configuration of 4 seats as per normal train travel. NPE always endeavour to ensure those who book more than 4 seats are seated in close proximity to each other to ensure they can enjoy the experience together. Children under the age of 2 and travelling on the lap of an adult travel for free.
Wheelchair access: Due to the age and design of the carriages it is not possible to board whist seated in a wheelchair as the entrance is stairs and the doorways are very narrow. However we will be pleased to convey passengers of limited mobility whenever possible provided they can step onto the train from the platform, climbing a step and move to their reserved seats with the help of an able bodied carer. Our crew would assist guiding the passenger up the step onto the train and arrange for the storage of the wheelchair in the guards van. The wheelchair must be able to be folded up and cannot be used on the train. Please let us know when booking if you need wheelchair assistance.

Photo credit: John Bovis

description:
STEAMS School BLENHEIM Term 4 2025, What is STEAMS?
STEAMS is an integrated learning programme covering Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Maths, and Society. It focuses on real-world skills, critical thinking, collaboration, and creativity through hands-on, project-based learning—not play-based, but purposeful exploration without rigid time constraints.
Students are immersed in engaging, age-appropriate activities that encourage curiosity, innovation, and independent learning.
Key Benefits:
Students in STEAMS learn to:
Think creatively and critically
Collaborate and communicate effectively
Connect ideas across disciplines
Take ownership of their learning
Explore without pressure
Understand real-world applications
When & Where?
Weekly classes during school terms, based on age group and location:
Blenheim-Waterlea Racecourse
Class Times:
Little STEAMerS (Ages 5–6): TUES 11:30am–2:45pm
STEAMS Jr (Ages 7–9): TUES 9:00am–2:45pm
STEAMS Sr (Ages 10–13): THURS 9:00am–2:45pm
Cost
Trial (3 weeks): Pay via Humanitix (non-refundable)
Ongoing: $75/day (incl. GST)
Little STEAMerS: $30/day
Scholarships: 25% off for financial need (not available for Little STEAMerS)
School Absence?
Inform your child’s regular school—they’re attending STEAMS School. Most schools are supportive, and students should be marked as justified.

description:
Octavia - A VATS Production!, COME TO OUR CLOSING NIGHT FOR A DIRECTOR Q&A!

Welcome back to another night of ancient theatre with the one and only Victoria Ancient Theatre Society! VATS is a student-led club at Victoria University of Wellington that puts on an ancient play annually, celebrating the fusion of Classical Studies and Theatre, to learn from, and to experience in full. This years' experience comes in the form of the Roman tragedy Octavia—the only extant Roman play set in the eternal city of Rome.

Often attributed to Seneca, but likely in truth penned by an unknown playwright we know as Pseudo-Seneca under the Flavian dynasty, Octavia is a hard tragedy depicting the divorce and hardships of the titular Octavia—the first wife of Emperor Nero.

Follow our tragic heroine as she bears the weight of her Julio-Claudian family name and all the expectations that are thrust upon her with it. Bear witness the cruelty of Emperor Nero and his crimes driven by an unbridled and unabated passion. Experience the illustriousness of a grand imperial wedding and follow it with the bloodied remains left by the ruthlessness of Roman politics. Shall Octavia survive this brutal game? Come find out, for you are cordially invited...

description:
Andrew Fagan – Passage Of Time Solo Tour, Andrew Fagan - iconic New Zealand solo sailor, songwriter, and frontman of legendary Kiwi band The Mockers - hits the road in November with a 20-date nationwide tour: Passage Of Time – Solo Songs and Stories from a Swirly World.

Running from 5th to 30th November, the tour charts a course from Invercargill in the deep south to Whangārei in the north, offering fans a rare chance to get up close with Fagan’s extraordinary life in music and at sea.

Picking up from his acclaimed 2024 bestselling book Swirly World: Lost at Sea, the Passage Of Time tour dives even deeper into Fagan’s thrilling and unconventional world.

The show is a unique blend of spoken word, storytelling, and intimate live music, as Fagan shares tales from his sailing and music adventures, interwoven with songs spanning his entire career – from band classics to his prolific solo catalogue.

Expect the unexpected!

Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free
These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.
Activities include:
• Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
• Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
• Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
• Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.
Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!
We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!

description:
Science Bites School Holidays Science Workshops, Get hands-on with some tasty, edible science these school holidays! Science Bites is an edible science workshop for tamariki aged 8-12 years old.

Learn about rainbow diffraction chocolate, make your own gummy worms, explore some glow-in-the-dark jelly, and more! All the projects in this workshop are safe to eat, meaning kids can taste their creations as they learn.

Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!

Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.

Tamariki can be dropped-off in the morning and picked-up afterwards; caregivers are not required to stay for the duration of the workshop. Tamariki should bring a packed lunch.

This workshop will involve handling and consuming some known allergens and substances your child may be sensitive to. Please refer to the list on the Space Place website.

Best suited for children aged 8-12. $65 per tamariki - 9am-1pm.

description:
CFs 20th Birthday Celebrations, On the 10th of October 2005 Rafael Ferrer Noel arrived in New Zealand and CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists - was born.
Coincidentally the 10th of October is also Cuban Independence Day (a.k.a. El Dia del Grito de Yara) - on this day in 1868, Carlos Manuel de Céspedes, "Father of the Homeland", gave freedom to his slaves and started the independence war against the Spanish colonial power, which led to the Ten Years' War
So we've got lots to celebrate and commemorate today!
A BIG GRACIAS to our teachers and assistants present and past (Rogelio Enrique Carles-Rosas, Nina Baranenko, Niki Boolieris and Jenny Beech), and all our students, dancers and supporters over the years. Without you we would not exist!

description:
Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers: Speaker Series - November 2025, BioTech N Beers presents the third instalment of its speaker series, and the last BioTech N Beers of the year!  
 Once a quarter we will be running a fireside chat with those that have been there done that, the up and coming and everything in-between.
For our final meeting of the year, we are also working in collaboration with Women in HealthTech.
 Women in HealthTech:
Women in HealthTech is a collaborative group representing the HealthTech sector in New Zealand, providing a foundation of networks and leadership.
We have come together to empower women with a diverse range of thinking at all levels of the HealthTech industry and assist with effecting cultural change. Our steering committee represent companies across New Zealand from early stage start-ups and research medical technology companies, to privately owned New Zealand suppliers and global multinationals.
 Kindly hosted by Creative HQ our speaker will be Ipshita Mandal-Johnson telling us about her journey between building a bio revolution to revolutionising bio.
Generously sponsored by FB Rice, come along for a yarn, some war stories, and drinks and kai.
Check out Ipshita’s bio below and we hope to see you there!
 Ipshita’s Bio:
Ipshita has over 15 years' experience in academia, private and public sectors in bio sciences, technology and financial services.
She had completed a BTech in Biotechnology at the University of Auckland (co-funded by Douglas Pharmaceuticals) and a PhD in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology at the University of Cambridge. She co-founded the Global Biotech Revolution in 2012, led the first GapSummit and growth of GBR activities including events in Singapore and the US till 2017 and is currently still a Steering Committee member. She also worked in a synthetic biology and chemistry biotech Nanna Therapeutics as CBO, which was eventually acquired by Astellas Pharmaceuticals for its rare disease pre-clinical assets. She then worked at McKinsey and Company in the India and US offices primarily in the technology, public sector and pharma practice areas (including as Chief of Staff to a $60Bn merger between Takeda and Shire). She has been an advocate for gender lens impact investing and women’s health through Global Bio Fund (invested in Baymatob in 2022 a med tech in maternal health) and the Xcellerator community.
She has provided advice to a portfolio of innovative and systemic investment projects in NZ through BioPacific Partners, Impact Lab, Malaghan Institute of Medical Research, MBIE funded RNA Development Platform and Advanced Technologies team. She is also passionate about bio systems thinking-philosophy and nature poetry. She has received multiple professional awards including thrice being listed in the UK 50 Movers and Shakers in Bio Business, selected to be a Leader of Tomorrow at the 43rd St Gallen Symposium and twice nominated as a Young Global Leader to the World Economic Forum (2024-25).
 FB Rice:
FB Rice is a leading independent intellectual property firm with a strong focus on biotechnology and the life sciences. With more than 75 years of experience and a dedicated Wellington office, we’re proud to support New Zealand’s growing biotech community through local presence and expertise.
Our Biotechnology Group brings deep scientific and industry knowledge across areas such as gene therapy, diagnostics, biologics, vaccines, and medical technologies. We work closely with clients across academia, research, and industry to protect innovation and support commercial success—offering strategic advice on patentability, prosecution, due diligence, and portfolio management.
As active participants in New Zealand’s innovation ecosystem, we value collaboration and are committed to helping the local biotech sector thrive.
 Creative HQ:
Creative HQ is a global innovation hub, based in New Zealand, that provides programmes for entrepreneurship and public sector innovation. Creative HQ creates change for governments and startups through innovation training, structured acceleration programmes and bespoke support.
Creative HQ, Wellington’s innovation hub, operates throughout New Zealand and internationally across the Asia-Pacific region with significant work experience in the Philippines, Singapore, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Japan, Hong Kong, India and Australia. They look to build confidence, capability and connectedness throughout their ecosystem while looking to inspire and support the growth of individuals and businesses through the use of design thinking methodologies. This enables the delivery of innovative solutions to their customers.
 Event Details:
Date: Thursday, 27 November, 2025
Location: Creative HQ, 7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011
Time: 4:30 pm – 6:30 pm
Cost: Free

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: StoryWalk®, Turn reading into an adventure with your tamariki at this special StoryWalk® in Carrington Park, Carterton. A StoryWalk® transforms a children’s book into an outdoor journey—pages are displayed on stands along the path, and children can walk, run, hop, skip, jump, or be wheeled to each one as you read together. The StoryWalk® Wairarapa project was instigated by and is managed by Wairarapa Library Service.

Guiding this experience is local Speech Language Therapist Polly Newton, who will share simple, practical tips to help strengthen children’s speech, language, and literacy skills through the way you read with them.

The StoryWalk® is located on a flat, sealed path around the park, making it ideal for prams, wheelchairs, and scooters. Meet by the playground and enjoy a relaxed, family-friendly activity designed for children and their caregivers.

This event is part of the Wairarapa Walking Festival and is proudly supported by REAP Wairarapa, Chatterbox Wairarapa, and Speech Teacher. The StoryWalk® Project was created by Anne Ferguson in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library, Montpelier, Vermont, and is a registered service mark owned by the Kellogg-Hubbard Library.

description:
Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate
Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!

Why join us? You will:

LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.

Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.
label: Conservation & Environment

The pieces will be fired once, (bisqued) and can be decorated with paint at home.

Recommended age for children are 6 and up. The booking is for one child and one adult and an additional child can be added for only $29.

Session Details:
When: Tuesdays (Yes, even in the school holidays!)
Time: 5:30-8:00pm
Cost: $10 per family (immediate, not extended)
Who: children/young adults with special needs and their parents, guardians, family members, carers, siblings.
On Tuesday's we also host a Brick Therapy session with Dan from Brick Engaged and there is an additional activity fee of $5 per child to participate in that activity.
If you are looking to have a birthday celebration at one of these sessions please txt Paul on 0272787087, or message us in advance. We would also encourage you to make use of a party room to host additional guests (an extra charge would apply to guests)
Come along in any dynamic that suits the family, to these relaxed and open sessions for families and kids living with special needs of all kinds.
Although we cannot cater to everyone's needs, we will do our best to support families to overcome obstacles to attend the sensory sessions.
Please speak with trustees regarding concerns.
(I.D or needs verification may be required at Trustee discretion).
Disclaimer: WE WILL GENTLY AND KINDLY TURN AWAY ANYONE WE FEEL SHOULD NOT BE THERE, AND WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO DO SO.

description:
Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake – The Legend Returns, We are delighted to share some exciting news – for the very first time in New Zealand, the RNZB Foundation has secured the rights for a special one-off screening of Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake – The Legend Returns, filmed live at London’s Sadler’s Wells Theatre in 2019.
Matthew Bourne’s groundbreaking Swan Lake offers an exciting reimagining of the traditional ballet loved by millions and it has taken the dance world by storm. Even if you have been fortunate enough to see the live stage performance, this screen version brings another dimension to the ballet - quite simply, it’s breathtaking!

description:
A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland - Carterton, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland - Carterton
“Jingle Jigs, Reels a Treat.”
Ken Longworth – The Newcastle Herald

Direct from its Off-Broadway season, A Taste of Ireland - The Irish Music & Dance Sensation, presents its holiday spectacular, A Celtic Christmas. Prepare to be enchanted with some of the world’s finest Irish dancers and musicians bringing the spirit of Christmas to life, in a show that will make you laugh, cry, and sing into the night.

After captivating audiences across the USA and around the world, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland returns to New Zealand this festive season following a highly successful 2022 tour. Experience the magic as world-class performers blend melodic folk mash-ups, acapella tap battles, and heartwarming storytelling in one truly unforgettable performance.

Featuring former World Irish dance champions and stars from Lord of the Dance and Riverdance, A Celtic Christmas delivers a holiday spectacular packed with Irish wit, traditional tunes and heartfelt ballads, alongside all your favorite carols. The show’s exciting mix of electrifying rhythms and extraordinary talent promises an evening brimming with Irish charm and enthralling entertainment, all in one powerhouse event.

Immerse yourself in a traditional Celtic landscape and let the magic of an Irish Christmas transport you to a world filled with excitement and wonder, where vibrant music and dance embody the heartbeat of the festive season.

With over one hundred and fifty 5-star Facebook reviews and over 150,000 followers, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland promises 100% live singing and dancing as it bridges the gap between energetic folk music, Irish dance, and modern tap styles.

Don’t miss your chance to see this magical show as it tours New Zealand for a strictly limited season. Get your tickets now before they sell out.

**musical instruments are subject to change from performance to performance

Dress loud, sing proud, and channel your favourite Bowie era — from glam and soul to Berlin cool or ‘90s brilliance. It’s karaoke, but make it Bowie. 🌟

SAVE THE DATE - Saturday 28 February

About this Event


SAVE THE DATE - Saturday 28th February,2026

Imagine yourself sitting on the grass embankment, having a refreshing beverage and listening to some fine tunes, all while basking in the sun! What better way to spend a Saturday!
Hosted at one of Wellington’s iconic venues, Beers at the Basin is a one-day Festival showcasing some of the best Craft Breweries, Local Wineries, Street Food, and Music that NZ has to offer.

description:
Freak Slug - Wellington, Manchester based musician Freak Slug - the project of Xenya Genovese - will be welcoming audiences in Pōneke Wellington and Tāmaki Makaurau Auckland into her dreamy indie-pop world this October.

Hugely influenced by ‘90s cult heroes including Ride, Mazzy Star and Stephen Malkmus, Freak Slug is all about hitting a mood. Everything that fuels her creative output is raw, authentic, sometimes weird, but always totally true self-expression. I Blow Out Big Candles is a strong statement of all of this and more. Down there, picking through the curious mix of sounds and feelings, from nostalgic, ‘90s-influenced and dreamy as well as eccentric and experimental, lives Freak Slug.

The 10-track project gives listeners a taste of what they will be in for at her Aotearoa shows, a journey of both soft soulfulness and sonic songwriting, all laid out on the table.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Volunteer Info Evening- 2/57 Willis Street, Are you ready to make waves in conservation?
Join Mountains to Sea Wellington on our journey to restore and protect our marine and freshwater environments.
This information evening will give anyone interested in volunteering with us an opportunity to hear all about our volunteer programme and meet the MTSW crew.
There are lots of ways you can help us at MTSW! Are you into photography? Do you make a mean cuppa? Love to snorkel? Love to talk about marine critters? Nau mai, haere mai! We’d love your help! In return, we promise you a summer of adventure and fun times.
You're welcome to join us anytime from 5pm, there will be a short presentation at 5.15pm, followed by drinks and kai. There will be Mountains to Sea Wellington Staff onsite, as well as some of our current volunteers who'll be able to give you the inside word on what it's like to volunteer with us!
We’ll be in the Silver Lining Room at 2/57 Willis Street. Entrance is via the lifts in the alleyway to the left of Unity Books, take the lift to level 2.
RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/URvGHkFxRmEmALgq8 so we know how much pizza to order!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Carnival of Chaos, Myth, chaos, murder, alchemy, mystery, and devils are afoot in this four-night festival featuring six short retellings of classic works with strange new twists! We invite you to THEA 303’s ‘Carnival of Chaos’ in Studio 77, premiering hybrid works from the House of Echoes (1 & 3 October): The Odyssey, Medea and The Devil is a Lover, and the House of Secrets (2 & 4 October): Rope, The Taming of the Shrew  and  God’s Gift.

Each adaptation has been directed, designed, produced, choreographed and managed by the students.

House of Echoes (Season A): Performs on the 1st and the 3rd of October

The Odyssey – An adaptation of Homer’s The Odyssey
Odysseus just wants to get home to his true love, but the journey isn’t exactly smooth. The streets after 2 a.m. and too many beers are alive with obstacles; cops are grumpy, goth girls are tempting, and the help of the Gods is nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, back home, a dangerous polycule is getting cozy with his Penelope…

Medea – An adaptation of Euripides’ Medea
Medea lives her perfect 1950s white picket fence dream! When her husband starts taking new pills “Conservatol, the wonder drug for traditional love” she learns that traditional love means different to what she thought. Betrayal, hurt, and anger push her to the edge making her act in ways she never thought she would. “Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, nor Hell a fury like a woman scorned.”

The Devil is a Lover – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost and Ben Johnson’s The Devil is an Ass
Satan and two devils, Beelzebub and Pug, make a pact to travel to a 1920s speakeasy on Earth and abstain from corruption for 3 years. As the narrative combines absurdist actions with Shakespearean dialogue, the three devils quickly learn of the difficulties present in avoiding corruption and the effect their devilish meddling has on humanity.

House of Secrets (Season B): Performs on the 2nd and 4th of October

Rope – An adaptation of Patrick Hamilton’s Rope (1929)
Not a whodunnit, but a howdoyahideit? Marion and Melanie are sure they’ve committed the perfect murder by killing their friend Norman and hiding his body in a chest, a chest their select group of friends have been invited over to have a murder mystery games night around. It’s foolproof, until the over analytical Constance comes to play…

The Taming of the Shrew – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew
In 1970's Aotearoa, sisters Katherina and Bianca find their love lives complicated by their father's order that one may not pursue romance unless the other follows suit. The sudden appearance of a charming factory owner and friend of Bianca's beau could mark a new hope for the two, but will this lead to an ocean of love or does something far more sinister lurk beneath the surface?

God’s Gift – An adaptation of Ben Johnson’s The Alchemist
The Carnival has come to town in 1615 London. Lovewit has gone to see the show, leaving her manor in the hands of Jeremy the Butler, the “Alchemist,” and Dol, a hardworking prostitute. Lovewit’s house becomes a place for schemes, with ample opportunities to take money from foolish men. Will Dol be happy with her split of the money? Or will a surprise visitor shake things up?

Content Forecast: mentions of and implied sexual violence and domestic abuse, mentions of drug use, strobe lighting, violence, coarse language, loud noises, haze, and smoke.
label: Festivals

description:
Brew Year's Eve, Wellingtons biggest New Years Eve party is back at Brewtown.
Celebrate Brew Years Eve with the ultimate party night of legendary Kiwi anthems, wall to wall bangers and classic 80s hits on a night where the dancefloor never stops.

A New Years Eve celebration like no other, back by popular demand Dragon and The Jordan Luck Band, joined by The Automatic 80s & The Blueprint smashing out all the big party tunes you know & love.

The Soundtrack to Your Night
Our epic lineup will take you back in time with all your classic favourites:
Dragon — get ready for timeless anthems like April Sun in Cuba and Rain.
The Jordan Luck Band — Kiwi sing-alongs like Why Does Love Do This to Me and Victoria.
The Automatic 80s — taking you back with the biggest 80s dancefloor hits.
The Blueprint — Wellington's best rock covers band taking you through to midnight.

Say goodbye to 2025 with a bang — party with us as we transform Brewtown's covered Greenspace into a full-blown New Year’s Eve Party, packed with live music, massive party vibes, and all the magic to make your countdown unforgettable.

Wednesday 31st December
Brewtown, Upper Hutt
R18

Tickets:
$65 Early Bird tickets on September 9th (one day only). - Register now for exclusive access!
General Admission on sale September 10th.

This isn’t just another night out — it’s Wellington’s biggest party of the year!

So round up your crew, grab your tickets, and get ready for confetti blasts, big sing-alongs, and festival-scale fun as we count down to midnight together.

description:
Chilean Independence Day 🇨🇱🇨🇱, Chilean Independence Day 🇨🇱🇨🇱
UPDATE!!!! We’re moving the event to Sunday the 21st because of venue availability.

Vamos a celebrar este 18 de Septiembre como corresponde! ✨

Los queremos invitar a celebrar estas fiestas con la comunidad en el bowling de Seatoun.
Vamos a tener dos parrillas prendidas, juegos tradicionales (gymkana, carrera de sacos, la silla musical, una pichanga y hasta karaoke), además de música y baile pa’ que no falte el zapateo . 🎶⚽🔥
La idea es que cada uno traiga algo para la parrilla y algo rico para compartir: puede ser un postre, unas empanadas, sopaipillas, ensaladas o lo que se les ocurra. En el local se podra comprar bebestibles varios, incluso terremotos!!! 🍷🍻
Y porque no hay primera sin segunda ni segunda sin tercera… 🎉
Este año vamos a celebrar con varios panoramas:
⦁ Sábado 13 de Septiembre: celebración en el restaurant Puro Chile desde las 12pm a 7pm .

⦁ Sábado 20 de Septiembre en la noche: seguimos la fiesta en el barrio con DJ Descontrol.

⦁ Domingo 21 de Septiembre: en el bowling de Seatoun con nosotros desde 12pm.

También para los que quieran ir a apoyar y ver el show de Puku Rangi Tea (Grupo de danza de Rapa Nui) en Wellington.
⦁Martes 16/09: Performance en Scots College Wellington. FREE 7pm.
⦁Jueves 18/09: Presentacion en el musel Te Papa Tongarewa. FREE 1pm

¡Así que vengan con ganas de pasarlo chancho y celebrar juntos este 18 toda la semana!!!

Nos vemos pronto!!!!!!


Let’s celebrate this Chilean Independence day the right way! ✨

We’d like to invite you to join us for our celebration with the community at the Seatoun Bowling Club.
We’ll have two barbecues going, traditional games (gymkana, sack race, musical chairs, a friendly football match, and even karaoke), plus music and dancing so we don’t miss out on some good cueca steps. 🎶⚽🔥

The idea is that everyone brings something for the barbecue and something tasty to share: it could be a dessert, empanadas, sopaipillas, salads, or whatever you’d like. Drinks will be available for purchase at the venue, including Chile’s famous cocktail, the Terremoto.🍷🍻

And because one party is never enough… 🎉 This year we’ll be celebrating several events:

⦁Saturday, September 13th: Celebration at Puro Chile restaurant, from 12pm to 7pm.

⦁Saturday, September 20th at night: we keep the party going in El Barrio with DJ Descontrol.

⦁Sunday, 21 September at the Seatoun Bowling with us from 12 pm.

Also for those who would like to go and support and watch the show by Puku Rangi Tea (Rapa Nui Dance Group) in Wellington.
⦁Tuesday 16: Performance at Scots College Wellington. FREE 7pm.
⦁Thursday 18: Performance at the Te Papa Tongarewa Museum. FREE 1pm.

So come ready to have an amazing time and celebrate this Chilean Independence Day/Week together, not just once but several times!

See you soon. 🎉🎉🎉

description:
Courtenay Carnival - The Biggest Dress Up Party in the Universe, Wellington’s most electric street celebration is back! The Courtenay Carnival transforms Courtenay Place into a dazzling hub of music, food, dance, and community spirit. From day to night, experience an unforgettable fusion of live performances, street eats, parades, and cultural showcases—all in the heart of the capital’s entertainment district.
What to Expect
Live Stages & Street Performers – From DJs to drumlines, salsa to soul, and everything in between, Courtenay Place bursts with energy. Expect a vibrant mix of circus performers, roaming comedy acts, drag artistry, and pop-up surprises throughout the precinct.
Entertainment Lineup
• Kids Disco – A fun, high-energy dance zone for tamariki.
• Circus & Comedy Acts – Jugglers, acrobats, and comedians bringing laughter and spectacle.
• Drag Performances – Bold, colourful, and high-impact performances lighting up the street.
• Wellington Batucada – The iconic Brazilian drum ensemble leading parades and igniting the crowd.
• Startime Band – Feel-good party classics to get everyone dancing.
• Love Shack – A crowd favourite delivering big vibes and nostalgic bangers.
• Saxy Time – Bringing funky grooves and late-night energy to keep the party pumping.
Food, Flavour & Street Eats – Local venues spill out onto the street with special menus, pop-up tastings, and signature Wellington flavours. From quick bites to sit-down favourites, there’s something for everyone.
Parades & Cultural Showcases – Experience vibrant cultural performances, community groups, dancers, and musicians celebrating the diversity of Pōneke.
Family-Friendly Zones – With entertainment for all ages, Courtenay Carnival is designed to keep families engaged from day to night.

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Daffodil Express 2025
Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!

Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.

Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.

Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.

The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.

Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.

Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!

The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.

Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!

Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free

For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/

description:
GDNZ 2025 Shelly Bay Cleanup, Join Ghost Diving New Zealand for a community cleanup!

This will be an ocean and shore based clean up targeting rubbish in and around the Wellington foreshore.

Scuba divers, free divers and shore crew all needed! Be prepared to get wet and dirty!

DATE: Saturday October 11th 2025

TIMES:
9.00am - Registrations open
9:45am - Briefing
10.00am - Divers in the water
2.00pm Clean-up and pack down

LOCATION: Shelly Bay - look for the GDNZ signs.

Scuba Divers who wish to participate must have a minimum of 30 logged dives and be comfortable working in low / zero visibility.
Scuba and Free Divers must provide their own gear and tanks. If you also have your own catch bag(s) or float boat for collecting rubbish, please bring this along and ensure they are named.
If you would like to join in the fun and participate as part of the shore crew, you will need to make sure you are wearing fully covered shoes and bring a pair of gardening gloves... also be prepared to get dirty!

ALL PARTICIPANTS, SHORE CREW AND DIVERS MUST REGISTER ON ARRIVAL.

PLEASE NOTE:
• This is a free, family friendly event, but children must be supervised at all times by an adult.
• Closed toe footwear must be worn for safety.
• Please bring your own hand protection (gardening gloves or similar).
• Don’t forget your own water bottle and bring sunscreen if it’s a warm day.
• Dress for the weather (warm clothes and jackets)
• There will also be plenty of work for non-divers to get involved.
Should the event be cancelled due to circumstances out of our control, notification will be given on the Facebook page the night before. Please remember to check prior to the event.
We look forward to seeing you there!
