description:
Jazz Festival: DADS at the Undercurrent!, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

The Dancing And Drinking Society have been bringing their swing blues sounds to dance floors and craft beer bars across the capital since late 1913. When they take to the stage, guitar, horns, vocals, and kick drum blend as The Society present their favourite old rarities with exactly the sort of vigour you want for some stress relieving dance times. They’ve cultivated a decent reputation for generous and open-hearted live performance. If you feel like a decent drink and a leg shake or two, this would make for a pretty good option.

With Mat Enright, Adrian Jensen, Daniel Yeabsley, Blair Latham.

description:
City Welcome Session, City Welcome Session
If you've recently arrived in Palmy, we'd like to extend a warm kia ora and welcome you to our wonderful city!

Join us on 1 November at Palmy Conference + Function Centre, 354 Main Street, for our renowned welcome ceremony, hosted by Rangitāne. The pōwhiri, led by Rangitāne, will formally welcome all newcomers to Palmy.

After that, we'll come together to share kai (food) and get to know one another, followed by a walking tour of the city centre.

Registration is not required for this free event. We look forward to seeing you there!

Join Us on a Amazing Chinese Food Adventure, Join Us on a Amazing Chinese Food Adventure
Join us at the Chinese Corner on November 8th to explore the rich flavors and traditions of Chinese culinary culture! Learn about famous Chinese dishes, dining etiquette, and the stories behind them. Get a hands-on experience of making your own tanghulu (candied fruit) —sweet, crispy, and fun!

Whether you're a food lover or curious about Chinese culture, this event is perfect for you. Don’t miss this tasty experience!

description:
I-Sarn Thai KanTok, Join Daeng from Tuk Tuk Thai for a deeply personal culinary journey to the heart of E-Sarn, the north-eastern region of Thailand she once called home. This one-night-only event celebrates the traditional Kan-Tok style of dining – a communal meal served on handwoven bamboo trays and shared amongst family and friends. This event is made to be shared, the ticket price is for a shared menu for two. 

Growing up in the small town of Tha Bo near the Mekong Delta, Daeng’s childhood was filled with stories of rice farming, village generosity, and dishes cooked from what the garden offered. In E-Sarn, meals were acts of love, shared daily around the Kan-Tok with laughter, music, and warmth.

Now, Daeng invites you to gather at her table and experience the flavours of her upbringing. You’ll be served nine traditional dishes on a beautifully crafted bamboo tray, designed for sharing, just as they are in her village.

On the Kan-Tok:
Hor Mok Salmon – Steamed salmon in banana leaves, marinated with herbs, spices, and coconut milk
Mok Nor Mai with Pork Belly – Pork belly steamed with bamboo shoots
Larb Gai – A celebratory chicken mince salad with fresh herbs and toasted rice
E-Sarn Sausages – House-made, spiced and fermented in true north-eastern style
Nam Prik Tomato – Roasted tomato dipping sauce with chillies, garlic, and shallots
Som Tum – Green papaya salad with a sweet, sour, spicy kick
Sticky Rice – Soaked overnight and steamed in traditional bamboo baskets
Fresh and Steamed Seasonal Vegetables – To enjoy with sauces and mains

Dessert:
Kanom Chan – Thai layered jelly cake
Kanom Mun – Tapioca and coconut pudding

Pull up a seat at Daeng’s table and discover the stories, flavours, and traditions that shaped her childhood.
Single tickets or odd numbers unable to be catered to.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour
Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
• No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
• Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
• Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
• Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
• Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
• Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
• Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email or call 04 499 1400.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

Firstly, we'll have two special cocktails on for this weekend only using Imagination's premium range that we know you'll love. Then this is followed up by a brand new Beer Cocktail using their brand new Blueberry Spice Gin!
It looks and tastes amazing so do give it a try.

description:
Fluid Art Workshop, Fluid Art Workshop
Spend an evening unwinding with paint, good food, and good company. This beginner-friendly class is designed for everyone—you don’t need to be an artist to enjoy it. All the materials will be ready for you, and you’ll get to explore blacklight-reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints, experimenting with marble and swirl effects to create something completely your own.
Since the paint takes a few days to fully dry, your artwork will stay safely with us—you’ll be able to come back on Sunday to pick it up.
It can get a bit messy, so come in clothes you don’t mind getting paint on, and tie your hair back if it’s long.
After the painting, relax over a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, the perfect way to finish a creative and relaxed night.
Meet your host, Alannah
Alannah has been fascinated by blacklight art since she was 15 and has been exploring different mediums to find what really stands out for 20 years. She takes inspiration from all the wonderful artists she encounters in the real world and online. She noticed that this particular type of fluid art hadn't really been done the way she does it, so she has developed her own unique style utilising blacklight reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints. Let her colour your world and explore the possibilities of fluid art together.
................................................................................................
Booking for Thursday is recommended!
For more details and to book please go here--
https://bit.ly/eventTickets

Make Thursdays your night to connect and take a break from your week. Events range from creative workshops, wellness courses to entertaining experiences. All within a down-to-earth and welcoming space. Each event wraps up with a plant-based dinner and dessert.

description:
Love Language, Calling budding poets and hopeless romantics - this is your opportunity to share your love of language, with a food and poetry degustation. 
This four-course dinner is a physical manifestation of love and an ode to food. Join Simon Sweetman, Wellington writer, critic, musician and poet, as he reads some of his own poetry, and yours too if you're feeling game. Chefs Tim and Aaron Banks will lovingly create a four-course dinner with ingredients locally sourced and lovingly produced by small scale sustainable farmers... and perhaps they will read their own poems too. 
If you're feeling poetic bring along your own poem specially crafted around this year's festival theme 'Food is Love'. It can be as long or short as you like, as happy or sad, comical or tragic, Keats or Bukowski. Spot prizes for various categories including 'Most Related to the Theme' and 'Most Obviously Foodie' poems. Includes four courses, and a welcome glass of bubbles on arrival.

description:
Macaron Masterclass, MACARON MASTERCLASS
Presented by Le Ciel Bakery
Whisk, pipe, and finesse your way to perfect Parisian macarons

Join us for a hands-on masterclass where you’ll learn the secrets to mastering this delicate French treat — from glossy meringue to flawless feet. Led by Chef Shuchi Bhardwaj, this is your golden ticket to boujee baking greatness.

- Create & take home your own box of beautifully filled macarons
- Learn foolproof techniques, flavour infusions, and piping styles
- Start your evening with a complimentary glass of bubbles and a decadent Black Forest cake for two—because love (and baking) should always begin on a sweet note.

What you’ll learn:
- Mastering macaronage & piping flawless heart shapes
- Avoiding common meringue mishaps
- Chef’s expert tips for achieving that perfect crisp-yet-chewy texture

Only 12 people per class—an intimate setting where you’ll have Chef Shuchi’s full attention and guidance. Whether you're baking with your sweetheart, bestie, or favorite foodie, this experience is sure to be equal parts fun, romantic, and delicious.

Location: Le Ciel, 100 Tory street, Wellington
$62 per person
Limited spots are available—book now before they’re gone!

description:
Lunch Speaker Series, Noble Rot invites you to enjoy a relaxed lunch in style. While away your afternoon with a leisurely three-course menu as they keep the wine flowing amongst you and your friends. They've lined up two incredible guest speakers at the forefront of the wine industry to entertain you with their stories, knowledge and insights into current trends in a relaxed but intimate atmosphere. You'll wish all learning was done this way. It’s the perfect excuse to treat your friends, your mum or your date.
 
Guest Speakers & Dates:

Saturday 9th — ‘Small Region, Big Sky’
Katherine Jacobs and her husband Jeremy embarked on a dream to produce some of Martinborough’s finest wines from their special vineyard in Te Muna, and they’ve achieved great success! Katherine will speak about upcoming trends, big dreams and hidden secrets in our favourite region’s wine scene.
 
Saturday 23rd — ‘A Rosie Afternoon’ 
Enjoy the company of Rosie Finn of Neudorf Vineyards, second generation of one of New Zealand's most prestigious wineries in Nelson. You’ll have the opportunity to ask Rosie all about current trends as she combines the story of her family winery’s historic roots and its impact on the landscape of New Zealand fine wines.

description:
Reiki Level One - Wellington, New Zealand. Dec 13th & 14th, 2025.., Reiki Level One - Wellington, New Zealand. Dec 13th & 14th, 2025..
Discover the Gift of Reiki with Usui Reiki Level One

Usui Reiki is a gentle yet powerful method of natural healing, rediscovered by Mikau Usui over 100 years ago. It uses the flow of Universal Life Force energy to heal and rebalance the mind, body, and spirit. The beauty of Reiki lies in its simplicity and accessibility—everyone has the ability to connect with these healing frequencies. Reiki is a lifelong tool, ready to support you whenever you need it most.

In this Reiki Level One course, you will:
🌟 Learn how to perform a self-Reiki session and offer one-on-one Reiki to family and friends.
🌟 Receive the sacred Usui Reiki Level One attunement in person.
🌟 Begin a 21-day spiritual cleanse to integrate the energy shifts.
🌟 Study the history of Reiki, basic anatomy, chakra systems, and the frequencies of language and emotional states.
🌟 Gain practical tools to incorporate Reiki into your daily life.

This comprehensive course exceeds all standards set by Reiki NZ Inc. The training includes 12 hours of tuition spread over two days (both dates must be attended), with a 21-day integration period supported by ongoing guidance and a private Facebook group.

Includes:
✨ 12+ hours of expert tuition over 2 days
✨ Comprehensive manual and certificate
✨Cacao Ceremony to expand our hearts in preparation for our attunement
✨ Light healthy afternoon tea and herbal teas each day
✨ Access to a private Facebook group for support
Payment options, including plans, are available—please email me for details at .

Class size is kept small to ensure an intimate and personalized learning experience. A commitment to home study and self-Reiki practice is required for 21 days following the course.

🌟 When & Where:
📍 Capricorn Spirit, Willis St, Wellington
📅 Two days attendance required - 10.45am to 4.45pm, Saturday, December 13th and Sunday, December 14th.

🌟 About Your Teacher
Gina Noetica is one of New Zealand’s most experienced and dedicated Reiki Master/Teachers. Teaching all levels since 2008 and working as a professional Energy Healer (Quantum Energy Alchemy) since 2001, Gina brings a wealth of knowledge and a deeply intuitive approach to her courses. Her grounded, heartfelt teaching style empowers students to embark on their own journeys of healing and self-discovery.

I would be honoured to share this sacred practice with you.

Namaste,

Gina Noetica
Founder of the Centre for Expanding Consciousness
Professional Quantum Energy Alchemist & Reiki Master/Teacher, Consciousness Coach, Cacao Ceremonialist, CE5 Ambassador, Breathwork Facilitator.
📧
📞 022 413 6752

description:
This Wasn't The Plan: A Musical Theatre Cabaret, This Wasn't The Plan: A Musical Theatre Cabaret
This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse. Please take your seats in this cabaret classroom as lecturer, acclaimed musical theatre performer Glenn Horsfall, takes you through the twists and turns of a life imagined versus a reality lived. Glenn lays bare his journey of self-discovery, from the highs of childhood fame to the lows of bullying and self-doubt. With beautiful songs and hilarious, heartfelt, humbling stories, this show looks at what it means when the script of life gets rewritten. This Wasn’t The Plan picked up the Auckland Fringe Tour Ready Award and Outstanding Solo Performance Award at NZ Fringe 2025. It’s a must-see for anyone navigating change or questioning societal expectations.

“Masterclass in storytelling” - The Post

Tickets from https://www.tahifestivalnz.com/this-wasnt-the-plan

description:
Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions, Doctors For Nutrition and MTM Community Project invite you to an evening of inspiration, education, and connection at our next ‘Dine with a Doc’ dinner.
Join us for a presentation on ‘The Power of Plant-Based Nutrition and Lifestyle Interventions for Preventing Chronic Disease’—an event designed to empower everyone from healthcare professionals to health-conscious community members. You will also be the first to hear about the new MTM Community Project, and about their mission. 
When: 6:30pm – 9:30pm, Tuesday, 19th August 2025
Where: Gear Homestead, 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Wellington
Price: $50 (includes dinner and non-alcoholic beverage)
At this event, Dr Heleen Haitjema will take you on a journey through the clinical benefits of whole food, plant-based (WFPB) nutrition. Through easy-to-understand explanations of key concepts - such as endothelial dysfunction, intramyocellular lipid accumulation, and calorie density - you’ll discover how WFPB eating can dramatically improve health outcomes and transform lives. 
After the presentation, join us for a panel discussion and a Q&A session with Dr Haitjema and Dr Luke Wilson. 
The evening continues with a plant-based dinner curated by the chefs from MTM Community Project, served in the elegant setting of Gear Homestead. Enjoy the opportunity to connect and network with leading dietitians, specialists, GPs, and passionate members of New Zealand’s plant-based community.
Buy your tickets now; spaces are strictly limited!
Sponsored by: Little City Kombucha
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Mystery Feast on Mischief Night! Halloween dinner with Chef Max Gordy 🎃 Supporting Kaibosh., Mystery Feast on Mischief Night! Halloween dinner with Chef Max Gordy 🎃 Supporting Kaibosh.
🎃 Step inside, if you dare... on the eve of Halloween. It's a Mischief Night!
👻A chilling murder mystery unfolds over a hauntingly good three-course Halloween dinner by Chef Max Gordy!

On 30 October, gather your cleverest friends and find your darkest ghoulish attire 🧛‍♀️ Who will crack the case first: the Detectives or the Villains? 🕵️‍♂️
Expect twists, laughter, and a touch of fright 💀 with spot prizes through the night — plus a reward for the best-dressed.

👩‍🍳 Award-winning chef Max Gordy ( @grazewinebar ) will conjure up a frightfully delicious Halloween-themed feast.
🥂 Your ticket includes one complimentary alcoholic beverage (with more available to purchase on the night).
🙌 Every ticket sold helps Kaibosh ensure that no good food is left to die.

TICKET TYPES
Bring a team of six to solve the mystery and devour a fiendishly good feast for $666.
Have a frightening four-some? Book a table for $444.
Spooky single seats available for $111... we will seat you at a mystery table...

VENUE
60 Dixon Street is up a flight of steep steps – with only one way in.

What is Mischief Night?
In parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey in the eastern USA, 30 October is called “Mischief Night.” The tradition refers to the eve of Halloween in which children and teenagers celebrate the holiday one night early with pranks, tricks and more. While in New England, some call it Cabbage Night...
Join us to experience Chef Max Gordy's culinary take on Mischief Night in Pōneke!

#Halloween #HalloweenNZ #MischiefNight #MaxGordy #EveybodyEats #CharityDinner #FundraisingDinner #WellingtonDining #Pōneke #WellingtonNZ

description:
Netherfield Ball, Step into the enchanting world of Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice at Homewood, where the timeless elegance of a Regency-era ball comes to life. This evening of romance, music, and culinary delight invites you to relive the iconic moments of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy’s fateful meeting.

Guests will be greeted with crafted cocktails inspired by love potions, showcasing ingredients from some of the finest distilleries in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. As the evening unfolds, indulge in a carefully curated selection of canapés, created with fresh ingredients sourced from Homewood’s own garden, evoking the flavours and charm of the Regency period.

The grand setting of Homewood, the esteemed residence of the British High Commissioner, will transport you to a bygone era. With the glow of garden lighting, live music filling the air, and an atmosphere brimming with romance, you’ll feel as if you’ve stepped into Austen’s world. Dancing will play a central role in the evening, allowing guests to immerse themselves in the grace and grandeur of the Regency social scene.

Whether you’re an Austen devotee, a fan of Bridgerton, or simply drawn to the allure of historical elegance, this event promises to captivate your imagination and senses. Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a night filled with charm, sophistication, and timeless romance.
label: Food & Drink

Whether you’re an Austen devotee, a fan of Bridgerton, or simply drawn to the allure of historical elegance, this event promises to captivate your imagination and senses. Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a night filled with charm, sophistication, and timeless romance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Next Gen Cook Off, The Next Gen Cook Off returns for its fifth year, and things are heating up at Everybody Eats.
Every Monday in August, four of Wellington’s freshest young chefs will go head-to-head in a high-energy kitchen takeover, serving up epic three-course dinners using rescued food.

Each chef will be given the same protein, generously provided by Meat Direct, but everything else is a surprise—ingredients are revealed that morning, based on what’s come in. Menus are created on the spot, and dishes are served to a buzzing, hungry crowd. It’s fast-paced, creative chaos with serious culinary skills on display. Guests get a front-row seat to the action, while supporting a truly game-changing enterprise.

4 August — Jessie Gibberd, Loretta
Originally from rural Waikato, Jessie Gibberd made the move to Wellington to study, but it was the buzz of hospitality that captured her heart. Swapping textbooks for tongs, she left her degree behind to dive headfirst into the kitchen. Now a chef de partie at Loretta, Jessie brings a grounded, fresh perspective to one of the city’s most beloved eateries.

11 August — Felipe Molina, El Matador
Hailing from Chile, Felipe Molina is a professional chef with over 15 years of experience in kitchens around the world. Having worked in several countries and world-class restaurants, Felipe brings a global sensibility to his craft. With a passion for seafood, meats, and bold, expressive flavours, his cooking is shaped by travel and tradition, blending international influence with creativity on every plate.

18 August — Zane Gupwell, Graze
Zane Gupwell began his hospitality journey at just 15, washing dishes at a local café in Mount Eden. From there, he headed to Queenstown, learning from a wide range of chefs and kitchen styles before challenging himself with a move to Wellington. Since then, he’s worked at some of the city’s top restaurants and now brings his thoughtful, evolving style to Graze Wine Bar.

25 August — Lulu Temmuyin, Mr Go’s
Lulu Temmuyin is a chef who loves pushing boundaries, even when they’re unexpected. Lactose intolerant but obsessed with cheese, and not a fan of lamb but winner of a lamb cooking competition, Lulu is all about surprises. At Mr Go’s, she brings bold, sustainable flavour to the forefront, blending personality with punch in every dish.

Everybody Eats runs on a pay-what-you-can model, transforming food waste into gourmet meals and bringing the community together over good kai. The Next Gen Cook Off celebrates and champions this mission, proving that rescued food can be next-level delicious.

The Next Gen Cook Off is proudly supported by The Gas Hub.

description:
Nyumbani: A Taste of Tanzania, Journey through the heart of Tanzania with dishes that feel like home - comforting, bold, and full of love. This special five-course degustation is created by Chef Shuchi Bhardwaj, a baker who grew up in Tanzania and carries its flavours, traditions, and warmth in her heart. 
Whether it’s the warm embrace of coconut-infused stews, smoky grilled meats, or fragrant spiced rice, each course is a reminder of how food connects us. This menu brings authentic East African flavours to the table, reimagined in a modern way that feels like home. Each course is matched with a carefully selected wine to enhance the flavours of the dish. Expect generous hospitality and a setting that feels like stepping into a Tanzanian family gathering.

description:
Having Heard a Glow – Lewis Vivian Cosgrave, Here, everything was aglow - and everything was connected by a web of invisible thread… and this morning, a new strand - fine, but still perceptible - pulled lightly at her heels…
Lewis Vivian Cosgrave (Ngāti Pūkenga, b.1997) is a Te-Whanganui-a-Tara based artist primarily focused on the experience of the quotidian, a life found along concrete pavements and inner city gardens, his works blend an interest in painting, drawing and photographic practices. Cosgrave works to find intentional reticence through the alteration of collected and personal archive imagery. Erasing, saturating and muddying with a refined sense of surface and delicate use of colour, arriving eventually to a space that grants us momentary reflection on the ordinary rhythms of daily life.
A short story by Lucy Clara accompanies the show.
Opening Friday, 26 September at 5pm – kindly sponsored by Duncan’s Brewing, Almighty and The Garden Table. The exhibition runs from 27 September – 18 October 2025 at Twentysix Gallery.
Opening Hours:
Thursday 12pm - 6pm
Friday 12pm - 6pm
Saturday 10am - 4pm
Or by appointment

The Rotten Luck Club is at the Pop-up Parlour!

Come along for a 2 hour cheese-making demonstration and tasting session! Local enthusiast Erin will guide us through the process and share her love for all things cheese.

description: Santiago to Buenos Aires, Noble Rot sommeliers Maciej Zimny and Jessica Wood invite you to embark on their recent road trip through Chile and Argentina. They will indulge you with stories and share their experiences through these two fantastic wine countries alongside a South American themed five-course degustation menu including dishes they enjoyed on their journey. Relax and enjoy their tales and insight into why the wines taste the way they do, the key stylistic differences between the two countries, and learn from them first-hand the secrets of why Chilean and Argentine wines are ones to watch in the future.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Sconnoisseur, Get ready to master the art of making Wellington's iconic cheese scones at Pravda Café. Widely regarded as the home of the city's best cheese scones, Pravda's creations are so beloved, they often sell out before you can blink. Now, you can learn the secrets behind their mouthwatering scones firsthand.

In this hands-on workshop, you’ll be guided through mixing and preparing your own batch of Pravda’s famous cheese scones. Once your dough is ready, you'll hand them off to be baked to crispy flaky perfection. While they cook, relax with a cup of tea or coffee, and once your scones are ready, you’ll enjoy the fruits of your labour fresh from the oven.

The best part? You’ll get to take home the coveted recipe, allowing you to recreate these legendary scones in your own kitchen whenever you want. This is a perfect opportunity to learn a piece of Wellington’s culinary history and enjoy a deliciously rewarding experience.

Timing is flexible to allow for moving between locations, if you'd like to order food from The Social Kitchen food truck at the Brewery, etc. The latest finish time would be 8.45pm.

description:
Snacks Amore, When the host brings you bread, instead of a red flag...Snacks Amore!
Amuse Snack Bar invites food lovers to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of light-hearted speed dating and snack-based bonding at their Euro-inspired aperitivo haven. Whether you are after a snack (human) or a snack (sustenance), you're guaranteed to leave with a full heart and a satisfied appetite.
Each attendee will enjoy 12 mini dates and 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, pasta alla norma, porchetta, and zabaione, all served in perfect bite-sized form. A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home. Throughout the event, wines curated by the charming Richard Klein of Artigiano Imports will be on offer, alongside Amuse’s house spritz, Negroni, and Parrotdog Lager.
The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming – more aperitivo hour than high-pressure matchmaking. The Amuse team, also musicians, will guide the evening with playful icebreakers, musical moments, and a light-touch structure that makes meeting new people easy and enjoyable.
Two themed evenings allow guests to choose their best fit:

Evening 1: General Assembly
Grouped on the night by chosen generation:
• 5:30pm – Millennials (28–45)
• 7:30pm – Gen X (40–60)

Evening 2: Rainbow Night
Grouped by dating preference.
• 6:30pm – she for her upstairs, he for him downstairs.

The event warmly welcomes all gender identities and sexual orientations. Attendees will be asked to indicate who they’re interested in dating at checkout, but gender identity remains private unless individuals wish to share it. Symbols and nametags on the night will help create a fun and inclusive vibe. Amuse Snack Bar is proud to be an LGBTQIA+ friendly space.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Introduction to Acceptance and Commitment Therapy Workshop - November 2025, Introduction to Acceptance and Commitment Therapy Workshop - November 2025
A 2-day introductory, experiential ACT workshop for clinicians.

About this Event

Growing research about ACT demonstrates its efficacy for a wide range of diagnoses and life problems. It helps people accept their internal experiences while moving towards the life they value.
At this experiential workshop you will establish a foundational understanding of Psychological Flexibility, develop skills for using ACT and learn about Relational Frame Theory (RFT).
Over the two days you will learn how to:
help clients hold their painful thoughts and emotions gently; identify and actively move towards their values; and develop awareness of the present moment and their capacity to observe it.
develop a therapeutic relationship in which support can be provided compassionately and flexibly.
formulate life struggles from an ACT perspective.
practice ACT exercises and relate the concepts back to your own life and clinical experiences.
meet clients where they are and foster their willingness to change.
This workshop is fully catered with vegetarian food.
Giselle Bahr and Ben Sedley are clinical psychologists and co-founders of ACT Wellington. They have been using ACT for over 15 years, and have been trained and supervised by many leading ACT therapists and researchers. Giselle and Ben have both worked at Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services, in Private Practice with adults and adolescents, and in the clinical psychology programme at Victoria University. Giselle has developed and facilitated ACT groups for parents and adults, and served on the Board of ANZ ACBS. Ben is the author of Stuff That Sucks: Accepting what you can’t change and committing to what you can, the co-author of Stuff That's Loud: A teen's guide to unspiralling when OCD gets noisy (with Lisa Coyne) and is an ACBS Peer Reviewed ACT Trainer.


QUESTIONS AND MORE INFORMATION
How can I contact the organiser with any questions?
Please get in touch if you have any questions about this training. You can email us at:

Can I have a GST Receipt?
If your employer requires a GST receipt from you, please email us and we will send you one.

What's the refund policy?
A refund is available until 30 days before the workshop. This includes all costs except for the eventbrite nonrefundable fee.
A 50% refund is available until 14 days before the workshop.
From 14 days before the workshop, your ticket is non-refundable but fully transferrable. To transfer your ticket to another attendee contact us with the new details.
Full refunds will be made if the event cannot proceed due to Covid19 restrictions, or attendees are unable to travel to the event due to Covid19 restrictions.
label: Health & Wellness

Amuse Snack Bar invites food lovers to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of light-hearted speed dating and snack-based bonding at their Euro-inspired aperitivo haven. Whether you are after a snack (human) or a snack (sustenance), you're guaranteed to leave with a full heart and a satisfied appetite.
Each attendee will enjoy 12 mini dates and 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, pasta alla norma, porchetta, and zabaione, all served in perfect bite-sized form. A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home. Throughout the event, wines curated by the charming Richard Klein of Artigiano Imports will be on offer, alongside Amuse’s house spritz, Negroni, and Parrotdog Lager.
The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming – more aperitivo hour than high-pressure matchmaking. The Amuse team, also musicians, will guide the evening with playful icebreakers, musical moments, and a light-touch structure that makes meeting new people easy and enjoyable.
Two themed evenings allow guests to choose their best fit:

Evening 1: General Assembly
Grouped on the night by chosen generation:
• 5:30pm – Millennials (28–45)
• 7:30pm – Gen X (40–60)

Evening 2: Rainbow Night
Grouped by dating preference.
• 6:30pm – she for her upstairs, he for him downstairs.

The event warmly welcomes all gender identities and sexual orientations. Attendees will be asked to indicate who they’re interested in dating at checkout, but gender identity remains private unless individuals wish to share it. Symbols and nametags on the night will help create a fun and inclusive vibe. Amuse Snack Bar is proud to be an LGBTQIA+ friendly space.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Spring wine degustation -France meet Aotearoa-, After the success of our Mid-winter wine degustation, Smoked & Pickled and Tim Russell invite you to celebrate the well awaited Wellington spring with their 'Spring Wine Degustation -France meet Aotearoa-' in the relaxed atmosphere of the restaurant at Vogelmorn bowling club.
Join us for a casual evening of drinking, eating and mingling around all things wine and food.
You will be introduce to a selection of wine curated by Timothy Russel from Russel Grant paired with a French/Kiwi 6 course degustation menu imagined by Craig and Alice at Smoked & Pickled.
$80 per person
Book now at smokednpickled@gmail.com
Limited space available so get in quick.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Bikespace - Road Ready Workshop, With the arrival of Spring what better time to get your bike ready for the road.
We’re continuing our series of one hour workshops targeted at those who want to learn a bit more about how their bike works and how to maintain & repair it to keep it running at its best.
This workshop is more general than some of our other more topic specific sessions. We will cover:
* Road Readiness. A front to back check for safety and performance
* Drivetrain tuning and maintenance
* Brake tuning and maintenance
* Tyres & Tubes. Pressures and repair.
Sunday, September 21st from 9:00am to 10:00am at the Bikespace workshop.
We'll spend most of the hour with interactive learning followed by time to work on individuals bicycles. To allow hands-on participation we are limiting the numbers to this workshop to 8 people and their bikes. Please indicate in the comments if you would like to attend and we will confirm attendees for this session.
We have a number of people indicate interest and then not attend the session. Please make every effort to attend if you sign up.
Due to our lack of covered outdoor space there is always the possibility that we have to reschedule if the weather is really uncooperative.
Bikespace is a Wellington City Council initiative allowing us to offer all our services at no cost to participants.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Sourdough Doughnuts & HOT FOOD at The Animal Medical Centre, Each Wednesday afternoon, Family Kitchen with Mark and The Animal Medical Centre team up to offer you sourdough doughnuts & hot, delicious, affordable meals.
From 2:30pm, at 114 Middleton Road, we'll have sourdough doughnuts in six flavours, mini-celebratory doughnuts, plus a hot dish.
This week's hot dish is fritto misto (breaded mixed fish and vegetables) with Italian roasted potatoes and Caesar salad.
Our sourdough doughnuts are priced at $22 for a box of 4 or $6 each. We also offer mini-celebratory doughnuts, a box of all six flavours for $25. The main hot dish is priced at a very reasonable $18 per portion.
EFTPOS is available.
If you want to pre-order, go to our website https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/weekly-menu/
We really appreciate The Animal Medical Centre allowing us to sell outside their new business.
Should you require an excellent veterinary service, contact the team at NEW Animal Medical Centre
https://www.animalmedicalcentre.co.nz/
Family Kitchen with Mark also offers catering. You can visit our website to see our packages if you have a function or require in-house dining. Our doughnuts are also available for purchase Monday to Saturday. Could you contact us to organise?
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/grazing-tables-theme.../
My website has a list of flavours and ingredients for each doughnut. Search weekly menus.
label: Food & Drink

description: Sweet Sensations, Noble Rot wants to sing the praises of sweet wines and help you to learn that they aren't just one note. They'll showcase a range of wines from around the world that lean towards the sweeter side without leaving a cloying sensation on your palate, enhanced by a specially-curated five-course degustation menu from entree to dessert. If you would like to explore your favourite level of sweetness in wine, this event is for you. The knowledgeable Noble Rot team are here to show you that sweetness is one of wine’s most versatile assets, as well-balanced sweetness in wine can be delicate, elegant and complementary to both sweet and savoury dishes. Discover how some grape varieties are more suited to producing sweeter wines and how their level of sweetness is achieved. If you're into the sweeter things in life, this one is for you.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Halloween Dress-up Ecstatic Dance, Elevate your vibe & find your soul tribe through this ecstatic dance experience guided by a live DJ.
The flow will transport you through a myriad of emotions, expressions, creativity, depth and bliss.
Let go of your inhibitions, set free your barriers & allow yourself to freely move and feel the flow where beat and dance meet.
$10 on the door (Limited door sales)
This is an alcohol and drug free event

Tickets are now available for Te Omanga Hospice's largest fundraising event - the Vintners' Lunch!

description:
The Casual Dram: 19, It’s time for another Casual Dram, and this time we’ll be taking a look at distillation rates - with double, partial-triple and triple distilled whiskies all making an appearance.
If you’ve ever looked at the flow chart for partial triple distillation, you’ll know that this sort of thing can be pretty complex!
But fear not, I promise we won’t be getting too scientific - and we’ll taste an interesting mix of official and independently bottled crackers, across a multitude of ages from some all-time fave distilleries; Mortlach, Benrinnes, Bunnahabhain and Amrut.
Here’s the lineup…
Bunnahabhain 12 years old 2023 Cask Strength Edition 60.1% (Sherry casks) WB 87.27
Mortlach 'Signatory Symington's Choice' 2007 / 17 years old #205 56.6% (1st Fill Oloroso Sherry Butt Finish) WB 88.23
Benrinnes Adelphi 13 years old 55.5% (1st Fill Oloroso Sherry Hogshead) WB 88.19
Amrut Triparva Triple Distilled 50% (casks as yet unknown) WB 87.19
Mystery whisky WB 88.11
I hope you can join me for another tilt at five tip top drams!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Science Bites School Holidays science workshops, Get hands-on with some tasty, edible science these school holidays! Science Bites is an edible science workshop for tamariki aged 8-12 years old.
Learn about rainbow diffraction chocolate, make your own gummy worms, explore some glow-in-the-dark jelly, and more! All the projects in this workshop are safe to eat, meaning kids can taste their creations as they learn.
Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!
Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.
Tamariki can be dropped-off in the morning and picked-up afterwards; caregivers are not required to stay for the duration of the workshop. Tamariki should bring a packed lunch.
This workshop will involve handling and consuming some known allergens and substances your child may be sensitive to. Please refer to the Space Place website.
Best suited to ages 8-12 $65 per tamariki.
label: Kids & Parents

description:
The Epic Life of Kahe Te Rau-o-te-Rangi, Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum is excited to have Miria Pōmare share the beautiful tāonga of her family’s story for Wellington Heritage Festival.

Miria comes from a long line of influential wāhine Māori. Her namesake, Lady Mīria Pōmare (1877-1971), was a community leader who spent much of her life advocating for the benefits of both Māori and Pākeha. In 1918, Lady Mīria was appointed an OBE for her service to the Māori Soldiers’ Fund which was established to help provide soldiers with comfort (food, knitted garments, letters) while they were away from home. Lady Mīria Pōmare’s story is shared in a display in the Attic of Te Waka Huia.

Hear the life story of modern-day Miria’s tupuna and great Rangatira Kahe who was one of five women who signed Te Tiriti in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Nau mai, haere mai to hear more about this Mana Wāhine and her truly epic life.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Enchanted Ale Quarter, Enter the magical realm of The Enchanted Ale Quarter, a fairytale-inspired pop-up tavern where whimsy, wonder and craft beer collide.

Step into a storybook setting, with twinkling lights, woodland decor, and forest-fantasy touches around every corner. Feast on gnome and fairy-themed comfort food like the solstice salad, loaded forest fries, sirens & ships fish & chips, and a decadent dark forest brownie, all paired with enchanted brews and mythical tipples.

Cosy, curious, and otherworldly, The Enchanted Ale Quarter brings a little magic to Wellington’s winter nights. Dust off your wings and join us for a pint, some sustenance or a potion, no quest required.
label: Food & Drink

description: Tire-toi une bûche, Executive Chef Jonny Taggart shares his love for the classic – and not-so-classic – flavours of Quebec. Fresh from a culinary adventure in Montreal, Jonny returns with an open heart, an inspired palate, and plenty to share. This special menu will feature everything from Tourtière (French Canadian meat pie) and smoked meat sandwiches to the beloved pairing of poutine with a steamie (Montreal-style hot dog), along with the sweet and comforting tarte farlouche. No need to book. Just come along with your friends and family and enjoy these French Canadian delights!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Milk and Coffee, Milk and Coffee
In a world where Mums are everything to everyone, come along to ‘Milk and Coffee’ and let us look after you. ❤️

We are also on hand to offer some breastfeeding and parenting support.

Come and have a FREE coffee and snacks with us and get some FREE support and guidance from a trained breastfeeding counselor.

Just bring yourself (and the baby) and let us look after you. ❤️

description:
Tītahi Bay Spring Community BBQ, Tītahi Bay Spring Community BBQ
It's (nearly) summer so it's time for a BBQ! Come and join us at 43 Kapiti Crescent (St Matthew's Hall) for a BBQ on the lawn. If it's bad weather, we will move into the hall.

All welcome! Dinner will be served from 5pm; we will make dinner, so just bring yourselves!



FAQ

Who is this for? Can I come along?

Yes absolutely, please come, we would love to have you. This dinner is for all the people who live in the beautiful community of Tītahi Bay!

What if I can't make it until a bit later?

That's all good, we will be serving a rolling dinner from 5 to 6.30pm so come whenever suits you. If you can only come a little later than 6.30pm, we will likely have more than enough so come anyway!

Can I bring my kids along?

Yes! In fact, please bring your kids along. We will have some games in the room and some options for crafts on the tables along with the food.

Do I need to bring anything?

Nope! Just yourselves, all are welcome just as you are.

But I really want to bring something to contribute?

If you would like to bring a salad to contribute to the BBQ, feel free to email us at and we can chat! We really just don't want this to be a barrier to anyone coming along.

Can I help?

Yes absolutely, this is a community event so help is always appreciated. It is also a great time to meet some other people. We will have some tasks for set up and also some for packing down and cleaning up. If you are interested in helping, flick us an email at

Will my dietaries be met?

We will make sure there will be options for these dietaries: vegan, gluten free, dairy free, and nut free.

If you have a dietary that isn't on there, feel free to check and flick us an email.

Can I bring my friend(s) along?

Yes, please bring your friends along, especially if they live in Tītahi Bay!

Who is this hosted by?

This idea is hosted by us, the crew who run Tītahi Bay Anglicans, but it is run with the help of our friends around Tītahi Bay. The hope is that this can become a recurring community event where others can join in on hosting this.

This is at a church, will I be preached to?

No, we promise that this isn't a Tupperware party bait and switch. While we definitely are a church, this event is for the Tītahi Bay community as a whole to be able to come eat together and connect.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Urban Cocktail Trail, On Sale Times
Presale Access - Thursday 31 July, 10am NZST
General Access - Thursday 31 July, 12pm NZST
----
Grab your mates and discover the best bars in Pōneke Wellington on the self-guided Urban Cocktail Trail! Whether you're a cocktail lover, or just up for a fun afternoon out, this trail is all about good drinks and great vibes!

Kick things off with a bite at your starting venue, then make your way around using your cocktail vouchers. Where you go and what you sip is totally up to you!

Tickets will fly, so lock yours in and get ready for an afternoon of flavour and fun!

VENUES + SIGNATURE COCKTAILS
1. Dirty Little Secret Ft. Peachy Pear
Absolut Pear Vodka + Vanilla Galliano + Peach Syrup + Lemon Juice + Egg White
2. Ernesto's Ft. Pimm'd to the Brim
Pimms + Cucumber Gin + Strawberry Liqueur + Juices
3. Otto Champagneria & Beer Hall Ft. Saigon Sunset
Papaiti Orchard Gin + Lemongrass Liqueur Syrup + Ginger Syrup + Lime Juice + Soda + Mint
4. Rosie's Red-Hot Cantina Ft. Coconut Margarita
Cazcabel Coconut Tequila + Triple Sec + Lime Juice + Agave Syrup
5. St John's Bar Ft. Tiki Trail
Sailor Jerry Spiced Rum + De Kuyper Banana Liqueur + De Kuyper Mango Liqueur + Kwai Feh + Lychee Liqueur + Lemon Juice + Pineapple Juice + Grenadine
6. The Old Bailey Ft. Pash & Dash
Rum + Passionfruit Liqueur + Passionfruit Syrup + Lime + Lemonade + Mint & Lime Garnish

TICKETS (Limited Availability)
Option #1 – The Connoisseur | $99
$10 Food Voucher for your chosen starting venue (valid until 2 PM)
6x Cocktail Vouchers to enjoy at any participating venue (valid until 5 PM)

Option #2 – The Trailblazer | $75
$10 Food Voucher for your chosen starting venue (valid until 2 PM)
4x Cocktail Vouchers to use at any participating venue (valid until 5 PM)
Note: Food options may vary from the venue’s regular menu due to the event format.

EVENT REGISTRATION & VOUCHER COLLECTION
Pick up your event vouchers and guide at the designated registration point before starting your trail.

Event Day Registration
Location: Ernesto's (1 Grey St, Te Aro)
Date: Saturday 6th September
Time: 12 PM – 1:30 PM

REFUND POLICY
Sorry no refunds, unless the event is cancelled/postponed by the organiser

GETTING AROUND
Aside from the amazing cocktails, one of the best things about the Urban Cocktail Trail is that it's a completely self-guided day out! What that means is once you've been to your nominated starting location you can go where you want, when you want!

Neighbourhood Events Co. recognises the unique role of Māori as Tangata Whenua and embraces Te Tiriti o Waitangi recognising Māori as Tino rangatiratanga of Aotearoa/New Zealand while embracing the three guiding principles of the Treaty – Partnership, Participation and Protection. We will endeavour to implement bicultural policies and practices that incorporate and value Māori cultural concepts, values and practices.

description:
Give it a go day, Bring the family and join us for a day packed with softball excitement! Swing for the fences in our own batting cage, have a hit around with our junior level, enjoy thrilling games from our senior level tournament while savouring a BBQ delight. This is a chance for everyone to experience the thrill of softball firsthand. Don't miss out on the fun at Te Atiawa Park, Sunday 5 October 12-2pm.
See you there, ready to hit it out of the park!
For more info or to register go to:www.kapitisoftball.co.nz | info@kapitisoftball.co.nz

description:
Crazy Ladies, Pamela Browne has organised a 25 year reunion for her four best friends from High School. From the moment Kay, now a chocoholic gun-toting funeral director arrives, the wheels begin falling off Pamela’s meticulously planned weekend.
Added to the mix is Sandy, who is now a Nun, Dianne, married the school nerd and is a mother of eight sons, Rachel, a runaway teenager on a mission to dig up some dirt on her mother, and Shaun, the greasy motel janitor, who ends up in a compromising position in the ladies’ wardrobe.
Guns, gags, cuffs, crucifixes, sleaze-balls , slander, pizza and pinot – everything you need for a great weekend reunion!

description:
Traditional Kölsch Service!, Kölsch Service is BACK!! Enjoy our fresh batch of Dösen Kölsch the traditional way - just like in Köln.
What's Kölsch service?
It's kinda like beer yum cha but there's only one thing on the menu - 200ml glasses of Kölsch bier!

We keep track of your tab by marking the edge of your coaster and when your glass is empty - voilà, another glass appears!
If you're done, just pop your coaster on top of your glass to indicate no more.
You can order food and non-alcoholics the same way, just take a seat and everything will come to you.
To make sure you get a table, book here: https://www.meandoses.co.nz/bookings
PLUS DEUTSCHES ESSEN!

We're serving up Apache's take on Currywurst - the classic German streetfood that is a dream with a crisp Kölsch. Yes we'll sort some vegan ones too!
We're also slinging more amazing fresh Brezels
from Brezelmania, served with cheese sauce

We'll be running Kölsch service from 12pm - 5pm on Saturday October 4th, come along and get the Köln experience!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.
label: Government & Politics

description:
We 💛 Mac 'n' Cheese, A feast with purpose, where every bowl makes a difference.
Celebrate the final day of Visa Wellington On a Plate and the end of winter with the ultimate comfort food: mac 'n' cheese, served all day long.

Two of Wellington’s legendary food rescue and community dining champions, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh, are joining forces to serve piping hot mac 'n' cheese, raising funds to help feed the community. As official charity partners of the festival, they are turning comfort food into real impact.

For just $10, each bowl will help fund a three-course meal for someone in need through Everybody Eats or provide a day’s worth of food for a family via Kaibosh.

Customise your mac with a range of toppings and flavours, all made from rescued food, showcasing just how delicious food recovery can be. In the lead-up to the event, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh will be calling on their social media followers to share their favourite mac 'n' cheese combos, with the top picks featured on the day.

Diners can enjoy their meal seated in the Everybody Eats restaurant or opt for takeaway to share with the whānau or flat.

The goal is to serve 2,000 bowls and fund 2,000 meals for the community. Join the celebration, enjoy incredible kai and help make a real difference.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Bunnings Warehouse NPC: Lions v Bay of Plenty, Bunnings Warehouse NPC: Lions v Bay of Plenty
Don’t miss this one! The Wellington Lions face Bay of Plenty in a rematch of last year’s epic final, this time at Porirua Park. With their last two clashes locked after 80 minutes, this round robin match is bound to be a ripper!


GATES OPEN: 1:00pm
KICK OFF: Wellington Lions vs Bay of Plenty - 2:05pm


SHUTTLE BUSES: Skip the parking hassle and jump on our FREE Rambler shuttle bus to the next three Lions home games at Porirua Park. Take the bus and be into win awesome golf spot prizes from The Morgans Golf Course & Judgeford Golf Club. Buses will run from the eastside of the Porirua train station to Porirua Park commencing at 1:00pm, 1:20pm and 1:40pm. Buses will loop from Porirua Park to Porirua train station for one hour following the game.


GIVEAWAYS: The first 150 kids at the Lions game (from 1pm) will receive 6x FREE player trading cards! Also for giveaway are 2024 Lions Championship Posters, Lions flags available for giveaway.


ENTERTAINMENT:
Pre Game Activations
• NPC Trophy photo opportunity with Leo the Lion

Halftime
• Rick Rolls ROAR n Race


POST-MATCH HANGOUT
After the game, keep the good times rolling! Join us at The Supply Room (105 Mana Esplanade, Paremata) and meet the team.


GATE ENTRY:
- $25 - Adults
- $14 - Students
- Kids 15 years and under free.

Wellington – My Home, Our Lions
#ROARwithUs

description:
Wellington Crack Chicken x Heinz Fried Chicken Sauce Pop-Up, Heinz’s fan-favourite Fried Chicken Sauce has finally landed in Aotearoa, and it’s making its NZ debut in style – with a limited-time pop-up collab at Crack Chicken. Already a hit with fried chicken fans overseas for its creamy, sweet and spicy kick, the sauce is now hitting Crack Chicken menus nationwide for one week only.

On the special menu:
- The Supreme Chicken Burger (crispy fried chicken, slaw, pickles and a generous layer of sauce)

- Crack Chicken’s golden Blooming Onion made for dipping,

- Plus the option to add the new Heinz Fried Chicken Sauce to anything and everything on the menu.

When: Friday 3 – Sunday 12 October 2025

Where:
- Crack Chicken Ponsonby – 168 Ponsonby Road, Auckland
- Crack Chicken Hamilton - Made Mess Hall - 401 Grey Street, Hamilton East
- Crack Chicken Willis Lane – 1 Willis Street, Wellington Central
- Crack Chicken North City - North City Mall – Porirua

Hot tip: Sauce lovers and fried chicken fans won’t want to miss this limited-time pop-up – once it’s gone, it’s gone.

description: Young Flame, Young Flame is a dining experience inspired by fire. Think fire show and flaming cocktail on arrival to then dine surrounded by hundreds of flickering candles casting a warm glow, for an evening of fine finesse. QT Wellington’s Executive Chef, Antoine Collet, delivers a bold three-course chef’s tasting menu that’s as deliciously playful as it is refined. And if you like the finer things in life, while devouring each course you'll sip on beer & wine to your heart's desire and let the sultry sounds of live music weave through the room, adding a touch of old-school glamour to your night. Young Flame promises an evening steeped in elemental elegance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Wings of Fire Challenge 2025, The Tasting Room Wings of Fire Challenge is back for 2025!

5 hot wings that get hotter as you go. Can you do all 5 and get your picture on the Wings Hall of Fame board?

We have teamed up again with our mates at Emerson's Brewery to bring you 2 different exciting brews to choose from this year, spice up your challenge further with with the Ghost Chilli Farmhouse Ale, or cool those taste buds with a refreshing Mango Lassi Sour.

Wings of Fire will be available from 1st October - 31st October, every day from 11.30am until 9pm, so come and see how hot you can handle.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Āhuru Kai Kōhua Poaka: Burger Wellington, The boil-up is a dish of love, traditionally made in big pots for whānau and friends. It brings people together. Te Papa wanted to capture the essence of this traditional Māori kai and give it a gourmet twist.

Traditional boil-up pork roulade, with Pagro lettuce and tomato, puha mousseline, and horopito aioli in a toasted Brezelmania watercress milk bun, with hand-cut kūmara fries, mānuka honey aioli, a shot of bone broth, and a heart-shaped raspberry framboise dessert.

Join us at the Te Papa Cafe on Level 1, walk-ins welcome. Reserve your spot by booking now.

Please note we aren’t able to accommodate dietary requirements.
label: Food & Drink

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.
label: Government & Politics

description:
AGM 2025, Hi everyone! Just letting you all know that next Thursday 14th August will be the Paremata Residents Association AGM
We are hosting the event at Mana Cruising Club (Ngati Toa Domain) and it gets underway at 7:00pm.
We have a guest speaker from Wellington Water (Steve Hutchison, Chief Advisor Wastewater) who will discuss the water network in our area, and give us insight into planned activities and future plans.
We also will run through the usual formalities required for associations (minutes, financial reports etc) and will try our best to not let it be to boring *insert sleeping emoji*
If anyone is keen on joining the committee team, you're welcome to put your name forward on the evening. Or send an email or Facebook message and let us know if you are interested.
The association needs good and willing people to help represent the local community and make our area a great place to live
See you on the night!

2025 Review of Retirement Income Policies, By 2030, over a million Kiwis will be 65+. Retirement is changing — and so are the needs of our older generations.
Join us for a talk with Dr. Patrick Nolan on the 2025 Review of Retirement Income Policies. He will share insights on the changing landscape, KiwiSaver’s role, policy gaps, and how we can build a fair, sustainable system for the future.
Don’t miss this important discussion about what retirement will look like for New Zealanders in the years ahead.
Seats are limited for Pizza & Salad for $30pp prior to the talk.
RSVP garamdelhi7@hotmail.com by 5pm on 16Sept’25

description:
Australia, New Zealand, and a post-American Asia, Foreign and defence policy in Australia and New Zealand needs to grapple with the likelihood that the US won't compete with China for regional leadership. Canberra and Wellington thus need to develop strategies that emphasise self-reliance, yet Australia in particular is pursuing ever-closer integration with the United States.
Sam Roggeveen is Program Director of the Lowy Institute’s International Security Program. He is the author of The Echidna Strategy: Australia’s Search for Power and Peace and Our Very Own Brexit: Australia’s Hollow Politics and Where it Could Lead Us. Before joining the Lowy Institute, Sam was a senior strategic analyst in Australia’s peak intelligence agency, the Office of National Assessments, where his work dealt mainly with North Asian strategic affairs, including nuclear strategy and Asian military forces. Sam also worked on arms control policy in Australia’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and as an analyst in the Defence Intelligence Organisation. Sam writes for newspapers and magazines in Australia and around the world, and is a regular commentator on the Lowy Institute’s international magazine, The Interpreter, of which he was the founding editor from 2007 to 2014. Sam also serves as lead editor at the Lowy Institute, and editor of the Lowy Institute Papers.
All welcome but please register to attend.

description:
Café des Idées in Wellington - Sealife stories from the subantarctic, Café des Idées in Wellington - Sealife stories from the subantarctic
Join us for the next Café des Idées - Sealife stories from the subantarctic: links between France and New Zealand

About this Event

The next Café des Idées, organised by and , is honoured to host Wendy Nelson and Kevin Hackwell for a captivating discussion on the shared scientific and environmental connections between France and New Zealand in the subantarctic marine world.

Wendy will be talking about important marine collections made on French expeditions of discovery to the NZ subantarctic in the early 1800s that are housed in the Herbarium of the Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris.
Wendy has been collaborating with Professor Line Le Gall (Departement Origines et Evolution) and for two weeks in October they worked to locate and document these important specimens - uncovering answers to some long held questions about the identity of species described over 180 years ago and not found subsequently.
In this talk she will take you into the Herbarium of the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, Paris - and highlight some of the remarkable treasures housed there.
(This work was supported by funding from the French Embassy in Wellington and the Royal Society of New Zealand Te Apārangi.)
Kevin will talk about the importance of the marine protected areas in the subantarctic and initiatives that have been taken to protect critical habitat for southern seabirds and connections between French and NZ in this critical work.

Wendy Nelson is a botanist and marine biologist, currently Senior Research Fellow Auckland Museum Tāmaki Paenga Hira
Kevin Hackwell is an ecologist, formerly Chief Conservation Advisor for Forest & Bird, a sister organisation to LPO (Ligue pour la Protection des Oiseaux)

📅 Friday, 05 December 2025 - 5.30pm
📍 Alliance Française Wellington, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎟️ Free entry, koha donation
label: Government & Politics

description:
Creative Futures: Arts, Economy and System Shifts, Join celebrated artist and cultural leader Teremoana Rapley MNZM for a powerful wānanga exploring the role of creativity in shaping local economies and systems. From local identity and wellbeing to economic growth and policy influence, this workshop invites artists, community leaders, and changemakers to reimagine the power of the arts in our region.
Through kōrero and shared storytelling, we’ll unpack how artistic practice can drive systems change and strengthen Lower Hutt's inclusive, culturally rich creative economy, one that reflects indigenous and local voices of communities across Te Awa Kairangi.
Teremoana Rapley MNZM is a pioneering artist, broadcaster, and cultural leader whose work spans music, television, and indigenous creative advocacy. Of Kiribati, Rarotonga, Aitutaki, Mangaia, Cuba, Jamaica, and Suriname descent, she first rose to prominence with Upper Hutt Posse and Moana & the Moahunters. Her practice is rooted in indigenous storytelling, systems change, and mentoring, often acting as a “Matriarchitect” to uplift others. With accolades including the Pacific Music Awards Lifetime Achievement Award and induction into the Aotearoa Music Hall of Fame, Rapley continues to shape Aotearoa’s creative landscape through collaboration, education, and community engagement.
In partnership with Toi Rauwhārangi College of Creative Arts, Massey University.
Light refreshments provided.

label: Government & Politics

description:
Suffrage Day Walking Tour Bolton Street Cemetery, It's Suffrage Day on Friday 19 September, marking the day in 1893 when New Zealand became the first self-governing country in the world to grant women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.

To celebrate our pioneer women, and those who signed the Suffrage Petition in 1893, we're taking a walk through the cemetery, talking about the roles of settler women from 1840 onwards.

We'll meet at the Seddon Memorial at the top of the cemetery (by Anderson Park) in time to set off at 11.00am, and we'll finish at the Museum in Bolton Street about 12.30pm.

This tour is suitable for all ages, but full mobility is required. Cost $10 per person, children under 12 free, and good dogs on leads welcome.

description:
Fifty Years of New Zealand International Review, This event commemorates 50 years of publication of New Zealand International Review, the NZIIA flagship publication for fostering discussion and understanding of international affairs as they relate to New Zealand. It also acknowledges the immense contribution of Ian McGibbon, who steps down as the Editor of New Zealand International Review after 44 years.
Join us to hear reflections from Ian on his four-plus decades in the role, a presentation by previous editor and historian Malcolm McKinnon on the evolution of New Zealand’s relations with the outside world and other speakers to be confirmed.
The event is followed by a food and drink reception.
Entry is on a 'pay what you like' basis to help cover the costs of the reception.
label: Government & Politics

description:
From Rome to Wellington – 75 Years of Friendship and Global Cooperation 🇮🇹🇳🇿, 🌍 From Rome to Wellington: 75 Years of Friendship and Global Cooperation 🇮🇹🇳🇿
Celebrating 75 years of diplomatic relations between Italy and New Zealand, this special event highlights the shared values, cultural connections, and enduring partnership between the two nations built on mutual respect, creativity, and a commitment to global peace and sustainability.
Join us for an exclusive fireside chat with
H.E. Cristiano Maggipinto, Ambassador of Italy to New Zealand,
as he reflects on 75 years of friendship and explores opportunities for future collaboration in diplomacy, culture, trade, and education.
Hosted by the Embassy of Italy in Wellington in collaboration with the United Nations Association of New Zealand – Wellington Branch, this event offers a platform for dialogue and exchange between the diplomatic community, academia, and the public.
Thursday, 20 November 2025
5:30 – 7:00 pm (5 pm arrival for 5:30 start) (followed by Italian refreshments)
RHLT3, Rutherford House, Victoria University, Wellington
Why Attend:
Celebrate 75 years of Italy–New Zealand friendship and cooperation.
Engage directly with the Ambassador of Italy in an open, insightful discussion.
Explore how both nations are working together to promote peace, sustainability, and shared prosperity.
Network with diplomats, students, academics, and community leaders.
Ambassdors Bio:-
Cristiano MAGGIPINTO
Born in Noci, Bari (Italy) on 20/12/1962.
1987: graduates from the University of Florence, degree in political science.
1989: joins the Italian Diplomatic Service and is assigned to the Directorate General
for Economic Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Appointed Second Secretary.
1993: First Secretary (Economy and Trade) in Tel Aviv (Israel).
1997: First Secretary for Social Affairs in Bonn (Germany).
1999: confirmed in Bonn and subsequently in Berlin (Germany) as Counselor for
Emigration and Social affairs.
2001: returns to Rome and serve as Chief of Staff of the Director General for Italians
Abroad and Migration Policies.
2004: promoted First Counselor.
2006: Consul General in Huston (USA).
2009: First Counselor for Emigration and Social Affairs in Washington (USA).
2011: appointed Minister Plenipotentiary.
2013: returns to Rome and serves as Head of the Communication and Evaluation
Office of the Directorate-General for Development Cooperation.
2017: Ambassador of Italy to Malaysia.
2021: Diplomatic Advisor to the Mayor of Florence (Italy).
2024: back to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Protocol Department.
In 2006 receives the Knighthood of the Order of Merit of the Republic.
Languages: Italian, English, French.
Married, no children.

This evening promises inspiration, meaningful conversation, and a celebration of two nations’ shared journey from Rome to Wellington.

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.

description:
Stitch & Butch @ Blondini’s, Stitch & Butch @ Blondini’s!
A casual meet up of crafters within the rainbow community
New members welcome.
Bring your knitting/crochet/cross stitch/embroidery/crafting/art or just come and have a chat.
Feel free to come partway through the time or leave early as needed.
Stitch and butch is a playful twist on the stitch and b!tch name to reflect the queerness of the group. Attendees do not need to be in any particular subset of the queer community to be welcome.
Usually gathered around one of the tables in the lounge area upstairs. Often near the walls for the brighter lights to better see our stitches.
There is a lift as well as stairs and Courtenay place bus stops across the road.
Held on the 2nd and 4th Mondays of the month with a summer break.
